name: The Clerk
content: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australias loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australias bicentennial celebrations in 1988.Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable house will:(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present Australian national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that whereas:(1) Identification cards and numbers severely threaten our freedom to live unfettered by excessive bureaucratic surveillance;(2) the Government has been unable to present any realistic justification for the introduction of ID cards and numbers;We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should reject any proposal to inflict ID cards and numbers on the freedom loving people of Australia.To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.Being signatures collected at a meeting organised by `Scientists Against Nuclear Arms in conjunction with the Mosman Peace Group on Tuesday 11th February at which Dr Barrie Pittock of C.S.I.R.O. talked on the subject on `Nuclear Winter.On 29 January 1986 the Sydney Morning Herald and The Australian reported that R.A.N. Lt. Commander Lynch (Ret.), who for four years had organised the visits of nuclear powered and/or nuclear armed warships to Western Australia, had warned about the danger to Perth posed by such visits.In the light of this warning, the undersigned residents of harbourside suburbs are concerned at reports in the Mosman Daily and The North Shore Times that nuclear armed and/or nuclear powered naval vessels will visit Sydney harbour in March/April and again in October.We appeal to our elected representatives to protect us from the possibility of a nuclear accident by ensuring that no nuclear armed and/or nuclear powered vessels are allowed to enter Port Jackson.To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:This petition of concerned Australian citizens asks that:1. The Australian government exert pressure on Moscow to-a. Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;b. Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,c. Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.2. The Australian Government-a. Launch a public appeal to help the Chernobyl victims;b. Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;c. Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic states are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; andThat the Government issued in December 1985 guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes.Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-preservation of benefits to retirement,vesting of employer contributions,equal employer and employee trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

content: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:That the Senate, noting that-(a) according to reports on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio news on 3 June 1986, a high temperature thorium reactor at Haan on the Ruhr River in West Germany, the only one of its type, which opened in April 1986, developed a leak on 4 May 1986;(b) West German farmers have felt constrained to block roads leading to the nuclear reactor, claiming there was a cover up of news about the leak by the company operating the plant which initially blamed the high level of radiation in the area to the Chernobyl disaster in the Soviet Union;(c) the plant is now closed, indicating the seriousness of the situation;(d) the State Government covering the area has warned that if the results of an inquiry into the accident are not satisfactory the reactors licence will be withdrawn;(e) local farmers, concerned about their crops, want the station closed for good; and(f) serious accidents at nuclear plants are becoming far too frequent for the general safety of mankind,urges the Federal Government to use its good offices in the United Nations to have world-wide safety checks instigated, with a view to setting minimum standards which all nations must observe.

debateinfo: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator COONEY
content: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned about a possible inconsistency between the terms of the Fisheries Act and terms of certain paragraphs of the plan. I wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) last Friday and the Committee urgently considered his reply this morning. In order to allay the Committees concerns, the Minister has agreed to add further criteria to the plan in connection with the suspension and the cancellation of certain fishing licences. The Committee also noted that the Minister had received legal advice from the Attorney-Generals Department, which he accepts, supporting the argument that the relevant paragraphs of the plan are valid. The Committees scrutiny of this plan and related fisheries notices has been long and detailed, as I described in the Senate on 29 May 1986. The Committee acknowledges the considerable and very courteous assistance it has received from the Minister for Primary Industry in its scrutiny of the legislation. As is the Committees usual practice, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committees correspondence for the information of honourable senators and others.Leave granted.The correspondence read as follows-MINISTER FOR PRIMARY INDUSTRY THE HON. JOHN KERIN, M.P.Parliament House,Canberra, A.C.T. 2600Telephone (062) 73 1711Telex 62308Facsimile (062) 73 2194Senator B. CooneyChairmanSenate Standing Committee onRegulations and OrdinancesThe SenateParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 2600Dear Senator CooneyThank you for your letter of 30 May 1986 concerning Plan of Management No. 3 under the Fisheries Act 1952 (the plan) and Fisheries Notices Nos. 158, 160 and 162. I am pleased to receive your advice that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has accepted all but one of the explanations in my letter of 27 May 1986. I also appreciate your opening remarks about that letter in general.In relation to the unresolved issue of the possibility that paragraphs 35.1 and 36.1 of the plan may have the effect of fettering the discretion that section 9a of the Act confers on the Minister to suspend or cancel a licence, I enclose a copy of the advice from the Attorney-Generals Department to which I referred in my letter. This advice indicates that in the opinion of that Department those paragraphs are a valid exercise of my power to make plans of management.Nevertheless, I have noted the general tenor of your letter which addresses the fairness of the two paragraphs. Given the reasons conveyed to you for not making reviewable a decision to suspend a licence and noting that a decision to cancel a licence is reviewable under section 16a of the Act, I have concluded that the interests of fairness will indeed be better served, without weakening the intent of the paragraphs to provide criteria on which to base decisions under section 9a of the Act, if I amend them so that the kinds of previous convictions to be taken account of by the Minister or the Secretary, in the case of a decision to suspend, or the Minister, in the case of a decision to cancel, are expressed more specifically.I therefore propose to insert a new paragraph in the plan that will describe an offence against paragraph 13 (1) (e), (f), (g), (h) or (i) of the Act, or against sub-section 14a (1) when the primary offence is against any of paragraphs 13 (1) (e), (f) or (i), as a ``relevant offence for purposes of Part 10. For purposes of sub-paragraph 36.1 (b) (i) of the plan, an offence against a provision of the Fisheries Regulations requiring the master of a boat to furnish information in relation to his fishing in the fishery will also be a relevant offence. Appropriate consequential amendments of Part 10 will also be made.In relation to your comments on the requisite intention which probably forms an element of many fisheries offences, the relevant intention is to do the act the substance of the offence, and not a criminal intention to damage the prawn fishery. The defendants intention would have been to use a boat to which fewer than the applicable number of Class A units have been assigned or to take prawns in a closed area or during a closed season or with prohibited equipment. In the case of paragraph 36.1, which applies only to a master-fishermans licence, the intention to withhold information or to furnish false information, required to provide me with essential data for managing the fishery, could also have existed.Since commencement of the plan, it has been open to a person who has had a master-fishermans licence cancelled to seek review of the period specified, in accordance with paragraph 36.2, in the notification that I am required to give under sub-section 9a (3a) of the Act. I would have regard to the merits of the case when determining whether that period should be a matter of days, weeks, months or years, up to the maximum specified in relation to the particular case by paragraph 36.2.I think it appropriate, and the representatives of the fishing industry who advise me about management of the fishery strongly support me in this, that a chronic offender against the overall management regime for the fishery should not be permitted to continue to participate in it if the offences have been proved before a court.You will note that the plan does not provide criteria upon which I would make a decision to cancel a boat licence. It is not the intention of the plan, where a person has had a master-fishermans licence cancelled, that the person should also be deprived of the right to hold a boat licence, although paragraph 37 of the plan does provide for suspension or cancellation of units of fishing capacity in relation to the boat involved in the offence. These provisions have been carefully drafted to provide the person with options that are reviewable if exercised by the Secretary.I believe that the proposed amendments of the plan will dispose of the paradox described in your letter. I do not agree that the AAT would have been precluded from considering any matter; they will be able to review any matter other than the fact of one or more previous convictions. The AAT had, and will continue to have under the amended plan, power to review a decision as to a period specified in accordance with paragraph 36.2.It was never the intention of the plan to cause mandatory loss of a right to a livelihood without appropriate review. First, the offence must be proved beyond reasonable doubt. Next, because the plan never envisaged the cancellation of a boat licence, the holder of a boat licence who also had his master-fishermans licence cancelled can continue to use the boat for fishing in another fishery under the command of an employed master-fisherman. Third, the plan requires the decision maker to have regard to the merits of the case in relation to the period of refusal of a further master-fishermans licence. Fourth, a decision made by the Secretary rather than a unit holder to cancel units assigned to a boat involved in the commission of an offence or to suspend that assignment, is specifically reviewable. The Secretary would make such a decision only if the unit holder had failed within the time specified to make an election as to which option he preferred.I have approved the amendments of the plan to which I have referred above and expect that they will come into force without delay after they are printed and notified in the Gazette.Yours sincerelyJOHN KERINPARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIATHE SENATESTANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES30 May 1986The Hon. John Kerin, M.P.Minister for Primary IndustryParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 2600Dear Minister,At its meeting on 29 May 1986 the Committee considered your letter of 27 May 1986 in connection with the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan No. 3 and Fisheries Notices Nos. 158, 160 and 162. The Committee acknowledges the consideration you have shown it in preparing such a detailed response to the Committees letters of 15 April 1986. Indeed the Committee is happy to accept virtually all of the assurances and explanations given in your letter.However, the Committee respectfully seeks your further clarification in relation to one aspect, namely the validity of paragraphs 35.1 and 36.1 of the Plan, which the Committee originally considered may be an unlawful fetter on the discretion conferred on you by section 9a of the Fisheries Act 1952. This particular aspect is dealt with in the last 2 paragraphs on page 2 of your letter. These paragraphs do not completely resolve the Committees uncertainties about the question.The Committee respectfully seeks your reconsideration of the question whether there may not be persuasive legal authority for the view that paragraphs 35.1 and 36.1 of the plan are invalid because they will have the effect of precluding the exercise of the discretion conferred on you and the Secretary by sub-section 9a (1) in connection with suspension of fishing licences, and on you alone by sub-section 9a (3) in connection with the cancellation of fishing licences. If in a particular circumstance you or the Secretary are precluded by the legislative instrument known as the Plan from actually exercising the suspension and cancellation discretions primarily conferred upon you by the Act, then these paragraphs of the Plan may be beyond power and may therefore be invalid. You may have disabled yourself and the Secretary from exercising the statutory discretion which Parliament has conferred on you in individual cases.The Committee would illustrate its concern in this way. Sub-section 9A (3A) of the Fisheries Act gives you a discretion to cancel a fishing licence if the holder has committed an offence under Commonwealth, State, Territory or PNG fishing laws. Cancellation of a licence means that a person and possibly a crew loses a source of livelihood. The Committee has no means of knowing with certainly, but it may be that some of the relevant offences in any of the 4 separate jurisdictions are offences of strict liability in the commission of which there has been no criminal intention to damage the prawn fishery. If there were no Plan, then, in such a case, or in any other case where mitigating circumstances were present, notwithstanding that there were two convictions you could exercise your discretion in favour of the licence holder and not cancel the licence. The Act gives you that discretion which must be exercised fairly in accordance with the purpose and objectives of the Act. General principles of administrative law might require that some measure of natural justice be afforded to the licence holder, for example the making of representations in mitigation, justification or excuse. However, if in the light of all of these matters, including the requirements of your own ministerial policy concerning the management of the fishery, you decided to cancel the licence, the merits of your cancellation decision could be reviewed by the AAT under section 16a of the Fisheries Act. The Tribunal could consider that given the purpose and object of the Act and your fishery management policy, the merits of the case did not, in all the circumstances, justify the individuals loss of livelihood.However, having made paragraph 36.1 of the Plan, which makes it mandatory that the licence of a holder who has two convictions under Commonwealth law only (paragraph 36.1 (b) (i) ) shall be cancelled, you may have disabled yourself from exercising a genuine discretion in a particular case directly involving individual interests. Yet this is the discretion conferred on you by Parliament in sub-section 9a (3a) of the Act in relation to individuals.General principles suggest that you must be prepared to make an exception to your general policy if the circumstances of the case warrant special treatment. The amplitude of the discretionary power to make Plans conferred on you be section 7b may not be so wide in connection with cancellation of licences as expressly dealt with in section 9A that you are expressly or impliedly entitled to adopt a fixed rule never to exercise your discretion in favour of a particular class of person. In the words of Lord Reid``The general rule is that anyone who has to exercise a statutory discretion must not ``shut his ears to an application (to adapt from Banks L. J.) [in R v Port of London Authority, Ex parte Kynoch Ltd [1919]1 K. B. 176 at 183] . . . What the [decision maker] must not do is to refuse to listen at all. (see British Oxygen Co. Ltd v Board of Trade [197] A.C. 610 at 625.)Paradoxically, where the relevant convictions have arisen under State, Territory or PNG law, paragraph 36.1 of the Plan may not apply and you may have retained your section 9a discretion.Nevertheless, where there are convictions under the Act or the Regulations you may have precluded yourself from considering any matter other than the fact of two Commonwealth convictions. In the adoption of such a rule you may have made it impossible to consider the merits of any particular case and the AAT may equally be precluded by the legislative Plan (as it would not be by a non-legislative statement of policy) from considering any question other than the fact of two convictions. If there are mitigating factors, such as strict liability offences or extenuating circumstances, these cannot be taken into account. The mandatory loss, under delegated legislation, of an effectively unreviewable right to a livelihood may be seen to be unfair and contrary to principle. The fact that you may not have actually exercised any discretion in the matter, when Parliament, in section 9a, intended that you should exercise some discretion, may make the cancellation unlawful. The paragraphs of the Plan, purporting to disentitle you from exercising any discretion, may be invalid.The Committee appreciates that complex legal questions are involved in the matter it has raised and that you have already given a detailed response which has satisfied the Committee on all but this outstanding issue. However, Principle (a) of its terms of reference require the Committee to scrutinise delegated legislation to ensure that it is in accordance with the statute and that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Committee would be very grateful to receive your comments and advice on the issues raised in this letter. It may be that further considered advice from the Attorney-Generals Department can allay all of the Committees uncertainties. However, the Committee, while at one with you on the need to protect fisheries, is nevertheless concerned that the reasonable rights of fishing licence holders to engage in their livelihood should rest on clear and unquestionable legal authority and should not be dependent on uncertain or doubtful propositions.It would be most helpful if you could let the Committee have your further views as a matter of priority. Because the time within which the relevant notice of motion of disallowance must be withdrawn or dealt with is about to expire, it would greatly facilitate the Committee if it could hear from you by Tuesday morning 3 June 1986.Yours sincerelyBARNEY COONEYChairmanMotion (by Senator Cooney)-by leave-agreed to:That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day for the disallowance of the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan No. 3, be postponed till the next day of sitting.

I seek leave to make a short statement.Leave granted.
debateinfo: EXTRADITION (FINLAND) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) AND RATES (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator COONEY
content: —The Extradition (Finland) Regulations (Amendment) had the effect of removing from the legislation the requirement that, before extradition could be granted, evidence of criminality accompanying a request for extradition should be sufficient to justify the trial of the person under Australian law. The Committee was concerned about the removal of this protection. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has explained that the deletion was made to give effect to last years changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act which was designed to facilitate extradition to civil law jurisdictions which do not have pre-trial evidence procedures. For extradition from such countries, what is required is information as to the allegations against the fugitive. The Extradition Act itself no longer requires that prima facie evidence of criminality be provided and the regulations have followed that approach. In the regulations the Attorney-General is following the policy foreshadowed in the amendments to the Act and the Committee has accepted his indication that persons subject to extradition requests will not be unduly prejudiced by the change because of the presence of a range of other protections in the regulations.The Rates (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 changes the way in which rates are assessed when improvement work is done to land by private developers rather than the Commonwealth. The intention is to have all improved land assessed on a similar basis. The Committee was concerned to discover what effect the Ordinance would have on applications currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal concerning rates assessment on a basis more advantageous to occupiers of privately developed land. The Minister has assured the Committee that the amendments do not operate retrospectively and that pending applications for review will be dealt with in accordance with the law as it was before the amendment was made. As is the Committees usual practice, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard copies of the Committees correspondence on extradition matters for the information of honourable senators.Leave granted.The documents read as follows-PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIATHE SENATESTANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES15 April 1986The Hon. Lionel Bowen, M.P.Attorney-GeneralParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 2600Dear Attorney-General,At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered the Extradition (Finland) Regulations (Statutory Rules 1986 No. 32) tabled in the Senate on 9 April 1986. These Regulations amend the Principal Regulations to take into account a Protocol to the Extradition Treaty between Australia and Finland done at Helsinki on 10 September 1985. The Principal Regulations now provide that the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 applies in relation to Finland subject to the Treaty as amended by the Protocol.The Protocol appears to make an important change to the Treaty. Previously sub-paragraph 1 (f) of Article 5 provided that extradition could be refused where ``the evidence of criminality could not have justified the trial of the person sought under Australian law. Under the Protocol, inadequacy of ``evidence of criminality is no longer a matter to be taken into account in the exercise of the discretion to extradite.The discretions described in Article 5 of the Treaty are protective discretions. The deletion of the paragraph limits the range of reasonable protections which, until the gazettal of these Regulations, have been available to protect the rights of a person sought. The Explanatory Statement accompanying the Regulations is rather brief and does not refer to the deletion of the paragraph. In its letter to you of 15 May 1985 concerning Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations, the Committee previously commented on the inadequacy of Explanatory Statements accompanying extradition regulations.The Committee would be grateful if you could explain the reasons and justifications for the deletion of the paragraph and indicate what consequence it will have for Australian extradition laws generally and the rights of persons whose surrender is sought in particular.From the point of view of the Committees Principles ``persons whose surrender is sought may include innocent persons who may be migrants, refugees, exiles or political dissidents whose rights should not be eroded by delegated legislation without adequate justification made public in an Explanatory Statement.Yours sincerelyBARNEY COONEYChairmanDeputy Prime MinisterAttorney-GeneralParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 260019 May 1986Dear Barney,I refer to your letter dated 15 April 1986 in which you expressed concern about the Protocol to the Extradition Treaty between Australia and Finland done at Helsinki, on 10 September 1985 and about the Extradition (Finland) Regulations (Statutory Rules 1986 No. 32-`the amending regulations). The amending Regulations give effect to the Protocol, by amending the Extradition (Finland) Regulations (Statutory Rules 1985 No. 163) to provide that the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 (`the Act) applies in relation to Finland subject to the Treaty, as amended by the Protocol.You noted that the Protocol appears to make an important change to the Treaty in that the discretionary ground for refusal of extradition previously found in sub-paragraph 1 (f) of Article 5 of the Treaty has been removed. That sub-paragraph provided, in effect, that extradition could be refused if the evidence of criminality accompanying the request for extradition would not be sufficient to justify the trial of the person under Australian law.This is indeed an important change to the Treaty and I can well appreciate that the Committee is concerned that it might be seen to limit the range of protections for the rights of persons sought. I must say, however, that this change was carefully considered in 1985 and has not been made for a specific or ulterior purpose of limiting the rights of individuals.The change was made in order to give effect to the amendments to the Act that were made by the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Act 1985. In my Second Reading speech on the Bill for that Act I said (Hansard of 20 March 1985 at page 596) in reference to amendments proposed to section 17 of the Act that this amendment ``will enable Australia to conclude extradition arrangements with countries which do not require the requesting country to furnish evidence of guilt but rather information as to the allegations against the fugitive. I went on to say, ``This amendment is of particular significance to civil law countries whose systems have difficulty in adapting to the provision of pre-trial evidence. The extradition arrangements of most European countries which are reflected in the European Convention on Extradition do not require the production of prima facie evidence. In other words, therefore, the deletion of sub-paragraph 1 (f) of Article 5 of the Treaty by the amending Protocol is purely consequential upon the fact that the Act no longer requires that prima facie evidence of criminality be provided.In order to put the matter you have raised concerning the amending regulations fully into context, I think that I should also inform you of other new extradition Treaties or Protocols to existing treaties which adopt a similar approach to that taken in the Protocol with Finland, that is, an approach which does not require prima facie evidence to support an extradition request.Following the amendment that I have mentioned above and other amendments of the Act, the Extradition Task Force that I established in February 1985 urgently to conclude extradition arrangements with appropriate countries has negotiated new treaties with Belgium, The Netherlands, Norway, Ireland and Italy and Protocols amending existing treaties with Austria and Sweden, as well as with Finland. These new treaties and protocols employ this approach, as do the texts of treaties that have been negotiated with Switzerland, Portugal, Luxembourg and Monaco. Negotiations for new treaties, once again using this new approach, are also at an advanced stage with France, Spain and the Federal Republic of Germany.In fact, I would hope that by the end of this year Australia will have modern extradition treaties or arrangements with all the non-communist European countries and that significant progress will have been made for new treaties with the United States and a number of North African, Asian and South American countries. The new treaties will, wherever possible, adopt the approach that prima facie evidence is not required. I must stress, however, that these treaties and protocols either reflect or will reflect the scheme of the Act and provide the internationally accepted grounds for the refusal of extradition. Those grounds serve to protect the rights of all persons whose extradition may be sought.I should also mention that the new approach in relation to extradition treaties is not confined to civil law countries. Later this year I hope to persuade countries which are members of the British Commonwealth that the requirement that prima facie evidence be provided for extradition between Commonwealth countries should be deleted. I intend to try to do this at the meeting of Commonwealth Law Ministers which is to be held in Zimbabwe at the end of July and I am fortified in my resolve to propose this change by the publication recently of a White Paper by the British Government for Plans for Legislation in relation to Criminal Justice. In that White Paper, a copy of which is attached, the Home Secretary announced that the British Government intends to discard the prima facie case requirement for the purpose of extraditions between Britain and non-Commonwealth countries.It is worthwhile that I note in passing one particular passage from the White Paper, because it accords with my own thinking and is most relevant to the Committees concern about the amending Regulations. The White Paper states at para 50:``. . . the Government believes that the prima facie requirement should be abolished. The requirement does not offer a necessary safeguard for the person sought by the requesting state; if does, however, present a formidable impediment to entirely proper and legitimate extradition requests. There are other effective ways in which the rights of the fugitive are protected-for example; by the double criminality rule and by the proper application of the political safeguard.I have noted your concern about the brevity of the Explanatory Statement accompanying the amending Regulations. In view of the fact that my Second Reading Speech, to which I have referred above, foreshadowed that there would be changes to the prima facie case requirement in future extradition treaties, perhaps the Committee will see the brevity of the Statement as being a matter of less concern than the Committee had originally thought. Be that as it may, however, I have directed my Department to ensure that Explanatory Statements contain more detail in future and, in particular, that the Statements in relation to the new Treaties that I have mentioned above do likewise.Yours sincerelyLIONEL BOWENSenator Barney CooneyChairmanSenate Standing Committee on Regulationsand OrdinancesParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T.PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIATHE SENATESTANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES2 June 1986Your ref: M86-5323The Hon. Lionel Bowen, M.P.Attorney-GeneralParliament HouseCanberra, A.C.T. 2600Dear Attorney-General,At its meeting on 29 May 1986, the Committee considered your letter of 19 May 1986 concerning the Extradition (Finland) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1986 No. 32). The Committee also considered aspects of the British Home Office Paper ``Criminal Justice, Plans for Legislation, March 1986 (Cmnd. 9658, in particular, Part IV, Extradition) which you were good enough also to send to the Committee. The Committee has obtained the Green Paper referred to therein, on which Part IV of the Report was based.As is evident from your letter, you appreciate that this Committee would naturally be concerned about the apparent loss from extradition law, of a seemingly protective requirement for extradition. While the Committee could not regard the Finnish legal system or its law enforcement officials in the same manner as it might regard those in South Africa with which it originated its continuing interest in extradition regulations, the Committee is nevertheless, on principle, concerned at any prospect that the rights of any persons whose extradition is sought should be diminished without clear and persuasive explanations.The Committee thanks you for your very detailed and considered reply which indicates that the change reflected in the Regulations is a flow on from amendments made last year to section 17 of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 which repealed the former requirement in paragraph 17 (6) (b) for the production to a Magistrate of such evidence as would, in the opinion of the Magistrate, according to the law of his or her jurisdiction, justify the trial, in that jurisdiction, of the person for the alleged extradition crime.Without such authority from Parliament itself, the Committee might not have accepted the removal of the evidence of criminality provision in the absence of compelling examples of how its continued inclusion in Treaties had thwarted proper and effective extradition of persons who otherwise deserved to stand trial in requesting countries. For example, the Committee notes from the British Green Paper ``Extradition (Cmnd. 9421, February 1985) that``Something like a third of applications made to the United Kingdom under our extradition treaties fail, often because of the inability of the requesting state to satisfy the prima facie case requirement. Furthermore, there are occasions on which some states are deterred from making a request at all because they believe that it will be too difficult to meet the requirement. (emphasis added)The Committee also notes the argument, made at paragraph 2.6 of the Green Paper, that``If we are sufficiently satisfied with the standards of justice in a foreign state to enter into a treaty obligation, we should not require that country to meet procedural requirements here which differ markedly from their own. It should, in principle, be for the requesting state to judge the sufficiency of the evidence for a trial of the fugitive.The Committee acknowledges, of course, that generally, and particularly since its scrutiny of the South African Regulations, you have manifested your commitment to ensure that effective extradition procedures operate in tandem with effective protection of the rights of prima facie innocent persons.The Committee notes your comments about Explanatory Statements and welcomes your decision to ensure that these are somewhat more detailed in future. These statements are of considerable assistance to the Committee and others in comprehending the background to an instrument of delegated legislation and in understanding a Ministers intentions as to its particular effects.Yours sincerelyBARNEY COONEYChairman

name: Senator CHANEY
content: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister again to the Prime Ministers comments at Canowindra in which he said that he would investigate the impact of the fringe benefits tax on farmers providing accommodation for their employees. I refer also to Mr Hawkes answer at Question Time in the House of Representatives yesterday in which he said that he was seeking information and kept open the possibility of change to the fringe benefits tax. In view of the fact that the debate on the legislation is likely to finish today, I ask the Minister: Has the Government completed its inquiries in this matter and, if so, will any change be made to the tax on farm accommodation?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —This was going to come out in the Committee stage of the debate this afternoon, but yesterday, as well as the matter having been raised at Question Time, Senator Chipp spoke to me and asked me whether I would try to get a statement from the Prime Minister for the benefit of the Australian Democrats. I said I would and later last night the Prime Minister supplied me with a copy of the letter. I think the best thing I can do is to read it now. I am sure Senator Chipp will not mind. The letter is addressed to Senator Chipp and says:At Canowindra on 31 May 1986 I received representations suggesting that the draft Fringe Benefits Tax legislation as it applies to rental accommodation--the Prime Minister only ever talked about the rental accommodation aspect of the fringe benefits tax--for farm employees would impact heavily on rural producers. In response to these claims I undertook to secure an assessment of the likely impact of this aspect of the tax.Advice received today confirms that account has been taken in the draft legislation of important concerns of rural producers. The review now underway is considering whether there is any valid basis for further flexibility in the manner in which the proposed tax is to be administered.There is no question of the Government moving to defer adoption of the draft legislation now before the Senate.The letter is signed by the Prime Minister.

name: Senator ROBERTSON
content: —Has the Minister for Finance seen an article in the Melbourne Age of 19 May, headlined `Study predicts fall in workers living standards? In that article the acting Federal Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association was quoted as asserting that Australian workers living standards at the end of 1986 would be lower than they had been under the Fraser Government. Has the Minister examined the study referred to in the Age article? Are its findings on Australian workers living standards accurate?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —I have examined the article and its findings are not accurate. The study paints an excessively gloomy picture of the living standards of Australians during the period since the present Government took office. It also contains a number of conceptual errors. I am surprised that the ACOA, which commissioned the study, has been quoting its results so uncritically, although perhaps one should not be surprised. The professors projections for developments during 1986 assume that the Commonwealth Government will cut real spending by 10 per cent in the areas he defines as being part of the social wage-that is, housing, health, culture, recreation and roads. He has drawn up those definitions, not me. I do not know where he got the idea of a 10 per cent real spending cut from. He takes account of the fact that wage and salary earners will see their next indexation pay rise discounted by two percentage points, but does not take account of the fact that pensioners and other welfare beneficiaries will not have their payments so discounted.When it comes to comparing living standards today with the standards applying under the previous Government, he adopts a very peculiar treatment of Medicare. He takes the levy off disposable household income because it is a tax, but in assessing health costs and, therefore, living costs directly, he uses the consumer price index figure which disregards Medicare. In other words, he uses an inflated CPI figure-the one that would have applied had Medicare not been introduced-but subtracts the Medicare levy from disposable income. I would have thought that that was a very serious conceptual error for an academic to have made. I am surprised that ACOA was satisfied with that and disappointed that the officials of that union, which has many members in senior positions in the Commonwealth bureaucracy who would be completely familiar with these things, did not seek sound advice from their members, instead of unsound advice from some academic scribbler. He also tracks the incomes of households in receipt of average weekly earnings and the incomes of households in receipt of unemployment benefit but ignores the fact that more Australians are in work under the present Government than was the case under the previous Government.Living standards for Australian workers generally will fall during 1986. The fact is that the terms of trade movements over the last 12 months have wiped about 3 per cent from national income. There are only two possible responses to that situation-either living standards on average must fall or the gap must be bridged with increased borrowings from abroad. While I am on this point, it is absolutely unfair that the entire burden should fall on wage earners. Groups in the community other than social welfare beneficiaries ought to be prepared to do their bit as well. I find it quite obscene that there is such trenchant resistance from other more fortunate groups to doing their bit and pulling their weight. In conclusion, the study does paint an excessively gloomy picture. It contains a number of errors. I am disappointed that the ACOA did not look more closely at the figures before going public with them.

name: Senator DURACK
content: —My question is directed to Senator Walsh in his capacity as both Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the claim by the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, that State governments should be compensated by the Commonwealth for the cost of the fringe benefits tax on their Public Services, which Mr Burke estimated in the case of Western Australia will be between $6m and $8m a year. Does the Minister accept the Western Australian Governments contention that the new tax will have particularly damaging effects on remote areas and that Commonwealth estimates of the costs and benefits of the package are seriously in error? Will the Government compensate the States, as requested by Mr Burke?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —I did read the report to which Senator Durack referred. As to the accuracy of the figures, I am in no position at this stage either to confirm or to deny them. But I should express the scepticism that I have generally about people who present figures and who are claiming that they have been done in the eye by the Commonwealth Government. History certainly has verified that scepticism. I would be surprised if that changes in the future. I also note, of course, that Mr Burke did acknowledge that it would be quite wrong to exempt State government employees from the provisions of the fringe benefits tax-as it would be quite wrong, of course to disregard it in the case of Commonwealth employees. In particular, I would be surprised if the claims that Mr Burke is making about the alleged effects on remote areas are correct. As to the question of compensation, the overall financial arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth will be settled in the context of the Premiers Conference, as is normally the case.
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator DURACK
content: —I ask a supplementary question. Does the last part of the answer by Senator Walsh indicate that the Commonwealth Government will seriously entertain such claims for compensation in the course of the usual horse trading that goes on at the Premiers Conference?

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —No, I will not confirm that. The reason is implicit in Senator Duracks last few words; that is, at the Premiers Conference a lot of horse trading goes on. I do not think anybody could say-with any degree of scientific certitude, anyway-what had been traded off, what had been seriously considered and what had not.

name: Senator TATE
content: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and Minister for Defence, concerns the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled `Conscientious objection to conscripted military service which was tabled on 28 May 1985. Is it a fact that the six senators on that Committee unanimously recommended that the scope of conscientious belief which should gain exemption should be enlarged and tested in a less adversarial forum than was the case during the Vietnam War? As more than a year has passed without a Government response, can the Minister inform the Senate why the Government has not managed to assess and respond to the unanimous view of the Committee?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —I am aware, as is the Attorney-General, of the admirable report of the Committee, prepared under Senator Tates chairmanship, which was, as he said, tabled on 28 May last year and was unanimous. That is a precedent which I would commend to other honourable senators in their committee work because it makes life easier for governments. As to the substance of the question, the Attorney-Generals Department has been asked by the Prime Minister to assume the primary carriage of the Governments response to the Committees report. In this regard it should be noted that the Attorney-General does not administer the legislation that was the subject of the report-namely, the Defence Act and the National Service Act. The Attorney-Generals Department has become involved in this issue largely as a result of Senator Tates own initiative, from which I take it-I cannot be sure about this-that he does not now resile. In its task the Attorney-Generals Department will, of course, have to get significant input from other departments, such as the Department of Defence, as provisions of the Defence Act are in issue, and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, as the National Service Act is administered by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.There are also a number of wider issues relating to conscription and conscientious objection that have been signalled in a letter from the Minister for Defence, and I am advised by the Attorney-General that departments have all these matters under discussion. While I am not able at this stage to respond in a manner that I would expect to satisfy Senator Tate, I am informed that there are good prospects that a response will be given after the winter recess.

name: Senator HAINES
content: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is he aware of the enormous number of recipients of German restitution payments who still have not received their full entitlements under the changes made by the Government in November last year? Can the Minister say how many restitution recipients are entitled to have this money excluded from assessment for eligibility for Australian pensions; how many of those people have made application; how many of those who have applied have been processed and are now receiving the higher benefits; and how many have had the full benefit to which they are entitled paid retrospectively from March 1985, as the Government promised? Finally, what explanation can the Government give for the protracted delays in administering this new system?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —As Senator Haines said, we changed the system in 1985 so that German restitution payments were not counted in the means test or the incomes test as a result of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision that was made earlier that year. However, there have been difficulties in verifying the nature of payments received by some clients who do not have documents which specify the nature of the payments they receive from Germany. Most clients potentially affected by the changes have held the necessary documents, are now being paid at the higher rate and have received their arrears back to March 1985. I do not think that that indicates sloppiness or whatever else Senator Haines may call the administration of this legislation.For example, in one Sydney office there are 50 cases and in 40 of these the German restitution payments have been entirely disregarded and the arrears paid. In the remaining cases the clients are receiving restitution in respect of loss of income. In Melbourne three offices are most affected by the changes. I have only approximate figures but I will get the exact figures later. Some 400 cases have been identified in these three offices as perhaps benefiting from the change. Of these, all but 50 have been finalised and in only a handful of cases are the German restitution payments still being taken into account because they represent restitution for loss of income. The difficulties are partly due to confusion amongst some people-not only among pension-receiving people of German origin, I might add-because of the distinction which is being made between the restitution for loss of income and restitution for other reasons, such as loss of property. In addition, there have been some cases where the Department has been approached by people who are receiving normal German social security pensions which, of course, are still treated as income.Steps have been taken to seek assistance from the German authorities in order to overcome the difficulties for those people who are unable to provide the Department of Social Security with relevant documents, and the Department will continue in its efforts to assist those people to obtain the relevant documents, or will even obtain those documents on their behalf. No recipient of German restitution payments has experienced a decrease in income in consequence of the revised treatment. The issue is whether such recipients may be eligible for an increase in the amount paid to them by the Department of Social Security and a consequent increase in their total income. That is the issue which is being pursued by the Department and about which the Department is conducting inquiries with the German Government. That issue is not assisted by silly statements from politicians and others who claim that the Department is no administering the changes properly and is encouraging people in receipt of normal German social security payments which are not affected by the changes that were made to come to the Department of Social Security in the expectation that they will received increased pensions.

name: Senator GIETZELT
content: —I am advised that the Government was anxious to take the steps that it offered holders of the other view, obviously the majority view, and it did so in the belief that the compromises it had worked out had a measure of support in the Australian Capital Territory. In every mainland State the electoral system used involves single-member electorates. However, the Government is prepared to provide for an electoral system under which there are 10 single-member electorates in Canberra and nine members for the whole Territory elected by proportional representation. This amends the Governments initial proposal for 13 single-member electorates. The case for single-member electorates is overwhelming. It is the system recommended by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Electoral Reform, and it is the system that the previous Liberal Government legislated to introduce into the Northern Territory. As I said, it is the system used in every mainland State. The Oppositions attitude, therefore, should be seen in that light.The Opposition does not want to contest the election on equal terms because, obviously, it fears defeat. It is opposed to this system because it cannot predict the result. It will be a test of the popularity of its Party leader, John Howard, which, obviously, is something that honourable members opposite want to avoid in the current political climate. Unfortunately, the people of the Australian Capital Territory are to be denied a democratic voice in their own affairs. The Opposition parties have not been prepared to meet the Government on its compromise proposals. Unless the Opposition parties indicate that they are prepared to support the Governments amendments, the Minister advises me that there is no point in wasting the time of the Senate in debating the Australian Capital Territory Council Bills. It is the Opposition senators who will leave the Australian Capital Territory as the only significant Western community without a form of local administration answerable directly to the people.

name: Senator BLACK
content: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen a report in the Brisbane Daily Sun in which a visiting Canadian medical practitioner alleges that the Governments drug offensive campaign contains false and alarmist material about the use of tranquillisers? Is the Minister aware that this doctors trip to Australia was sponsored by the tranquilliser manufacturer, Wyeth International? Will the Minister advise the Senate of the accuracy or otherwise of the allegations?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —Yes, I noticed the article in the Daily Sun. Senator Black drew my attention to it. I noticed also in the article that Dr John Saunders from the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital drug and alcohol unit described Professor Rosser, the doctor concerned, as a museum piece if he believed that the tranquillisers that he talked about were not addictive. The pamphlet on tranquillisers of the national campaign against drug abuse does not say that there has been an alarming increase in the use of tranquillisers. In fact, it points out that tranquillisers, because of their greater safety, are increasingly being prescribed in place of barbiturates, which is a very desirable development. The national campaign against drug abuse has adopted a balanced approach to all drugs. The material-certainly the material that I have read-is not alarmist, nor does it make value judgments; it makes what I believe are sensitive statements as to indicated usage and the risks involved.All jurisdictions in Australia have sought actions on these and on other drugs. In the case of the tranquillisers it is difficult to obtain accurate figures on the number prescribed. Neither I nor the Minister for Health has any accurate information at the moment on why Dr Rosser is in the country at all or who sponsored his visit. I must say, though, that if it has been sponsored by one of the pharmaceutical companies, particularly by Wyeth, it is reasonable for one to speculate as to the accuracy of his comments and his motives for making them.What we have tried to do in this Parliament, in the Senate, and more recently in this Government is to have a rational and sensible debate on the drug problem in this country. It is not achieved by people on either side making alarmist and stupid statements. I do not believe that the documents that have been put out by the Government and by all the State governments contain alarmist material, nor do I think the situation is advanced by statements of the like made by Professor Rosser who, like many visiting professors, apparently thinks that, because he is not in his own country and not amongst his own peers, he can make statements which will not be questioned and which do not need to be backed by facts. I would not hesitate to suggest that, back in Canada, he would not make such statements. If he does, his tenure of office as a professor will not be a very long one.

name: Senator FOREMAN
content: —Did the Minister for Finance see a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 May 1986 entitled `What They Did in Canberra? In that article the latest workings of the Oppositions Waste Watch Committee, under the leadership of Senator Michael Baume, were reported on. Can the Minister state whether it is true that this Government has given grants totalling $20,000 to public servants in the Department of Social Security to stage an in-service play on the highs and lows of departmental life?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —The short answer is no; it is not true. Like so many of the scandals the Waste Watch Committee purports to unearth, it is wrong again. I have seen the report in the Sydney Morning Herald and it refers not only to Senator Michael Baumes fearless leadership of the Waste Watch Committee stunt but also to some of his former careers in less than flattering terms.The article notes that the senators Waste Watch Committee tends to be particularly active on Sundays when things are generally a bit quiet and it can get a run in the papers on Monday. Actually I think the real reason the honourable senator wants to get a run is to further his own ambitions to find a place on the Opposition front bench. Indeed, it is more specific than that; he wants to supplant Senator Messner as shadow Minister for Finance. The Waste Watch Committee is the vehicle that he hopes will carry him onto the front bench. He hopes to eclipse Senator Messners less than dazzling performance with the publicity that his Waste Watch Committee stunts generate.It is not my place to give advice to the beleaguered Leader of the Opposition on sensitive matters such as saving his own skin. I reckon he has already got enough lead in his saddle bags without adding Senator Michael Baume to it. In his haste to obtain some personal publicity, Senator Michael Baume did not check back quite far enough on his facts, an error he has made before; indeed, an error he consistently makes. Grants totalling $20,000, the original source of which is the Federal Government, have been given to public servants in the Department of Social Security so that they can stage the in-house play In-Security, which apparently does explore the highs and lows of life in that Department. The funds were allocated through an Australia Council program called Art and Working Life. Rather than simply criticising and trivialising the destination of those funds, if Senator Michael Baume wants to criticise the policy of holding the Australia Council at arms length from government and giving it funds that the Australia Council distributes, he should do so. But that is not the real point that I want to make. The real point is that that particular program was established by the Australia Council in September 1982 and the most innumerate member of the Opposition should know that we were not in government at that time, but the Fraser Government, in which Senator Michael Baume was allegedly an influential back bencher was in office.

content: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. name: Senator COLSTON
content: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to the ANZ Bank employment advertisement series which shows that in Queensland in February, the latest month for which figures are available, the number of job advertisements in the Courier-Mail, Brisbane, fell by 0.6 per cent? Is this contrast with the Australian average increase of 5.9 per cent further evidence of the poor state of the Queensland economy under the Bjelke-Petersen Government?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALSH
content: —I am aware of those figures which show the result or the outcome for the month of February which Senator Colston has mentioned. That is not an aberrant figure; indeed, it confirms a trend which has been very clear for many months, that is, that the advertised job vacancies in Queensland are consistently on a trend line below those of the nation as a whole, which is of course yet another example of the constant stream of economic indicators coming out of Queensland demonstrating the rapid deterioration of that States economy under a government in its declining years.The actual decline of 0.6 per cent in the job advertisement figures against a national average of a 5.9 per cent increase is another fairly dramatic indictment of Queenslands economic performance. I guess the Premiers attitude to that would be the same as his attitude to the comments of his prominent National Party colleague, Sir Roderick Proctor. However, clearly, with annual net migration in the last year in excess of 5,000 in the prime working age group of 20 to 34 years-the key job seeker age group-there are many people who are worried about the lack of job prospects in Queensland.The refrain of the Queensland Government used to be that Queensland has a high unemployment rate because it is such a lovely place to live, that people are drifting up from the south to lie around or to work in the sun. More frequently, according to the Queensland Government, dole bludgers from the south were coming up to lie in the Queensland sun. That argument was never credible. It is now demonstrably statistically disprovable.In fact, people in that prime working age group have been leaving Queensland in the last 12 months. There has been a net outward migration of 5,000 people. Those people are voting with their feet. They are leaving Queensland because they know that they have much worse prospects of getting a job in that State than they have in the Labor governed States to the south.Queensland has been the lucky State in a sense for many years. It has attracted easy investment because of its resource endowments. That period has now come to an end. When the Queensland Government is being required by economic circumstances to stand on its own feet and to compare itself from the same base with other States in its economic performance, employment growth and so on, it is found to be severely wanting. I guess that one of the symptoms of any regime that is coming to the end of its period is a sustained and severe decline in its economic performance.

content: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and concerns the continuing destruction of Australian forests by woodchipping. Lamb for the Secretary to the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment in a letter of 13 November 1985 to the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry that Hollow Tree Enterprises Pty Ltd should be designated as proponent in terms of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and subject to an environmental impact statement?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator RYAN
content: —Negotiations for a memorandum of understanding with Tasmania concerning the future of export woodchipping operations in Tasmania are being conducted by the Minister for Primary Industry. The following information has been provided by him in answer to Senator Sanderss questions. The issues raised in questions 1 to 3 of Senator Sanderss question fall within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industry. I expect that, when arrangements are finalised, the Minister will make details available so that the public can appreciate the mechanisms for protecting Tasmanian forests, particularly the National Estate areas. Senator Sanders will then be in a position to assess the answers to these questions.In relation to the Hollow Tree Enterprises project in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, Senator Sanderss question appears to be based on the incorrect premise that if a proponent is designated for the purposes of the administrative procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, the project will automatically be the subject of an environmental impact statement. As is made clear in the memorandum from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment to the Department of Primary Industry, referred to by Senator Sanders, the purpose of suggesting that a proponent be designated was to provide a basis for a decision on the need or otherwise for an environmental impact statement.In fact, the memorandum states that the initial view of the Department is that an environmental impact statement would probably not be necessary, provided certain conditions could be applied to the project. These conditions related to restrictions of exports, waste materials and the application of environmental protection guidelines to the agricultural clearing and management of the companys property at St George in Queensland. The approval of the Minister for Primary Industry for exports covers only sawmill wastes, timber from clearing on the property, which would be subject to compliance with the appropriate environment protection guidelines, and thinnings from New South Wales Government hardwood plantations established for wood production. The honourable senator will appreciate that the decision as to whether a particular proposal is environmentally significant and whether a proponent should be designated is one for the action Minister; in this case the Minister for Primary Industry.

name: Senator GILES
content: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans Affairs. The increasing average age of veterans and war widows over the next few years will inevitably mean that the provision of institutional and non-institutional care will require significantly increased allocation of funds. What measures are being taken by the Department of Veterans Affairs regarding the escalating costs of domiciliary care provided by private nursing organisations to veterans and war widows?
debateinfo: N/A
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GIETZELT
content: —The question of providing adequate care for veterans is a matter that has been before the Government since it came to office in 1983. The basic strategy, of course, is to keep people out of institutions. The reason for that, of course, is to meet the general aspirations and needs of veterans, as well as to apply cost effectiveness principles to the way in which those objectives are met. Domiciliary nursing costs have risen from $3.8m in 1979 to $17m in 1985-86. As a consequence, the Repatriation Commission has recently reviewed the procedures, with particular reference to New South Wales and Victoria, because there has been some blowout in expenditure and some laxity in the way in which the principles of domiciliary nursing have been applied. The Government is committing itself to providing services to veterans so that they can maintain themselves in their own homes. That is the basic principle involved in the way in which the system operates. Domiciliary nursing costs will increase, but institutional costs will increase faster. So we have a common objective in these areas.I have directed my Department to ensure that the interests of the taxpayers, as well as the interests of the veterans and war widows, are protected so that they are not exploited by profit motivated private nursing organisations. That has taken place in some cases in some States. As a result of the the recent review, from 1 September 1986 the maximum amount of domiciliary nursing which may be prescribed by a local medical officer without prior approval is one hour per day for a maximum of three months. Any nursing in excess of that will require prior approval. In New South Wales and Victoria the Department will exercise greater control over delivery of the service by assessing requests requiring prior approval, so that other than in exceptional circumstances the maximum payment for domiciliary nursing will be restricted to four hours per day. In order to meet that objective local medical officers will be reminded of the long-standing policy of my Department that where a government subsidised domiciliary nursing organisation exists, it should be used in preference to private or agency nurses, as we have less control over the way in which the money is expended if they are used.

I have noted the calls from the business community to which Senator McIntosh referred-in particular, one which was published in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday and in the Adelaide Advertiser on the same day. I note that the business group is calling, among other things, for cuts in the funding to State and local government and has a quite extensive list of other specific program areas in which it is calling for cuts. I do not agree with all of the calls that it is making, but I will at least give the business community credit for having more courage and sense of responsibility than has the Opposition, which does two things. It says that expenditure should be cut, but never nominates an area in which that ought to take place. The second thing it does is that it promises $1 1/2 billion worth of additional expenditure in a variety of areas. Last week it promised another $500m-plus to the agricultural sector. So the Opposition, which is forever tediously saying that expenditure must be cut, does not nominate any specific area in which it should be cut. It irresponsibly promises $2 billion in additional expenditure, attempting to buy up the number of noisy pressure groups that it thinks will help to return it to government. Of course it has absolutely no intention of delivering those expenditure promises, should it get back into government.Senator Chaney informed us last week that the rural policy document, which was leaked, has no status; it is only a discussion paper. It lists about eight specific areas which contain promises for an extra $500m in outlays on the agricultural sector. Given that Senator Chaney has informed us of this, I have asked whether the Opposition is not committed to any of those individual promises in its discussion paper. I have asked which of those individual items the Opposition will welsh on or repudiate. Will it repudiate the commitment to refund all fuel excise to farmers, including the excise on petrol that they use to drive to the city and back? Will it welsh on the promise to fully restore the fuel freight equalisation subsidy, which would cost $110m? Will the Opposition repeal the sales tax on wine, which would cost the revenue $60m or the excise on brandy which would cost another $38m? Will it welsh on its promise to abolish charges for export inspection services which would cost about another $50m? I am still waiting for a reply from Senator Chaney, Mr Howard, Mr Sinclair or Mr Hunt on whether the Opposition will welsh on all those commitments and, if not, which ones will it welsh on and which will it stick by.

name: Senator WALSH
content: —I have seen the letter which gives a very different view of the magnitude of fringe benefits received by farm employees to that which is presented by members of the National Party of Australia and the President of the National Farmers Federation. From what I have heard from shearers who used to work on the pastoral properties owned by the President of the National Farmers Federation, there were certainly no fringe benefits for the shearers in those places. Indeed his pater used to be known as `Hungry McLachlan. The average rural worker has been portrayed by Mr McLachlan, the NFF, the National Party and the Opposition generally as receiving in addition to wages, petrol, meat and so on-in other words, substantial income in kind. The retired rural worker who wrote the letter to which Senator Maguire referred suggested that if that was actually so he might be prepared to come out of retirement. He said that the only people that he knew of receiving those tangible additions to their wages were `blokes who come from agricultural colleges with a degree that says they know all about farming and get put in as managers or some such. I will quote a little more from the letter in question. It says:During my time working as a rural worker on three different stations, never did I ever receive free meat, petrol or firewood: meat I had from-it says `employees, but that is clearly a typographical error-employer was paid for, free petrol is laughable, firewood I carted for myself in my own time, the `number of other benefits I think are a figment of Mr McLachlans imagination.I believe that later in the Committee stage of the debate on the fringe benefits legislation Senator Grimes will be detailing a response to-which, of course, means `a massive correction of-the assertions which are being made by the National Farmers Federation.

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —I am now in a position to supply some more information on the film Hail Mary. I think, in deference to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, that I should give a supplementary answer to her question today. The film, prior to its registration, was examined by the Film Censorship Board on two occasions. The Board is an independent statutory body, qualified to make judgments on community standards. The Film Censorship Boards unanimous decision-it was the whole board of 11 members who saw and voted upon the film-is that the film is neither indecent nor blasphemous but rather seeks to give the biblical story of the Virgin Mary a contemporary setting.Although the central theme in the film concerns the emotional, moral and philosophical questions posed by the rather unusual dilemma in which the central characters find themselves-namely, a virgin pregnancy-the Mary of the films title is not the Bibles Mary and is clearly meant to be a contemporary character beset by late twentieth century social and moral conflicts. The director, Jean-Luc Godard, has described the film as devout. Against the protest that has been received from the church, one should mention that, as was spelt out in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 May, La Croix, a French catholic newspaper, has called it Godards `great Christian film, and a Catholic jury at the Berlin Film Festival last year gave it an award.Finally, now that the film has been registered and released from the control of Customs, the Attorney-General has no available powers, either constitutionally or under regulation 40 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, in regard to this film. The Attorney advises me that he is confident that the Film Censorship Board, as an independent statutory authority, has approached its duties in a responsible manner.

name: Senator GIETZELT
content: —Earlier in Question Time Senator Collard asked me a question relating to suggested improvements to the international terminal facility at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The Minister for Aviation has provided me with the following information: The Kingsford-Smith Airport international terminal has from time to time been the subject of adverse media coverage and gives rise to many personal complaints. For some years, the terminals deficiencies have been recognised by the Department and by the airlines. It is proposed that the terminal be remodelled and expanded in a number of areas to increase its capacity from 1,000 to 1,800 passengers per hour to cater more adequately for international passenger traffic at acceptable levels of service. The proposed works, which will concentrate on improving the passenger and baggage processing systems and public and passenger amenities, have been estimated to cost $20m.However, a Public Works Committee hearing dealt with these matters and that proposal was under its consideration on 4 February this year. The Committee reported to the Minister on 7 May and concluded that it was not expedient for the proposed work to proceed. It believed that the proposed work would not alleviate the congestion to any significant extent. It did not believe that the proposed work would be the most effective use of the money to be expended. The Committee recommended planning for the provision of a new international terminal building and stated that that should commence immediately. It recommended that the Commonwealth authorities provide staff to process passengers at a maximum attainable level. It also recommended that the curfew be reduced by one hour in the morning. That report from the Public Works Committee is currently being considered by the Minister and by the Government. No other information is available to me to respond any further to the question that was raised today by Senator Collard.
