name: Senator MICHAEL BAUME
content: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, and I wish to make a personal explanation. At Question Time, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, claimed that as Chairman of the coalition Waste Watch Committee, I had wrongly alleged that the Government had given $20,000 to employees of the Department of Social Security for an in-house play. Senator Walsh said that the $20,000 was in fact given by the Australia Council. Senator Walshs claim is totally incorrect. It is yet another example of his intellectual sloth. I have a copy of my Press release on this matter, dated 25 May, which clearly shows that I made no such claim. I seek leave to have this Press release incorporated in Hansard to establish the facts.Leave granted.The document read as follows-GOVERNMENT DIVERTS FURTHER ARTS GRANTS TO UNIONSGrants of $20,000 to public servants in the Department of Social Security to put on an ``in-house play with a ``quite strong political message are among this week-ends examples of increasing volumes of Government arts money being diverted to the trade union movement, Chairman of the Opposition Waste Watch Committee, Senator Michael Baume said today.Senator Baume said under the Hawke government almost $1.5 million that would previously have gone to traditional arts areas has been diverted to trade unions and associated organisations.In addition, hundreds of thousands of dollars have gone to radical and ``front groups who use the arts to spread propaganda.At the week-end, the Australia Councils Theatre Board announced its final allocation of 87 grants for 1985-86, amounting to $800,000 and bringing its total grants for the year to $12.43 million.In line with Government policy, an increasing proportion of grants from the Australia Council for arts purposes has been diverted away from traditional recipients into programmes such as ``artists in community and ``art and working life, in which the union movement is heavily involved.The $20,000 in the latest grants to public servants is to write and produce a play called ``In-Security which is described as exploring the ``highs and lows of life in the Department of Social Security, depicting the work experiences of a demoralised staff.The play is being written as the group goes along from a working outline but a major theme developing so far is that the public is being ``short changed by the system.In a scene from this still incomplete play, ``bucketfuls of cheques are poured out for a poor pensioner, an ironic reflection of the bucketsful of money the play is receiving from the Federal Government.``Cut waste to cut taxesThe first Australia Council grant towards this play was $10,000 from the Community Arts Board in November last year through the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, (the relevant union), followed by $1,000 from the Literature Board, and then this week-ends $8,416 from the Theatre Board.Organisers hope for another $8,000 grant when the show is hopefully ready for performance in July in Social Security offices around Sydney.Funding of this self-indulgence is bad enough, but depriving other genuine arts organisations of funds for this kind of wank is intolerable.If the Government believes it needs to improve morale among its employees in this fashion, it should not rob the artistic till to do so.Funding granted this year under the Governments guidelines by the Australia Council include:Workers Cultural Action Committee (NSW) $28,500 lifting its grants under the Hawke Government to $88,678.Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia $33,000 lifting its grants to $153,477.United Trades and Labour Council of South Australia $54,000 lifting its total to $263,000.Victorian Trades Hall Council $58,500 increasing its total to $133,200.Trade Union Labour Day Celebration Committee (Victoria) $15,000 lifting its grants to $45,000.ACTU $11,350 increasing its total to $83,850.Other unions receiving arts grants this year include the Combined Unions Shop Committee NSW, the FEDFA, Ships Painters and Dockers, Storemen and Packers, Municipal Officers Association, Musicians Union, Painters & Decorators Union, Professional Officers Association, ABC Staff Employees Association, and the Trade Union Community Research Centre (Tasmania).Radical and ``front organisations also receive arts grants such as the Australia Nuclear Free Zones Secretariat, FILEF (an affiliate of the Italian Communist Party which is a major recipient of Federal Government grants), the Australian Anarchist Centennial and numerous theatre and visual arts organisations whose objectives are political and which use the arts as a propaganda medium.If these Australia Council arts grants simply meant providing increasing opportunities for the arts to be available in the workplace or to working people who would not otherwise have access to them, then they would be justifiable, even in todays economic crisis.But these grants are mainly going to finance the spread of political propaganda under the guise of arts funding.At a time when a recent study showed the trade union movement having huge assets and enormous income, it is ridiculous for the Government to finance the spread of union propaganda through politically motivated songs, plays, banners, posters and newspapers produced at public expense under the guise of promoting the arts.If the union movement along with other political and radical groups wish to use the arts as a way of spreading their message then they are quite entitled to do so provided they pay for it themselves and not ask the Australian taxpayer to foot the bill.By making unions and radical groups into patrons of the arts at public expense, the Government is reinforcing the view that the easiest way for a writer, performer or artist to get money these days is to have a leftist or radical message, Senator Michael Baume said.25 May 1986For further information, phone Senator Baume 02/817-5625

name: Senator GARETH EVANS
content: —As Minister representing the Minister for Defence I table the Review of Australias Defence Capabilities by Mr Paul Dibb. I seek leave to make a statement relating thereto and to incorporate that statement in Hansard.Leave granted.The statement read as follows-I am very pleased to table today the review of Australias Defence Capabilities by Mr Paul Dibb. Mr Dibb has worked directly for me as a ministerial consultant; His review is not a statement of Government policy, but an independent analysis of major defence policy issues facing the Commonwealth at this time.The Dibb review will now become a basic input to the development of a Government White paper on Defence policy, which will lay down our plans for the Defence Force over the next decade and beyond.In preparing his report Mr Dibb has consulted closely with the Australian Defence Force and the Department of Defence. The CDF, General Sir Phillip Bennett, and the secretary to my Department, Sir William Cole, have responded favourably to Mr Dibbs conclusions on Australias strategic environment, and to his proposal for a National Defence Strategy for Australia. And they broadly agree with his specific recommendations on force structure, though with some differences on details such as numbers and timing.Overall they consider that Mr Dibb has done an excellent job-and I heartily agree.The Dibb review is an intellectually complex and rigorous analysis of the defence needs of this nation in the light of our strategic circumstances. This kind of analysis has rarely featured in the defence debate in this country, because public discussion of defence here has almost always been concerned solely with the broad foreign-policy environment of defence decision-making.One fundamental conclusion is that the contribution of all three services is seen as essential to our defence effort. There is a strong emphasis on maritime and ground force capabilities in credible contingencies. There is a proper regard given to the enhancement of our capacity to deploy air power across the vast distances of our continent and its approaches. And the potential for reserve forces to make a major contribution to our defence effort is clearly established.Defence FundamentalsN/AWhen Mr Dibb was commissioned to review Australias defence capabilities, he took as his starting point the strategic assessment endorsed by the defence committee. He then examined the three essential elements of our defence planning environment. These essential elements are not new-they reflect long-term historical trends and underpin basically bipartisan attitudes to our defence requirements.The first of them is that Australia should aim for defence self-reliance-the ability to defend ourselves from within our own resources from direct threats to our sovereignty and interests.Secondly, sound defence planning should be based on realistic Budget parameters. Australias experience has been that peacetime defence expenditure has never consistently exceeded 3% of GDP. Indeed for most of Australias peacetime history, defence expenditure has been well below this.Thirdly, we recognise that low-level military threats to Australia could emerge relatively quickly, but it would take many years for any country other than a superpower to equip itself to attempt a major military assault on Australia.On these foundations Mr Dibb has produced a rigorous and disciplined analysis of our force structure requirements.Self-RelianceN/AAustralians have a right to expect that their nation is able to defend itself. That is at the core of nationhood, and it has long been an Australian aspiration.Just fifty years ago this year, John Curtin told this House:The people of Australia would expect this country to be capable of defending itself should the occasion arise.And he went on to say:A greater degree of self-reliance in Australias defence is essential.In that speech in 1936 Curtin predicted the events between December 1941 and March 1942. He foretold that Britain, fighting for its life in Europe, would be unable to send its navy to defend Australia from the Japanese, and that without that fleet the inevitable fall of Singapore would lay Australia open to peril.He concluded:The dependence of Australia on the competence, let alone the readiness, of British statesmen to send forces to our aid is too dangerous a hazard on which to found Australias defence policy.In 1936 Curtins policy was hotly debated and rejected-to Australias great cost. But today self-reliance is beyond debate.A self-reliant Australia is an expectation both of the Australian people and of our allies. It has been required by our principal ally, the United States since the early 1970s.This requirement has been reiterated by successive United States Administrations. In a major policy statement in November 1984, Secretary of Defence Caspar Weinberger said:We have learned that there are limits to how much of our spirit and blood and treasure we can afford to forfeit in meeting our responsibility to keep peace and freedom. So while we may and should offer substantial amounts of economic and military assistance to our allies in their time of need, and help them maintain forces to deter attacks against them we cannot substitute our troops or our will for theirs.The previous Government recognised the relationship between self-reliance and a sound contribution to alliance relationships when it said in its 1976 white paper:This self-reliant posture derives essentially from our own national interests and responsibilities. It also accords with our status as an ally of the U.S., for by accepting our local responsibilities we can contribute to the alliance relationship and to the U.S. global effort.The ability to defend itself is the absolute minimum that any self-respecting country should contribute to an alliance. Australia can scarcely pretend to contribute to the defence of broader western interests if it cannot even defend itself. Indeed, as U.S. Secretary of Defence Weinberger said at the National Press Club in April:Defence of a countrys own borders and own airspace and the sea around it, obviously, is a prime attribute of sovereignty and, of course, has to be one of the first priorities of any country.So a policy of self-reliance contributes to the strength of the alliance. And Australia makes a further substantial contribution to western security, as well as to international stability, by hosting the joint defence facilities and through a range of other cooperative activities, such as regular visits by ships of the U.S. Navy.Equally, the alliance with the United States contributes to Australias ability to defend itself. Mr Dibb concludes that a self-reliant defence of a continent the size of ours demands access to intelligence, high-technology sensors and military equipment. For much of this the United States is the best source by far, and for some it is the only source. This is an important conclusion, and one which should not be overlooked in our thinking about the defence relationship with the United States.Our U.S. alliance will remain a significant deterrent to any potential aggressor. Any nation contemplating the use of force against us would have to reckon with the help-including possibly the direct military assistance which the U.S. might provide to Australia. That possibility would inevitably be a major complication in the plans of any would-be attacker, and thus it serves as a powerful deterrent.Our relationship with New Zealand is also of particular importance because of our common history and traditions, our proximity and our shared strategic concerns. Under ANZUS we have cooperated effectively with both the U.S. and New Zealand for many years to preserve our strategic environment. This cooperation continues with both parties, despite the difficulties in the US-NZ bilateral relationship. Nonetheless we look forward to the resumption of full trilateral cooperation under ANZUS when this becomes possible.We continue to value our excellent relations with all countries in our region and particularly with the members of ASEAN and of the South Pacific forum. Our good relations with our neighbours is a major enhancement of our security, and we value the contribution which good defence relations can make to the development of a broader understanding and harmony between ourselves and our neighbours, particularly under such programs as the defence cooperation program and the five power defence arrangements. Mr Dibb points out that such defence relations offer political benefits which exceed their direct military value.I believe there is no fundamental difference between this government and the opposition parties over the doctrine of self-reliance, and what this means for our alliances. The coalition governments white paper in 1976 was based explicitly on a self-reliant defence posture.In a key paragraph, that white paper said:A primary requirement emerging from our findings is for increased self-reliance. In our contemporary circumstances we can no longer base our policy on the expectation that Australias Navy or Army or Airforce will be sent abroad to fight as part of some other Nations force . . . We believe that any operations are much more likely to be in our own neighbourhood than in some distant or forward theatre.But despite this broad agreement on these basic issues, a clear conception of Australias real defence needs in an era of self-reliance did not emerge from the coalitions seven years of government.There were a number of reasons for that. One was the coalitions failure to establish a reliable financial basis for defence planning.Australia spends about 3% of GDP on defence. We spend more on defence than on any other Commonwealth responsibility except social welfare and health.This year the defence bill is over $6.5 billion-almost 10% of total Commonwealth outlays. This is a huge investment of Australias national wealth, and of the wealth of individual Australians. Defence costs every man, woman and child in Australia over $400 per year.Because such vast sums of money are involved, it is impossible to plan responsibly for defence without realistic financial guidance. Such guidance must respect the economic and political limits to the levels of defence spending which can be sustained in peacetime.The last coalition government twice proposed major expansions in defence spending, in 1976 and 1980. In both cases, the proposed high levels of expenditure on which defence planning was based simply could not be sustained. And on both occasions defence spending fell back to below previous levels within a year. The effect on defence budgeting of this glut-and-famine approach to spending levels has been very damaging.An effective and efficient defence force cannot be developed by making grandiose commitments when international crises make defence spending popular, and then slashing spending the next year as defence concerns recede. Yet that was what the coalition did.More fundamentally, the coalition government simply failed to put into practice the philosophy espoused in its 1976 white paper, because they would not tackle the hard issues involved in developing a self-reliant force structure.Comprehensive force structure planning was neglected and all too often procurement decisions reflected political and financial expediency. The protracted wrangle over replacing the aircraft carrier perfectly reflected their indecisiveness and lack of vision.In such an atmosphere it is not surprising that competing force structure philosophies flourished within the defence community. When this government came into office it sought detailed advice on our future force structure. But we found that there was no agreement, even on the scale of war we should be preparing to fight.Defence PlanningN/AThe difficulties which the defence establishment has faced in resolving these issues is indicative of broader problems which Mr Dibb found in Australias defence planning.One specific problem identified by the review is that each of the three services continues to do much of their initial force structure planning in isolation. This can lead to narrow and competitive views of Australias defence needs.I am pleased to announce that the government has decided to tackle this problem by appointing a vice chief of the defence force directly responsible to the chief of the defence force for co-ordinating military planning.This officer will be equal in rank to the chiefs of the individual services, and his appointment will mean that increasingly, planning by the separate services will be fully coordinated.As well, the Secretary to my department and the chief of the defence force are examining other ways to streamline force-structure planning.I am also pleased to report that Mr Dibbs work has done much to reconcile different views within the defence community on some of the fundamental issues in our defence planning. In particular, the chief of the defence force and the secretary to my department have advised me that they accept and support Mr Dibbs conclusions on the level of contingency which should have priority in our defence planning.Threats and WarningN/AMr Dibb has endorsed the judgement that major threat to Australias security-other than in the context of global war-would take some ten years to develop.This judgement has been endorsed by successive defence committees and has been accepted by successive governments from both sides of this house for over a decade.It is based on an expert technical assessment that no country, other than the superpowers, has the capability now to mount a major attack in the face of Australias existing defence forces, and that it would take at least ten years for such a capability to be developed.But the capabilities to mount low-level attacks of various sorts against Australia already exist or are in prospect. Such attacks could be mounted with quite modest forces of a sort and level maintained by most countries for their own legitimate purposes.Such low-level attacks would not threaten Australias national survival, but they would nonetheless be serious emergencies.Mr Dibb has found that this range of low-level military contingencies would pose more acute defence problems than is generally believed. A campaign of maritime harassment, and raids in remote areas, could severely test our present defence capacity. He recommends that these lower level contingencies should receive more attention in defence planning than in the past.This is not a prediction of military threat. I want to emphasise that Australia enjoys good relations with all its neighbours, and no country is likely to develop hostile intentions towards us. Before any country could develop an intention to attack us, relations would have to deteriorate dramatically and fundamentally. But because circumstances and intentions can change relatively quickly, our forces need to be prepared to cope with credible levels of conflict. These can be set by considering the limits of regional military capabilities.An important corollary of these judgements is that we would receive considerable warning of any effort to increase military forces to the point where they would have the capability to mount a major attack against Australia. Australia would have time to expand and develop its forces to meet higher threats as they developed.The challenge posed by the concept of warning time is to develop a defence force which could meet low level threats arising with little warning, and yet could also be expanded fast enough to meet a higher level threat should a potential adversary begin to develop the necessary capabilities.This challenge has not been adequately met in the past. The concept of a `core force has been developed on the basis of warning time, and Mr Dibb notes that it provides a useful set of basic principles on which to define the capabilities required for high-level conflicts. But he sees, in addition, the need for a strategic concept focused on dealing with lower levels of conflict within our neighbourhood.Defence Strategy for AustraliaN/AForce planning needs a clear overall conception of how Australias defence forces would meet a threat, before it can be decided in detail what sort of forces are needed.In articulating that strategic concept Mr Dibb has made a most important contribution to improving our defence planning.To bridge the gap between strategic guidance and specific force structure proposals, Mr Dibb has developed a defence strategy for Australia, which he has called a `strategy of denial.I want to make it perfectly clear that this has nothing to do with ``fortress Australia, as some have suggested before they have seen anything of the reviews contents.Mr Dibbs defence strategy embraces three key features. The first is a focus on the specific geographical features of Australia and its surroundings.The second is a concept of layered defence, which takes advantage of our geography. Thirdly there is a need for a clear understanding of the levels of threat we may face. The chief of the defence force and the secretary to my department endorse these basic principles.Strategic GeographyN/AMr Dibb argues that our unique geographical environment should play a central role in Australian Defence planning.He argues that the vast maritime areas which surround Australia-known to strategists as the sea-air gap-and the remoteness and harshness of our northern areas, critically determine the military options of both attack and defence.Australias huge distances contribute to its security, particularly from major attacks, because only the superpowers could project and sustain large-scale military force onto its shores.But in lower levels of conflict, the effects of distance work less in Australias favour. Although the sea-air gap remains a formidable barrier to forces of any size, our vast northern areas mean that a major Australian defence effort could be needed to find and repel small attacking forces.Mr Dibb concludes that our defence forces need to be structured specifically to exploit the strengths and to guard the weaknesses inherent in our strategic geography. To provide this geographic focus for our defence planning, Mr Dibb has indicated an area of Australias direct military interest. The characteristics of this area should be the over-riding determinants of the capabilities required in the ADF.Broadly speaking, this area of direct military interest covers the whole of Australias land mass, and extends some 1,000 nautical miles beyond it in all directions. That area is around 10% of the earths surface and it covers distances equal to those from Sweden to Afghanistan or from Finland to the Suez Canal.Australias area of direct military interest is not, of course, the limit of our strategic concerns. Mr Dibb identifies a broader area which he calls our ``Sphere of Primary Strategic Interest, extending throughout South East Asia, the eastern Indian Ocean and the South Pacific.We have important strategic relationships in this region which we should develop and strengthen. The area involved takes in almost a quarter of the surface of the globe. I defy anyone to describe this as an isolationist approach for a country with a population of only 16 million.The definition of Australias area of direct military interest does not preclude the possibility of Australian forces being sent further afield, in either fighting or peacekeeping roles.What Mr Dibb proposes is that priority should be given to developing those capabilities which best enhance Australias capacity to deny an enemy substantial military success against us within our area of direct military interest.That is the Australian Defence Forces prime national task, and that should determine its organisation and equipment. But forces designed to do that job will be capable of making a contribution further afield as well, should the need arise.Layered DefenceN/AMr Dibb proposes that our strategic geography can best be exploited by a system of `Layered Defence within our area of direct military interest.The first layer-and Australias most important defence planning concern-is to prevent any hostile force crossing the sea and air gap. For this we need good intelligence and surveillance as well as air and sea forces capable of interdiction.Closer in-the second layer-a range of capabilities is needed to defend our offshore resources and the coasts themselves, including air-defence, mine countermeasures and appropriate naval ships.Lastly-in the third layer-we need highly mobile land forces capable of operating across the north to protect population, military installations, infrastructure, and industry.It is important to point out that under the strategy which Mr Dibb has proposed, each of our three services has a vital role to play at all levels of contingency.Force StructureN/AI turn now to Mr Dibbs specific proposals about the force structure which his strategy requires. I will not attempt here to go through all his recommendations, but I want to identify some major issues and, where appropriate, to indicate the Governments intentions.The issues here focus on the classic question of ``how much is enough. At a time when Australia is at peace, and expects to remain so, these are not easy matters to resolve. Defence has to fit into national budget strategies like everything else. Defence planning has to be very rigorous, and our defence dollar needs to be spent wisely.Let me emphasise first that Australia already has substantial military forces. Our intelligence and surveillance systems are the most advanced in the region. Our strike and interdiction capabilities include some of the most potent equipment available anywhere in the region. And we have well-trained maritime and land forces that are being progressively re-equipped with modern weapons and support systems.The high priority for intelligence and surveillance capabilities recommended by Mr Dibb accords with the Governments thinking, and is reflected in current programs. Mr Dibb gives special attention to the over-the-horizon radar project which offers the very real possibility of allowing continuous monitoring of the great expanses of our sea and air approaches. We are looking at ways in which this program can be accelerated and expanded.The review notes that the further development of over-the-horizon radar may have implications for other systems such as airborne early warning. I am on record as favouring the acquisition of airborne early warning aircraft. Mr Dibbs advice is that an early decision on acquisition is not required. Instead studies should go ahead in parallel with the further development of over-the-horizon radar. Those studies are proceeding and the capability will be considered by the government as the white paper is prepared.The introduction of the highly capable F/A-18 marks a major improvement in our air defence capacity. I accept Mr Dibbs advice on our need for aerial refuelling, particularly to provide the F/A-18 with an improved capacity to provide air cover for surface ships. Planning for aerial refuelling is continuing on this basis.The review gives careful attention to our strike forces. Our 23 F-111 aircraft and six submarines are unmatched in regional terms, and we have formidable strike potential in other forces such as the orion and F/A-18 aircraft. The review concludes that the F-111 force should be retained until the mid-1990s when decisions about its long-term future will be required.The review endorses the new submarine program, which will introduce new highly capable submarines into the force structure in the 1990s.The potential of mine warfare against Australia is given particular attention in the review. Mr Dibb observes that we have a major force structure deficiency in the much-deteriorated state of our mine countermeasures force. Although some progress is being made, this is an area where we have unacceptable vulnerabilities. I am determined to remedy this as quickly as possible.I observe here that this experience illustrates the need for setting clear force structure priorities. Arguments can be found to acquire many capabilities. Some would argue for another fleet underway replenishment ship. Some would argue for more fighter aircraft and more tanks, all equipped with the latest in electronic combat systems and weapons. But these arguments have to be set against clear deficiencies in our capacity to handle credible contingencies, such as an effective mine-countermeasures force.Similar considerations apply to our requirements for surface ships. Mr Dibb starts with the fundamental issues: For what purposes do we need surface ships, of what kind, and how many? He rigorously examines the demands of Australias maritime environment.Mr Dibb identifies important roles for surface ships in lower levels of conflict. But he notes that there are some concerns about the vulnerability of surface vessels in higher levels of conflict, particularly when the very high costs of modern highly capable surface combatants are considered.He concludes that our surface fleet may become deficient in its capacity to handle a range of maritime contingencies if it is limited on the one hand to higher capability destroyers which can be afforded only in small numbers, and on the other to small patrol boats whose capabilities are essentially limited to peacetime tasks.He therefore proposes introducing substantial numbers of a new class of light patrol frigate in the 1990s. The light patrol frigate should be able to provide an effective maritime presence in credible contingencies in more exposed or distant waters, and to contribute to the protection of important focal areas and our shipping. This proposal represents a major advance in thinking about maritime priorities.These new frigates should be capable of carrying a complex modern weapon fit, including harpoon missiles, a gun, air defence systems and a helicopter.This is no brown water ship. Vessels like it are readily identifiable in NATO forces, although ours would need to be tailored specifically to meet Australian requirements.The outcome would mean, if the government were to adopt Mr Dibbs maximum suggestions, a substantial increase in the business end of the surface fleet. From 12 highly capable-if in some instances aging-warships we could go as high as 17.These ships would be in 2 categories. Firstly, heavy destroyers of the FFG/DDG variety, the capabilities of which were substantially enhanced by the governments decision to acquire Seahawk helicopters. Secondly, a class of light patrol frigate would replace aging destroyer escorts and some of the less capable patrol boats.Mr Dibb identifies a real role for the army, and he comprehensively refutes those who would do away with ground forces and rely solely on our air and naval forces. Mr Dibb concludes that low level conflict would be a formidable problem for our ground forces.The first priority for ground force planning would be forces to deal with raiding groups in a range of low-level conflicts. The emphasis would need to be on light but adequately armed forces, highly mobile, able to operate over vast distances, and needing the minimum of logistic support with concentrated protective forces in key areas.But Mr Dibb also notes that the possibility of fighting a conventional land battle in Australia is not so entirely improbable that we should not retain some limited skills and expansion capacity against such an event. The appropriate forces for such circumstances should be developed within the framework of a force giving priority of manning and equipment to the needs of lower-level, more credible contingencies.An important recommendation of the review is the need to upgrade substantially the tactical mobility of our ground forces by expanding the utility helicopter force. This is the single most expensive equipment addition to the current program that the review recommends.Mr Dibb also identifies a need for the army to be provided with adequate ground mobility and firepower.While the current M113 armoured personnel carrier may not be ideal it is generally adequate in the short term, perhaps with some modifications. In the long-term program for the replacement of the M113 there is time and scope for practical experimentation with different vehicle types, particularly in the north of the continent. There may also be a place for specialised mobility vehicles.Mr Dibb sees a reduced need for armour and mechanisation of our ground forces, and considers that artillery should be constrained. I emphasise that he does not propose doing away with these capabilities. Rather he proposes limiting the resources applied in these areas, and that the reserves should take a greater role in maintaining the expansion base elements.I note that there are some reservations in the defence force about the practicability or timing of some of these capability adjustments. Similarly, practical considerations may limit the speed with which the proposals for basing of major regular army units in the north can be implemented, although options are being considered for a smaller unit.These differences should not obscure the major contribution that has been made to our understanding of the role of Australian ground forces. Mr Dibb has confirmed our northern areas as the priority area for ground force operations; he has examined the nature of the conflict that could be expected there; and he has drawn attention to the huge logistic problems of dispersed operations across a vast and harsh northern hinterland.The Dibb review confirms the central role of airpower in the defence of Australia at all levels of conflict, and it endorses the RAAFs basic structure and capabilities.But the review calls for these resources to be more directly focused on the specific strategic requirements of Australian defence. To this he recommends the development of more air bases in the north, for example, and by acquiring air to air refuelling for the FA-18s.The review also confronts the airforce with the vital challenge of developing a comprehensive surveillance system involving an optimum combination of other, AEW and ground-based radar.I mention now some other issues raised in the review.The review does not propose any radical changes to the existing command and control system, but notes that the trend is for the joint command structure under the chief of defence force rather than single service operations. This trend is already reflected in the move towards functional command arrangements, and will be assisted by the appointment of a vice chief of the defence force. Other command and control proposals-the question of control of the battlefield utility helicopters and the establishment of a northern command-are already being examined within defence.ReservesN/AMr Dibb makes a number of major recommendations about the reserves, designed to give them more central and challenging roles in the ADF.Mr Dibb proposes that the army reserve should take over from the regulars some of the heavier weapons-including tanks and artillery-which are maintained primarily to provide a base for expansion. This would entrust the reserves with a vital and exciting role.But that does not mean that the reserves will only have a role in remote, high-level contingencies. It is also proposed that the army reserve should be given specific responsibility for the security of vital installations in our north.Mr Dibb has concluded that this task would be a major undertaking even in the type of low-level contingency which could emerge with little warning.Mr Dibb envisages that individual reserve units in southern states should be allocated specific towns and installations in the north which they would be deployed to defend in an emergency.Reserve units would deploy to exercise regularly in their allocated area of responsibility, giving them greater familiarity with their wartime tasks, and increasing their sense of purpose.Similar recommendations are made for the Airforce and Navy Reserves. In the Airforce Mr Dibb proposes that reservists take over specific roles in aircraft maintenance and airfield defence.In the Navy he proposes that reservists should take over the operation of mine countermeasures vessels, which as I have already said is one of the key areas of defence in plausible low-level contingencies.The Government is very concerned to strengthen the role of the Reserves in the ADF, and I believe Mr Dibbs proposals are an excellent guide to how this could be done.As a start, I agree with Mr Dibbs endorsement of the long standing proposal that limited call-out of the Reserves should be possible in situations short of a declared defence emergency. I intend to take legislation to this effect to Government. When implemented it will do much to increase the value and flexibility of the Reserves as an integral part of the ADF.These new tasks and directions for the Reserves will require a greater training effort, and we will be considering increasing the number of days training each year. We will also consider an increase in Army reserve numbers from the current figure of 23,000 to a new ceiling of 26,000 by 1988, instead of the present ceiling of 30,000.Mr Dibb has examined the readiness and sustainability of our forces, and exposed some deficiencies in our capacity to measure this. He points to the need to ensure that key military forces are properly ready to pre-empt or respond to credible low level situations arising with little warning.An important consideration here is the need for a proper stockholding policy, which has been badly neglected in the past. We do not need large stocks of all items, but we do need to ensure that the forces required to respond at short notice are properly equipped and can sustain operations.Specific funding will be allocated to ensure that some current deficiencies are remedied as part of the effort to improve the readiness of our reaction forces as Mr Dibb recommends.ConclusionN/AIt is the custom of many defence commentators in this country to run up shopping lists of capabilities, without regard to their cost or practicability. Mr Dibbs review was not intended to be a cost cutting exercise, and has not been conducted as such. But he has costed out his proposals responsibly. His work on resource implications was not intended to provide a definitive financial prescription for the future. Rather he was concerned to demonstrate the affordability of his proposals, and to illustrate a way ahead for their implementation.As Minister for Defence, I have been impressed by the quality of this review. Mr Dibb has taken the broad principles of strategic guidance, refined them into a defence strategy and applied these concepts to our force structure in a comprehensive and balanced way. It is of course possible to suggest different approaches and to quarrel with some of the lines of argument used and the conclusions reached. But I believe that most will acknowledge this review as a significant intellectual achievement that should make a major contribution to the way in which Australians think about defence.It is not my purpose here to provide a final Government decision on the conclusions and recommendations of the review, although I have already indicated my acceptance of its broad approach and its main principles. I now intend that there will be the opportunity for discussion and debate on Mr Dibbs work, both in the Parliament and outside.I understand that the Australian Government Publishing Service intends to have copies of the review available in its bookshops around Australia within a few days. Mr Dibb himself will undertake a round of speaking engagements as part of the process of discussion and debate.The public version of the review is essentially the same as the classified version presented to me. Classified material has been removed, including some technical details on equipment performance and some material on intelligence matters. The public version does include, however, a full and comprehensive discussion of all the major force structure issues.It should now be clear that the Dibb review is a very complex, rigorous document. It demands deep study, and I hope those who participate in the debate will give it the detailed attention it deserves.Defence policy raises fundamental and serious issues for this country. Defence expenditure is now at the highest levels for peacetime, and constitutes a large financial burden for a nation facing some economic difficulties and many competing demands.Mr Dibb has developed his proposals within responsible financial limits. Yet his advice on the defence program provides for new submarines, a new class of surface vessel, many more helicopters for the Army, new surveillance and early warning systems, a revitalised mine-countermeasures force and an improved capacity to sustain air and ground forces across the north.The House has a right to expect that those who disagree with Mr Dibb will do more than mouth slogans. Where there is disagreement with this report we deserve to know what specific programs would be implemented instead, how these are justified by our strategic circumstances, and how much they would cost.When I appointed Paul Dibb in February last year, I said that I regarded his review as the most important appraisal of our defence capabilities since the end of World War Two. The result has more than met my hopes.I conclude by formally recording my thanks to Mr Dibb and his team for their outstanding work.Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:That the Senate take note of the paper.

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator SIBRAA
content: —When this Government came to power in 1983 it was evident that some serious defence thinking was necessary. An overview of Australian defence needs, capabilities and potential was clearly lacking. In 1983 the Australian Labor Party came to power, after spending 31 of the previous 34 years in opposition. The failure of the coalition to come to grips with the defence question was painfully apparent. All too often in the late 1970s because threats were not present-I might add that they are still not apparent-little was done to develop this comprehensive overview of defence.Mr Paul Dibb, a well-respected and independent analyst, was employed to review the whole question of defence. His brief was indeed a large one, because the whole picture has to be reviewed. The role of the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy, the Royal Australian Air Force, as well as the question of logistics had to be reviewed. This review also had to come to grips with the changing perception of Australias role in this region and, indeed, in the world. Australia as a nation is a member of the Western Alliance and ANZUS which not only provide certain securities but also demand responsibilities. To be an effective member of that partnership Australia needed this defence overview. In dealing with this review some very important issues emerge. The Dibb Review of Australias Defence Capabilities is an intelligent, comprehensive and coherent vision of Australian defence capacity at present and what options we ought to pursue in the future. Put simply, the Dibb report tells us where we have come from, where we are at and, most importantly for defence planners, in which direction we need to head.In 1941 Australia faced the possibility of a Japanese invasion. Already committed to a war on the other side of the world and already with considerable forces in Britain and the Middle East, Australia lacked the ability to defend either its merchant navy or even its shores from a Japanese attack. At the time the Labor Government had to face immediate threats, even though Labor Prime Minister Curtin had forewarned about such eventualities years earlier. In fact, in 1936 John Curtin stated in a speech in the other place:The people of Australia would expect this country to be capable of defending itself should the occasion arise.He went on to say:A greater degree of self-reliance in Australias defence is essential.Five years after that speech the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbour, invaded Indo-China and swept through the Indonesian archipelago into Papua New Guinea.In February 1942 the Japanese proved that they were the masters of the western Pacific by taking the impregnable base of Singapore. The threat then, naturally enough, was obvious. The Japanese made the message clear by bombing Darwin, with a considerable loss of life and shipping only a few days later. The Curtin Labor Government was quickly made aware of its weakness and how Australia, relying on the bulwark of Singapore and upon Britains ability to reinforce that base in time of war, was now in peril of attack. Curtin-I repeat, five years before Pearl Harbour and substantially before German rearmament-went on it that speech to conclude:The dependence of Australia on the competence, let alone the readiness, of British statesmen to send forces to our aid is too dangerous a hazard on which to found Australias defence policy.The basic premise that has underpinned Australias defence thinking since those dark days of 1942 is the necessity to be able to be self-reliant. Australian forces of sufficient strength need to be able to defend sovereign territory, coastal areas, sea approaches and trade. Australia in the 1980s, rather than the 1940s, has to take the primary responsibility for its own defence. These words of United States Secretary for Defence, Mr Weinberger, in an address to the National Press Club in April, made the point very clearly:Defence of a countrys own borders and own airspace and the sea around it, obviously, is a prime attribute of sovereignty, and, of course, has to be one of the first priorities of any country.Secretary Weinberger had developed this point in a major policy statement in November 1984 when he stated:We have learned that there are limits to how much of our spirit and blood and treasure we can afford to forfeit in meeting our responsibility to keep peace and freedom. So while we may and should offer substantial amounts of economic and military assistance to our allies in their time of need, and help them maintain forces to deter attacks against them we cannot substitute our troops or our will for theirs.The previous Government also recognised the need to maintain defence self-reliance. In its 1976 Defence White Paper the following was stated:This self-reliant posture derives essentially from our national interests and responsibilities. It also accords with our status as an ally of the U.S., for by accepting our local responsibilities we can contribute to the alliance relationship and to the U.S. global effort.The problem was, of course, that whilst the bipartisan approach to self-reliance was a plank of defence policy, the actual implementation of the policy in the hands of our predecessors left much to be desired. Most of the hard decisions were avoided, put off for the next crisis, at which time expenditure could be much more easily justified, and the Defence Forces structural implications were not developed. In fact, Mr Dibbs job was made all the more urgent by the fact that some decisions had been put off for far too long.The Dibb report is based on sound par- ameters. In essence, three main bases for this report emerge: Firstly, the need for self-reliance as a primary aim, on which I have already made extensive comments; secondly, that costs be based on realistic budget estimates; and, thirdly, that we recognise that, whilst low level threats can emerge quickly, it would take many years for any country other than a superpower to equip itself for a major military assault on Australia. The second point, of course, is at the heart of the matter because the cost of a good, efficient, well-trained and capable defence force is not cheap. At present, budget outlays for defence are around 3 per cent of gross domestic product. That means for this financial year a cost of $6.5 billion. The 3 per cent figure is a realistic one even though it represents 10 per cent of Commonwealth outlays and is the biggest outlay behind the social welfare budget. Under the coalition the Budget outlay exceeded 3 per cent from time to time during some international crisis such as in 1980. However, in other years it was pared back well below that figure. The basis of this report is that an outlay of 3 per cent, which can be maintained, is better than the boom and bust syndrome with which defence planners until now have had to contend.As to the military threat to Australia, Mr Dibb makes certain contingencies clear in his report. Australia needs to have defence forces which can cope with low level threats, which can develop quickly or without warning at all. Such possibilities as incursions into sea and air space, harassment of fishing vessels and coastal shipping, terrorist-type raids on off-shore oil or gas rigs, covert mining of ports, air harassment of northern settlements, raids on northern communities and sabotage of installations would constitute a low level threat, a threat nonetheless that would require adequate and competent counter measures. Escalated low level conflicts would be more severe, more pronounced and would involve more regular attacks on shipping and on isolated settlements.The Australian defence forces would need to be able to react to all of these developments immediately. More substantial conflicts in which more pronounced threats to Australia and Australias vital interests should be detected by intelligence forces well in advance. An example of this might be the acquisition of greater capabilities by one of our neighbours which, when detected, could see Australian forces develop adequate counter measures. However, it must be clearly stated, so that no confusion on this matter exists, that the Dibb report at present sees no threat to Australia or Australian interests on any level. Current defence thinking is not based on some perceived threat in our region, but on the axiom that Australians have a right to expect that their nation is able to defend itself.Under this report the Army will not be reduced. The Army reserves will go up from 23,000 to 26,000. The operational deployment force capacity to lift a company into battle will be expanded to a battalion. Located at Tindal in the Northern Territory, a battalion of troops will protect military installations and ultimately these forces will be of brigade strength. Of course one of the chief recommendations of this report is the exciting way in which the reserve forces will fit into this new defence posture.

name: Senator SIBRAA
content: —That is an issue that is being looked at very carefully by the Minister. Not every line in this report has to be followed. The reserves will have better equipment, more training and will be assigned specific tasks in the north in times of danger. Call out legislation will be needed for use of the reserve formation under this plan. It should be pointed out, however, that these are volunteers and not conscripts. To assess the ability of any enemy adequate intelligence is required. It is, of course, required not only before any conflict but also during it. This review calls for two Jindalee over the horizon radar installations with eventually two more. This will be at the backbone of early warning and will need to have a high defence classification for security purposes. The use of this facility for civilian purposes, such as the detection of drug importation and consequent enforcement, will be an added bonus.In this report the role of the Royal Australian Air Force is seen as crucial. The ability to project Australian military power some 1,000 nautical miles from our coast will require a $200m upgrading of the current 23 F111s, as well as the acquisition of mid-air refuelling capabilities. To achieve such a presence a new Air Force base in north Queensland will need to be built. Under this review the Royal Australian Navy will not have a carrier and will be reliant for air support from the Air Force rather than having its own fixed wing component, but it will still be a blue water Navy with a clearly defined role. One of the first areas to be tackled is that of mines and mine counter measures. It is a situation which can be described only as one of criminal neglect; that is the way in which previous governments and the Navy have treated this matter. If current Navy plans to upgrade this capability fail, three ships from overseas will need to be purchased in the near future.The life of much of Australias destroyer escorts soon will effectively be over. The patrol boats which are in current use are also severely limited and of little strategic use. One specific recommendation is that five patrol boats and three destroyer escorts be replaced by eight light frigates. These frigates would be similar to the ones which are already in service with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. In essence, they would carry one Seahawk helicopter, be missile armed for surface-to-surface and surface-to-air capability and have guns for coastal bombardment. When the last of the FFGs are completed such vessels could be built in Australia to overseas design.There are many recommendations in this report and options for future defence planning. The Dibb review is a comprehensive set of recommendations based on a realistic set of precepts. The report does not have to be followed to the letter; far from it. A White Paper will be issued at the end of this year or early next year and it should be pointed out that Mr Dibbs comprehensive review has shortened the process that would necessarily have followed by at least 18 months. The Dibb review is the first comprehensive statement of Australias defence preparedness and in which direction it should rationally proceed. This review is not an isolationist one. The review talks about projection of adequate military power to 1,000 nautical miles from Australias coastline to being capable of defending Australian sovereignty and vital maritime interests.This review also recognises the value, as this Government does, of the membership of the ANZUS pact and the Western alliance. Recommendations are clearly shown about how Australia can usefully play a role in ANZUS and in the Western alliance, the foundation block of which must be Australian self-reliance. This review, I repeat, is not an isolationist one. It projects an Australia that can adequately defend almost 10 per cent of the earths surface.

name: Senator MacGIBBON
content: —I regret very much that the Senate has had very little time to look at the Dibb report, `Review of Australias Defence Capabilities, which has just been tabled. It is a big report and it certainly is worthy of consideration. I have read in full the tabling speech by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I have read two-thirds of part 1 of the paper and I have skimmed the rest of it. I regret that I do not have time to take it apart piece by piece. I give notice that I accept the Ministers challenge in his tabling speech, and I will certainly be coming back to debate this matter in detail in the fullness of time. I hope that, in contrast to all the other speeches which I have made, the Minister this time will not run away from the arguments which are put to him. In all the years that I have been in the Senate I have never had the courtesy of a reasoned reply to any of the comments I have made in the defence field. Since the Minister has gone out on a limb this time and has invited comment, he will certainly get it from me and, I imagine, from a large number of my colleagues.This document authenticates Australian Labor Party defence policy. More than that, it authenticates what the Labor Party has already done in running down the capacity of the Australian defence forces to defend Australia. The document is certainly a very interesting academic treatise, from what I have seen; but regrettably it starts with some false assumptions and it builds its whole argument around these assumptions which are totally false. It does not matter how logical it is from there on; having made the false assumptions, or a series of false assumptions, one cannot get the right solution when starting from the wrong point. In the limited time we have this afternoon I certainly cannot go through this document in detail, so I will confine the few minutes I have to debating the conceptual basis, the conceptual inadequacies, of this report.One of the first points made in this report is that there is no threat. If we look at the history of mankind we will find that 90 per cent of armed conflicts between nations have never been predicted or foreseen. They arise de novo. We can see the origins of them very clearly when we look at them in hindsight; but with foresight, which is what we have to live with, we cannot see them. It suits the Labor Party to downplay defence and, in supporting that downplay of defence, it uses the assumption of no threat to back it up. I was very interested to see that the Minister quoted from a former failed Labor Prime Minister, Mr Curtin. He quoted at length from what Mr Curtin said in the 1930s. What he did not say was that six months before the outbreak of the Second World War Mr Curtin was saying that there was no foreseeable threat to Australia. Mr Curtin is reported in the Hansard of the House of Representatives six months before September 1939 as saying that there were no threats to Australia at all. What happened when Japan came into the war? Again we had this no threat doctrine.Honourable senators interjecting-

name: Senator MacGIBBON
content: —I do not need any protection from illogical people such as those opposite, Mr Acting Deputy President. Within four months of entering the war, the Japanese swept through the whole of the western part of the Pacific. Where was the 10-year warning time then? We paid for the negligence of the Labor Party at that time with the lives of young Australians. I for one will not tolerate a situation like that ever again while I have a say in the matter.Another basic concept on which this report is based is the strategic assessment. Labor hides behind the strategic assessment, as if the strategic assessment were some sort of holy document which is always accurate. The strategic assessment on which Australian defence planning is based, according to evidence which has been given to the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, is a political document. In other words, the public servants in the Department of Defence write the strategic assessment in the light of the government of the day to cater for the known prejudices and beliefs of that government. It is not a document which deals accurately with the strategic situation.The third false assumption in this document is that Australia can never afford more than 3 per cent of its gross domestic product for defence. Three per cent of gross domestic product is simply not enough in the modern age and in the situation we face to meet the defence needs of the country. Mr Beazley will not accept that. One of the very first conditions Mr Dibb was given in his remit for the report was that he had to accept the financial restraints that exist at present; in other words, the 3 per cent of gross domestic product. That is simply not enough.

name: Senator MacGIBBON
content: —I would look at cutting it down considerably. The fourth point which the Government goes on with is a jingoistic belief in self-sufficiency. I have always maintained that we should be self-sufficient in defence, but I do not mean that in the jingoistic way that the Labor Party means it. I believe that we should not be a parasite in the region. I believe that we should have effective standing forces so that we can maintain our alliances in the region.Finally, I come to the fortress Australia concept, which is the whole concept of what the Labor Party wants in defence. The bottom line of it all is: What can Mr Beazley get away with from the far Left of the Labor Party? The defence policy of this Government, like the foreign policy, is what the left wing, the Senator Cooks and people of that kidney, will accept. I do not accept that that is what the majority of Australians want, let alone what they need. With this report, we hide behind the flim-flam of a strategy of denial. There is no honesty in that. There is no declaration that this is fortress Australia. Instead, there is the dissembling point-it is a strategy of denial. I will come back to that point later.There is a dear belief in the Labor Party that, if we hide like a lot of good little children in our back yard and do not go out and play on the streets, we will be safe-no one will climb over the fence to get us. That might be a fine philosophy for kids, but it is not a philosophy for adults in an adult world. The Dibb report rationalises what has already taken place in the defence forces since Australia became governed by the Labor Party. The Labor Party got rid of any overseas deployment capability so that it could incorporate Fortress Australia as a fact of life. There were two keys to this. The first was abandoning the Fleet Air Arm. Not replacing the aircraft carrier means that we do not have air cover at sea. Despite what Senator Sibraa in his ignorance said, if we do not have air cover at sea we simply cannot have a blue water navy. But Mr Dibb, as he says in his report, cannot see the need for ships other than for coastal protection duty. I hammer this point: If we do not have air cover we cannot have a blue water navy. That maritime strategy has been known for 50 years.The second thing the Labor Party did to strip Australia of anything other than a Fortress Australia capability was to disband the amphibious squadron at HMAS Moreton. It got rid of the six landing craft heavy ships-Balikpapan, Brunei, Labuan, Betano, Wewak and Tarakan-and the amphibious heavy lift ship Tobruk. Not only did the Labor Party destroy that amphibious capability; it also in the same blow destroyed the training capability for the Army because 6 Brigade at Enoggera was tasked with training for the amphibious role.The most likely consequence for the use of Australian forces will be in the south-west Pacific area to support a friendly democratic government that is under attack, probably from some of the friends of the Labor Party from the Libyan Embassy, or the Cuban Embassy, in Vanuatu or something like that. Without an amphibious squadron, without an Army unit trained in amphibious operations, we simply cannot support our foreign policy in the region because the Labor Party has taken that resource and that capability away from us. In return it comes up with the Fortress Australia concept-the strategy of denial; the policy of layered defence.Mr Dibb put Mr Beazleys moat in terms of a thousand miles of what he, in a buzz word, calls the sea-air gap. Mr Dibb has only to look at the map to realise that the 1,000 nautical miles barrier around Australia has quite a lot of land in it. It is not a moat. It includes New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and Timor. It extends to Ambon, the Celebes and part of Indonesia. There will be bases in that land mass. He comes to the astonishing conclusion that although there will be this 1,000-mile barrier, we do not need to know what is going on in it because Mr Dibb recommends that we do not buy an airborne early warning capability. Without an AEW capability we simply cannot survey that area. The benefits of Jindalee, the over-the-horizon radar, are considerable. However, they are nowhere near precise or comprehensive enough to be able to survey those areas. We are going to have a moat of 1,000 miles and we are assuming that all the good people out there will not trouble us. We are going to have a brown water navy. We are not going to be able to put surface ships into the area because they lack air cover.Mr Dibb relies very heavily on the Royal Australian Air Force. As everyone knows, I have a very soft spot for the Air Force, which is an essential part of the deterrent function of Australian defence. However, the Air Force has a very limited use. One can either bomb someone or one cannot. One cannot influence the foreign policies of another country by putting aircraft overhead. That is not the way the Air Force works. One either destroys a target or one does not. Aircraft are very inflexible; what is more, they are very short term. One can be over a distant target only for minutes.Of course, the other casualty is the Army which is to be reduced really to riot police status. It will be a SWAT squad. The New South Wales Police Force would be able to take on the Army when the Dibb report is fully implemented because there is to be no armour, no armoured personnel carriers and no artillery. The Army is going to buy some helicopters, and that is good. However, one cannot fight from a helicopter. Soldiers have to get out of those helicopters if they want to do anything. I hope that the people running out of the helicopters are the Mr Dibbs and the Mr Beazleys of this world and that they have only a green shirt for protection. I hope that there are a few accurate markesmen on the other side because they will then learn-although it will be a fatal learning process-that we have to have armour on the ground and close fire support.The policy of strategic denial has some very fundamental flaws for Australian defence. It denies any alliances in the region. It abandons the notion that we are part of a community of nations which want to live in peace and stability. It says to those people in the region: `We in Australia will not be able to deploy the Army, Navy or Air Force, either individually or collectively, to help and support you if that need arises. We are saying: `We are turning our back on you completely. You do not matter to us. People in the region do not like it, as the Indonesians have made very clear. But more importantly, because we turn our back on those people, we are sending them a very clear signal that we see them as the potential enemies. The consequences of that for our foreign policy are enormous. At the end of the day one only has to look at history to know that no fortress has ever stood alone. We cannot pull up the drawbridge over the moat around Australia and live in peace in perpetuity. This simply cannot happen.I would now like to turn very briefly to the report itself which, of course, commences with that great statement I have already dealt with-the statement that there is no threat. The following statement is made on page 7 of the report:Air strike or naval interdiction capabilities that could contribute to our allies in more distant areas should not be a force determinant.That is a nonsense, and I have just dealt with that point. The report also states:Enhancement of the land-strike capacity of the F111 force is not required at this time.But the best part is in regard to maritime defence. I will refer to two statements in the report because they are factually incorrect. The report states:Land-based aircraft would be expected to provide maritime air defence where necessary . . . but we should avoid policies that require naval surface vessels to be placed at risk of air attack without access to our own defending aircraft.That is the most nonsensical piece of academic irrelevance that I have ever heard. Someone should have told Senator Withers or Senator Hamer when they were having the hell bombed out of them in the Mediterranean in the 1940s that there should have been a policy that should not commit ships without air cover. We do not control those situations. The second nonsensical statement is that the F111 can perform the role of a long-range air interceptor. One thing the F111 cannot do is to act as a fighter. It lacks the radar and the armaments to do it. All it has are Sidewinders. A big heavy aircraft like that simply cannot operate in that way.I will go through other things in the report in much greater detail at another time. However, in summary and in conclusion, this report is isolationist, it is insular, it is immature and it is impractical. It will destabilise the area and it is dangerous for Australias long term security.
debateinfo: REVIEW OF AUSTRALIAS DEFENCE CAPABILITIES
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator MASON
content: —The Australian Democrats agree with the broad thrust of the Dibb Review of Australias Defence Capabilities which we have been awaiting with some interest. We believe that the report should now be used as a basis for broad agreement on what our defence needs are going to be over the next decade or so. I note with some interest the promise in the tabling statement of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that there will be a White Paper and that that White Paper will contribute significantly to our defence planning over the next decade and beyond.There is little doubt that for many years there has not been clear direction in our defence planning and that this has resulted in some very serious and expensive mistakes. We have been ineffectively spending far more on defence than have most other countries, notably such countries as Canada and Japan. The comparisons between Australias performance and the performance of those countries are, to put it mildly, pathetic. This appears to have been due to an ambivalence in the planning area between whether we are going to operate in the world of today or whether all of our strategy, all of our thinking in defence, is going to be based on what happened 45 or 50 years ago. We might just as well go back to the Battle of Waterloo and plan on the basis of what we were doing then as go back to the lessons of World War II.I know that that argument has gone on in this place and the community since the days when the short deck aircraft carrier was proposed. This was a disastrous enterprise and a disastrous concept. I have put a number of questions on notice on this matter. The last one that was necessary was: In the event of war and the possibility of a nuclear attack submarine being in the vicinity of Australia, would the new short deck carrier put to sea? I understand that certain people in the Department of Defence gave this question a great deal of agonising thought and they came up eventually with the only possible answer which was yes. That was the end of the debate, because anybody with any rationality would know that such a ship at sea, with the means we have within our Budget to defend it, would not last five minutes in those circumstances. It would be a mere sacrifice of that ship and every living soul on it. Therefore, I think we are coming slowly and painfully to a more rational view of what might be done in this country from the point of view of defence.The concept of forward defence, with Australia substantially being defended by powerful friends, into whose forces Australias forces were interposed to play minor roles, has been disastrous for this country in the past in terms of planning and would be even more disastrous in some circumstances one could think about. I put a scenario, for instance, in which both of the super-powers were severely mauled in a nuclear war-this is a very likely possibility-but in which Australia emerged relatively unscathed. I do not agree that that is necessarily a very strong possibility, but it exists. We would then be alone without powerful friends and forced to look after ourselves in a situation of virtual isolation of forces. If we went ahead purely with the concept of throwing in our lot with our powerful friends, we would inevitably be the victim of any casual opportunist or adventurer among our northern neighbours. Such an adventurer or opportunist may not exist now, but we must take into account, as the Dibb report has, that it may emerge and that it is not beyond the bounds of possibility.In other words, it is good common sense and rational planning for us to take a strong, independent attitude towards our own defence and to do everything we can within the reasonable expenditure of money in the circumstances to see that Australia is in a position to defend itself and particularly to be able to convey a foreign policy message to the world that we are thinking along those lines. To allow Australia to come to a situation where we were apparently quite without a defence capability in modern terms would be disastrous. I had hoped, until I heard Senator MacGibbon, that that ambivalence about our defence aims would now become a thing of the past. Unfortunately, it appears that that is not the case.The oceans in war time will be very unfriendly places, with weapons afloat, especially under the sea, which we would have no hope of dealing with. Blue water ships of the type we could readily afford would be sitting ducks for a nuclear attack submarine. The Governments plans to build smaller, patrol-type frigates in Australia are along the right lines, but I hope that the same disastrous mistake is not made as was made with the Fremantle class ships. Those patrol ships are excellent small warships, but their main armament is a bofors gun of the type used in World War II, which I understand on good authority is not capable of even firing a shot across the bows of a Taiwanese fishing boat if it is proceeding in a stiff breeze upwind.
