debateinfo: REVIEW OF AUSTRALIAS DEFENCE CAPABILITIES
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator MASON
content: —I gather that is the case. It is absolutely disastrous and totally irresponsible to have perpetrated such a thing. I have spoken to senior officers-not naval officers-who are concerned with this class of ship and they have wept tears of blood over this. They know perfectly well that those ships could be missile capable. There is space in them for the control systems and missiles and they ought to have been designed that way from the beginning. Happily, that point is noted on page 129 of the Dibb report, but there is an ambivalence there. It is stated that these ships probably will not be missile capable, but they might be. I suggest that the Government ought to grasp that nettle right now and not build or buy any more light ships or frigates of that type which do not have surface to surface or surface to air missile capability.Our reasoning is based on the enormous advantage of the capability to fire missiles in large numbers. Phalanx and other quick firing gun defence systems can protect an enemy from a small number of missiles, but our ability to fire such missiles in large numbers from cheap, mobile, easily defended and to some extent expendable platforms would progressively increase our chance of completely destroying an invading fleet. That has been taught in regional wars where naval forces have been engaged, such as the Middle East and the Falklands. Perception by the rest of the world that we have the capacity to do great damage is a vital foreign policy weapon that we should have. It would be a serious deficiency if once again, as with the Fremantles, we built a whole class of small vessels without that missile capability. Such ships with small guns scarcely enable units at all; they are more coastguard type ships. Somebody mentioned earlier in the debate something about coastal gunnery. We are certainly not going to do much effective coastal gunnery with ships of that type in any war I could conceive in the future.In relation to the Air Force, we agree with the two major recommendations; to provide air to air refuelling for the FA18 aircraft-it is absolutely essential if these aircraft are to carry out any kind of reasonable role in the future-and to maintain the F111 aircraft force. Senator MacGibbon does not agree with that, but I think the F111s are worth maintaining and upgrading. They fill a role that the FA18s are not capable of filling.For many years the Australian Democrats have pressed for a modern, professional Army with the strongest possible airborne and parachute capability. We are delighted to see that the Dibb report has made recommendations in this direction. The last thing we would want is an Army which does not stress quick mobility, trained and equipped along conventional lines, based in south-east Australia. That is what we have had in the past. If we have that, we are looking at the possibility that any future threat to this country will come from either New Zealand or Antarctica. That is not so; any future threat to this country will come from the north or west. It is again square one stuff that we have to have a highly professional Army with the best light weapons we can provide; not artillery, but weapons that a man can use in his own hands. Those weapons exist and are indeed lethal. The Army must have the capacity and training to be moved quickly to any location in Australia where a threat might arise.I agree with the Dibb report that there is not really a major threat to Australia at the moment because of our geographical situation. If a threat emerged, unless we are in a position to have that kind of mobile force, which could actually go and fight and operate efficiently on the ground anywhere in Australia, we might at some stage have the considerable embarrassment of having to fight a long, drawn out conflict against a comparatively small force which had been landed somewhere in our north-west, which we might not know about, on our present state of reconnaissance, for days or weeks after it happened. We have to have the capability of getting a force in quickly which is capable of dealing with that. Here again the foreign policy message is important. It is essential for our neighbours and the rest of the world to know that we are smart enough to see things in those terms.As I recall, there was an agreement among the Whips, which the Democrats intend to honour, that this debate should be held to 10 minutes on this matter, so I have only one more thing to say. I am concerned at the early reaction of the Liberal and National parties to the Dibb report. As has been reported in the media today, their comments have been unconstructive and quite damaging to an effective Australian defence effort. We cannot go back to the past and make important judgments on the basis of the weapons, strategies and experiences of the past. It is important also that one should not take something such as this report, which has been carefully thought out and constructed in detail, and damn it out of hand. I hope that that tendency will not be continued by the Opposition. I will not say that the report is not beyond criticism-of course it is not, and that is probably the best reason for my appeal to the Opposition. If the Opposition has criticisms, let them be realistic and useful so that when the promised White Paper, which will determine how our defence will stand for the coming decades, is written, the Opposition will have some constructive and useful input rather than merely saying, quite emotionally, that we ought to go back to the forward defence policies of the past without qualification.

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator VALLENTINE
content: —I welcome the general thrust of the Dibb report-the report of the Review of Australias Defence Capabilities-that is, that Australia should be moving towards self-reliance in defence capabilities. This is an important document which highlights the need for a new approach to our foreign policy upon which this report is founded. A disturbing aspect of the tabling statement of the Minister for defence, Mr Beazley, is that Caspar Weinberger is quoted more than anyone else in the whole document. In fact, Mr Beazley moved swiftly from quoting John Curtin to quoting Caspar Weinberger, whose statements received a lot more prominence. It is as though we must have the United States permission to develop our own defence policies. The reality is that we have been requested by the United States to develop self-reliance since the Nixon statement in Guam in 1969. The Dibb report merely complies with that directive from the senior partner in the nuclear alliance in which we are now involved. Pages five and six of the text of the Ministers statement are an apology to those who think it inappropriate for Australia to have any independent thoughts whatsoever.The discussion which has taken place already in anticipation of this report has been very healthy. There must be much more debate about foreign policy and defence issues in this country. I call for a community based defence review inquiry along the lines of the one being conducted in New Zealand at present. The Dibb report will serve as a very useful starting point for such community debate. Like the issue of nuclear disarmament, I believe that foreign policy and defence issues are too important to be left to politicians and academic experts. The people should have a say and I look forward to that happening.Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

name: Senator MACKLIN
content: —I move:That the Senate take note of the paper.The statement put down yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), presented in this place by the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, Senator Walsh, deals basically with the single matter of the marketing boards which the Government is seeking to overhaul, as time and the legislative commitments of both chambers permit. We have already looked at the restructuring of some boards. Obviously a very large number are yet to be looked at. The Australian Democrats still see a number of problems with the proposition. We have been very firmly of the view that these marketing authorities should have a producer majority. The Governments second key principle, at page 5 of the text of the statement, reads:. . . boards of the authorities will be established on a corporate rather than a representational basis with members selected according to merit and relevant expertise.While that may sound very useful-I do not think anyone can be against expertise-we will lose a considerable amount of contact if we give away without question the representation base of these boards. Page 7 of the text of the statement, with regard to that representation base, reads:As such the system in which members are elected through ballots of particular interest groups is unsuitable since members would be answerable to those groups.I think that one of the particular strengths of the notion of a representative board as against a nominated board is that it is answerable to those groups. But, in being answerable to those groups, I believe that such a board is able to take those groups with it on most occasions with regard to the decisions that are made by that board. Surely it is of vital importance in regard to the boards of any of our major industries-or even some of the newer and smaller industries which have established boards-that the industries must have confidence in and support for the policies of those boards. By cutting ourselves off from the representative base, we give away one very real and effective means that has been used in the past to get the co-operation of the special interest groups. I remind the Senate that those special interest groups are not just any group in the community; they comprise the people who produce the commodity which is being sold. In other words, they have a very clear and distinct interest in what those boards do and in how successful those boards are.It is not the case that the representatives on those boards can in any way further the interests of the groups which they represent without at the same time furthering the aims of the boards, because the interests of those production groups and the interests of the boards are identical-that is, to increase the export of and markets for those commodities. Therefore, I think somewhat of a fallacy has crept into the Governments thinking with regard to this aspect. It is as though it believes there is some conflict of interest between those two groups. There is not, and there cannot be.When we were looking at representation on the Australian Wheat Board, which was one of the boards that the Government sought to restructure earlier, the Australian Democrats would not accept the Governments proposal and a compromise was reached whereby expertise was sought from representative groups. I believe that is a solution that should recommend itself to the Government so that we may be able to maintain both the representative nature that is currently available to the boards and the expertise that the Government is currently seeking.
debateinfo: GOVERNMENTS POLICIES FOR MARKETING RURAL PRODUCE
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I rise to support Senator Macklin in his contention that the marketing boards should have a large amount of grower representation. The growers are the people who suffer from the rural crisis. They are the people who need to be protected against the problems that are imported from overseas. We do have a rural crisis, so it is very timely that the Government should be looking at reorganising the boards which are some of the main front organisations which handle our overseas marketing. Our prices overseas are very low because of dumping by countries all over the world, particularly by the European Economic Community and the United States of America, which subsidise their domestic production and also accumulate surpluses of the various agricultural products that they eventually dump on world markets. They also give aid through consumer credit programs. I believe the Government should consider allowing our boards to enter into that sort of program.I want to address a few other factors which the boards need to look at. I refer to the fact that many countries prefer to import pre-packaged or pre-processed goods which are ready for sale or final assembly into a salable product. If we can get into that area and have more value added to our products, we will get more revenue in this area. This is one of the points that was made quite cogently in the statement of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). The other problem is that a lot of our products are considered to be fair average quality-f.a.q.-products. What is sought by foreign countries is high quality products which they can sell in their markets at a special premium price.We also have low local prices. The boards do handle some marketing on a local basis. One of the major problems is that we have many small producers selling to a few large wholesalers. A small surplus of products can result in a large slump in prices on the local market. It is possible that dumped products may compete and produce a local lowering of the price of the product, particularly where the products which are imported are of a higher quality or greater variety than the ones which are produced here. Currently we also have rising costs because of high interest rates, government service costs, wage rises and other costs, and an inflated capital value of land, which poses a real problem for people living near cities. We also have the problem of the cost of tariffs due to the tariff protection of oils, machinery and fertilisers.The Government is kidding itself if it believes that it can solve the problems of producing an export efficient industry just by reorganising the marketing bodies. The Minister promises an effort to reverse the corruption of international markets as countries default on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, but he does not say how this will be done. He talks about joint negotiations of marketing treaties with our Pacific neighbours, New Zealand for a start, through the closer economic relations scheme. I support that, but we must go a lot wider. It is very important that we should look at such innovative thoughts as tying the interest rates on overseas loans to commodity prices on world markets and try to institute that through all our systems. But the Minister does not address these views.I believe that we must get more and more behind getting higher value added products on to the market and exporting them. This can be done only through a sensible incentive program. I hope that the industry research and development legislation and the 150 per cent tax concessions will help in doing this and that people will look for sensible private sector solutions to complement the Minister.

name: Senator COOK
content: —I move:That the Senate take note of the paper.This is the first of a series of papers dealing with the International Labour Conference. It is important to note that Australia was a foundation member of the International Labour Organisation which is a branch of the United Nations devoted to labour studies. The ILO is a tripartite body which meets annually in Geneva and it begins its 1986 meeting next week. It is a body in which we have participated and by which we are well regarded as a country, although during the latter years of the Fraser Administration our standing in the ILO decreased because of activities by that Government on the industrial relations front in this country which contravened ILO conventions. However, this Government has adopted those ILO conventions that it is open to adopt and last November the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) reported that convention 142 and convention 150-the first dealing with vocational guidance and the second with labour administration-had been adopted by Australia.These papers deal with two new conventions coming from the 1985 conference-convention 160 which concerns labour statistics, the method of collection, the formation of those statistics and what they cover; and convention 161 which deals with occupational health and safety. There are also recommendations in both those fields associated with those conventions. I wish to dwell on the one which the Minister has indicated he is prepared to adopt and ratify in Australia-that is, the convention on the collection of labour statistics. That convention tries to find a uniform international base for collection of statistics associated with employment, unemployment, underemployment, average earnings, hours of work, wage structure, distribution of income, labour costs, consumer price indices, household income and expenditure, occupational injuries and disputes. This would facilitate justifiable comparisons between countries. One would not be comparing statistics that are collected on differential bases and therefore are not quite accurate.This convention is desperately needed to bring greater sanity to the industrial relations debate. It is one of the provisions of the accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions that we improve our statistics base so that we can address problems as they are instead of viewing them through rose tinted glasses and seeing them as various players in the industrial relations field would like them to be. We can now deal with reality, not illusion. The reason Australia can now move to ratify this convention is that we meet most of the standards and in the only two areas in which we do not meet them, we have steps in train to do so.The most important convention of the two is the one that concerns occupational injuries and diseases. As I said, there are steps in train to enable us to meet the standards of the convention on the statistics on labour costs. However, it is important to make the point that given the primacy of industrial relations and industrial disputes in the political debate in this country, there is nothing wrong with the provisions we have set aside ourselves as a nation for collecting statistics on industrial disputes. But we have absolutely no statistical base anywhere at all-nor have we ever had one-on the level of industrial accidents, injuries and disease. All the surveys that have ever been conducted show that losses to production in industry are between two and a half and three and a half times more as a result of injury, accident and disease than as a result of industrial disputes. It just turns out that industrial disputes seem more enticing as a political argument in public debate. Because that has been the case with conservative governments over the years, we have not attended to the need to get a statistical body of information together about accidents which are more damaging to our national output.This Government has moved in that direction with its occupational health and safety legislation; over time it will be able to meet the criteria set out in the proposed convention and it will be able to ratify the whole convention by adjusting its collection of statistics through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. When employers in this country bleat about the cost of workers compensation claims, it should be remembered that they talk about reducing the cost of workers compensation by reducing benefits, not by collecting the statistics to attack the problem and resolve the high human and financial cost to industry.

debateinfo: INTERNATIONAL LABOUR CONFERENCE
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GILES
content: —Among the documents in this particular group I wish to address those that deal with the collection of labour statistics-convention 160 and its accompanying recommendations, convention 170 of the International Labour Organisation. I was gratified to read in the accompanying statement by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that the standards and goals set in Australia for collecting statistics in the area of labour are equal to or better than most of those embodied in the Convention and in the more detailed Recommendation and that where we currently do not fully meet the obligations of articles 11 and 14 we will certainly move to do so in the near future.The lack of comprehensive and reliable statistics of an international standard was brought home very closely to members of the Australian delegation which represented Australia at the United Nations Conference at the end of the Decade for Women in 1985. Strenuous efforts had been made by the United Nations to review and appraise the achievements of the United Nations Decade for Women. The information that had been finally collated was interesting and in some cases indicative, but in very many cases it was not particularly reliable. Of the 160-odd nations that are members of the United Nations, only about 108 were in a position to provide up to date statistics, not only in relation to employment matters, but also across a whole range of social and economic determinators. It was quite obvious, as we tried very hard to assess what had been achieved during the Decade for Women, that in many cases the data simply was not available. In the document that issued from that conference a number of references were made to the paucity and inadequacy of statistics. In paragraph 28 of `Forward looking strategies, the title of the document that was adopted by consensus at that conference, it says:According to ILO estimates and projections--Not firm statistics, I point out--women constitute 35 per cent of the worlds labour force, and this figure is likely to increase steadily to the year 2000. Unless profound and extensive changes are made, the type of work available to the majority of women, as well as the rewards, will continue to be low. Womens employment is likely to be concentrated in areas requiring fewer skills and lower wages and minimum job security. While womens total input of labour in the formal and informal sector will surpass that of men by the year 2000, they will receive an unequal share of the worlds assets and income. According to recent estimates, it seems that women have sole responsibility for the economic support of a large number of the worlds children, approximately one third and higher in some countries, and the numbers seem to be rising.Out of the same conference came another reference to the lack of information about the work that women do and the value of that work. Paragraph 120 reads:The remunerated and, in particular, the unremunerated contributions of women to all aspects and sectors of development should be recognised, and appropriate efforts should be made to measure and reflect these contributions in national accounts and economic statistics.It is a source of considerable satisfaction to those of us who were on that delegation to note that the Australian Government has given instructions to the Australian Bureau of Statistics to include in a time series in 1988 a survey of domestic production in Australia and the value of that domestic production to the economy, thereby taking up the suggestion that contributions within households should be recognised within national accounting.
debateinfo: INTERNATIONAL LABOUR CONFERENCE
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator CROWLEY
content: —I rise to speak to the International Labour Conference papers too, although I must confess that a certain confusion about when papers are or are not coming on means that my preparation is less than comprehensive. I apologise to the Senate for that. I am very pleased to endorse strongly the remarks of my two colleagues Senator Cook and Senator Giles. I wish to pick up some of the points made by Senator Cook, in particular those concerning the lack of adequate statistics. Australia may have adequate statistics as compared to other countries, but I think that would mean that nowhere in the world are the statistics adequate, particularly when it comes to accident and injury and the problems of defining accident and injury, let alone the basic data collection concerning those matters.I think it is a matter of considerable pride that this Government has established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. A very great part of the central work of that Commission concerns the importance and adequacy of data collection. In fact, we received in our offices earlier this year a proposed outline of guidelines for the adequacy and standards of data collection in this whole area. I forget the exact title of that booklet, but I think it is put out by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. It goes to the very point that what we need at this stage is some guidelines as to what we mean by accident and injury and, further to that, how statistics relating to those definitions, once in place, can be collated and collected. It is certainly true that at the moment in Australia our statistics, albeit according to this report not unlike those collected in other countries, are worthy of the title `woeful.The other important point highlighted by Senator Cook was the issue of how many working days are lost in this country due to accident and injury as compared to industrial disputes. In the late years of the Fraser Government Mr Macphee was on record as saying that the difference was a factor of four; that is, four times more days were lost due to accident and injury than were lost due to industrial disputes. That was in the heady days of very high industrial disputation under the previous Government. I hope that the number of days lost due to accident and injury has fallen as well as the number lost due to industrial disputes, but in fact that gap may be even wider if our accidents and injuries have maintained somewhat the same level as before, because the level of industrial disputation has fallen so dramatically under this Government.I refer honourable senators to the annual report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation, yet another report which was tabled in this place but which, due to time constraints, was not spoken to. It is certainly one of the reports to which I had wanted to speak. On page 26 of that report, under the heading `Collection of compensation statistics, it is stated:Unfortunately, the statistics collected annually from departments and other bodies falling within the jurisdiction of the Act-that is, the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971-are not comprehensive. More detailed information is required to enable analysis of patterns of compensation expenditure. In coming months a statistical policy will be established that defines the statistics the Commissioner will collect and the purpose of these collections.This report, in this paragraph and others, goes to the very point raised by Senator Cook concerning the inadequacy of statistics and the importance and significance of our falling into line with the International Labour Organisation Convention so as to try to increase our statistics and data collection. One other matter that I point out concerning employees compensation relates to the dramatic increase in compensation payouts-from $21m to $156m between 1975 and 1985-as compared to a less than 100 per cent increase in the number of accidents. We do not have the statistics to enable us to understand why those figures are increasing so dramatically. We need them. I am delighted to endorse this report, which looks at Australias place in the world on this very important issue.Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I move:That the Senate take note of the paper.The 1985 annual report of the Western Australian Local Government Grants Commission comes before us at a time when local government funding legislation is very much in the air. On 21 May the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, Mr Bill Hassell, received some publicity on this topic under the newspaper heading `Big rise in council rates predicted. By the time the last edition of the West Australian had been printed, the story had worked its way from page one to page three. The point Mr Hassell was making was that Western Australian councils are in future to get a slightly smaller proportion of the national untied funds because that allocation is now moving to a per capita basis. The previous system disadvantaged South Australia and Victoria. The amount involved, while in the hundreds of thousands, is really nothing compared to the $2 1/2m which Western Australian councils lost last year because of the mini-Budget when the Liberals decided to assist the Hawke Government in pulling the plug on an election commitment.Honourable senators will recall that both Labor and Liberal policy in this area is that local government should receive 2 per cent of personal income tax collections by the Commonwealth Government. That was enshrined in the legislation until 28 May last year when the combination of Opposition and Government ranks saw it reduced to a 2 per cent increase in real terms. The difference turned out to be about $28m across the whole of Australia. The Lib-labs, that not so unusual combination of senators, sent a signal to the Self National inquiry into Local Government Finance that 2 per cent of personal income tax, or even some other proportion of a Commonwealth revenue or expenditure base, was politically impossible for the future. It was an unfortunate undermining of the work of the Inquiry, and was a view supported by all the local government associations and State Ministers for local government.I just wonder whether Mr Hassell was as strong a defender of local government last May as he paraded himself to be last month. If more Liberals had put the case for local government to their Federal parliamentarians in May 1985 the Western Australian Local Government Grants Commission, whose report we are discussing, would have had much more money to distribute. That in turn could have meant that over 100 extra people could be very gainfully employed in the areas of great need, because it would have been in these areas that the extra funds were distributed.There are some refreshing features in the eighth report of the Grants Commission. The State Government has increased local government representation on the Commission by substituting a nominee of the Country Urban Councils Association in place of a Treasury representative. An additional research position was created, taking the Commissions research and secretariat staff to four. This is indeed a modest overhead to ensure the fair distribution of funds and that contact is made directly with councils as the Local Government Grants Commission visits different parts of the State. In fact, the Commission has a four-year program for visiting all councils. It has also established a special hearing mechanism to give councils, which believe that their disabilities have not been properly recognised, an opportunity to make their case publicly. This is a very important part of the process. Quite often through this process it will turn out that councils get a better understanding of what information they need to provide to the Commission. Once councils understand roughly what goes into the calculations and how best they can put their submissions together, they will be happier with the processes and the outcomes.I notice also that the Western Australian Local Government Grants Commission refers to the need to improve the collection of financial and other statistics. It mentions that a standardised local government accounting system will improve the quality of information from 1985-86. That is an area in which Federal resources can be applied very effectively through both the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Office of Local Government. As local government moves more and more into the human services area, it will be essential to get a quantitative idea of the needs.

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —I understand that the honourable senators question was: Why are the indexation arrangements for housing reviewed only every ten years? The proposal to index the market rental value of housing provided to employees is designed to make administration of this aspect of the fringe benefits tax easier for employers. As with the existing remote area housing provisions of the income tax law, it avoids the necessity of establishing a fresh market value every year. At the same time, it is necessary to bring the index value into line on a regular basis with the actual market rental value. These factors were balanced when determining the ten-year review period. I think that was the sum total of the honourable senators question.

I will read it out to honourable senators. The letter is addressed to Senator Chipp and says:At Canowindra on 31 May 1986 I received representations suggesting that the draft Fringe Benefits Tax legislation as it applies to rental accommodation for farm employees would impact heavily on rural producers. In response to these claims I undertook to secure an assessment of the likely impact of this aspect of the tax.Advice received today confirms that account has been taken in the draft legislation of important concerns of rural producers. The review now underway is considering whether there is any valid basis for further flexibility in the manner in which the proposed tax is to be administered.There is no question of the Government moving to defer adoption of the draft legislation now before the Senate.The letter is signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What that means is that the Government intends to continue with the legislation as it is. Of course, there is a review. We do not put down pieces of legislation as though they are etched in stone and will never be altered. If there were any untoward effects we would take that into account. The problem with this whole area of fringe benefit tax on farm employers can be best seen by some of the nonsense that has been written and the inflammatory material that has been distributed. I noticed that the New South Wales Livestock and Grain Producers Association put out a statement saying that there are 56,770 farms with an average of one employee. That means there is a whole swag of them with half an employee, a third of an employee and a fifth of an employee because many farms have two, three, four and five employees. If a statement is started off with mathematical nonsenses like that in it, it is no wonder that the further down one goes in the statement the sillier it gets.

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —This takes us back to the argument we had last night. It is a very difficult question which was not answered by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) last night. I hear what the Minister for Community Services said about the relationship between an employer and an employee and so on, but clause 148 states:A reference in this Act to the provision of a benefit to a person in respect of the employment of an employee is a reference to the provision of such a benefit-Then there is a string of exceptions. Exception (f) states:whether or not the benefit is provided or used, or required to be provided or used, in connection with that employment;Exception (a) states:whether or not the benefit is also provided in respect of, by reason of, by virtue of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, any other matter or thing;In other words, it seems that the law is so drawn as to override the point that the Minister is making about the establishment of a relationship between employer and employee. It is clause 148 which is the crux of our problem. I cannot see how the Minister can offer us such solace as he is trying to do by saying that it does not cover the situation which has been outlined.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —Clause 148 (1) reads:A reference in this Act to the provision of a benefit to a person in respect of the employment of an employee . . .That is the base reference point. That has to be established. It cannot be watered down by the rest of the paragraphs. If he is in that house, not because he is an employee but because he is a member of the household, he clearly is not covered by that clause.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Messner
content: —But it says `whether or not in relation to any other matter or thing. It appears to go running over the top of it.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

name: Senator Messner

debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —The paragraph states `whether or not the benefit is also provided in respect of something else. We have to pass the base condition at the start of the clause, that a benefit is provided in respect of the employment of an employee. In this case it is clear that the bedroom that a kid has lived in for 20 years is not suddenly provided on the basis that he is an employee on the farm. It is provided because he is the son of the farmer.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —The point is that the tax is payable where there is the connection between employment and the employee. Fair enough, one might say that that direct condition does not apply in respect of housing which is provided to the son. But there is a relationship of employment between the employer and the employee. So that condition is satisfied. However, the next paragraph goes on to say whether or not in relation to any other thing. In other words, any other factor is disregarded. So the fact that he has occupied that room as a member of the family for 20 years or whatever does not seem to have any bearing on the matter because the Commissioner of Taxation can determine that the relationship between the employer and the employee is the determining one and that tax will be payable as a result. That is the crux of the point that we are getting at.

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —Now we are getting down to the nitty-gritty. The fact is that the Minister resorts to name calling and carrying on in these circumstances without addressing the issue. debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —Clause 148 talks about the provision of benefits. The following very firm statement is made in the first two lines of the clause:A reference to this Act to the provision of a benefit to a person in respect of the employment of an employee . . .That is the absolute base; that is the first hurdle that one has to cross. Clearly a son living in a farmhouse that he has lived in all his life does not go anywhere near crossing that hurdle.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —With respect, it looks as though we have to go right through the whole thing again. The question of the current employer and the relationship with an employee is defined in clause 136. The clause defines the terms `current employer and `current employee. It refers to the Income Tax Assessment Act, the way in which a person gets a benefit and the way in which that benefit is taxed. The liability for tax is established by tracing through these provisions.Clause 148 does not in itself provide for the payment of the tax. It appears merely to define an employer and employee relationship. It then broadens that definition so that, in effect, the Commissioner is given an overriding power by determining the benefit in such a way as he can disregard or, in other circumstances apply, the factors relating to that relationship of employer and employee. This seems to me to be perfectly clear. I just cannot understand why the Minister cannot see that that is broadening the whole interpretation of that provision.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —If honourable senators opposite read the legislation, they will see that the aim of that provision, as is pointed out on page 151 of the explanatory notes, is not to broaden the scope. It is to ensure that it is not narrowed. The key words are still those in the first part of clause 148 (1). I do not know that I can add any more than Senator Walsh was able to say by way of explanation last night in an hours debate in this place. I think it is interesting that honourable members opposite are getting down to bits and pieces of this type. It is just beyond our comprehension-apparently it is beyond the comprehension of everyone except for a few people sitting in the chamber at the moment-what the problem is.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —I have to take exception to that remark because I am in receipt of a letter from the Law Council of Australia that makes that very point. If the Minister is giving us an undertaking that he will examine the matter further, take into account the feelings that we have demonstrated during the debate, and either confirm or deny in writing the Governments intentions at some later stage, we will sit down and wait for that response. However, the point is that this matter has been raised by people who interpret these things on a day to day basis. I cannot understand-it appears quite clear to me-why the Government cannot see that in fact this provision will have unintended effects.

content: —I just want to make one point. Numerous accountants have rung me up and made the same point about the wording `in respect of. They say that the wording is very poor but I will not elaborate on that. They suggest that the wording should be changed to read `in relation to secure or maintain the employment of an employee. They say that this would get over the problem that I think is concerning most of us. If this is not done, it becomes difficult to determine the interpretation that should be used in respect of children who becomes employees. The present wording leads to all sorts of inconsistencies. The following questions are examples of this: Did you give the use of the car to your son because he was your son or because he was your employee; did you give the use of the house to your son because he was your son or because he was your employee?

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —The honourable senator can broaden it all he likes. But we are talking about a specific case brought up here by Senator Crichton-Browne. We are talking about a young person living in the family house with his family. I am the last one in this place to say that the wording of legislation is always perfect. I am the last one to say that legislation does not have some untoward effect. I have seen enough of that in 12 years in this place. Senator Walsh last night and I today, on behalf of the Government, have asserted what the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasury and the Government believe is the proper interpretation of this legislation. There is, therefore, plenty of evidence in our statements in this place last night and today as to what we believe and what are our intentions. I have said that the Commissioner of Taxation intends it that way and I assert that on his behalf at the moment. If any difficulty or problems arise out of any of this legislation, it will be continuously reviewed. If the legislation has untoward effects, they will be corrected as they have always been in the past. Untoward effects of the type which would penalise individuals are always corrected very quickly. It is the fixing of untoward effects which allow people to evade and avoid taxes which have been delayed in this country, as we know.Perhaps this is a very good argument for something I have asserted for a long time; that at the start of every piece of legislation in this country there ought to be a clear and detailed statement of intent by the Parliament, as is done in the United States of America and other countries, so that when the legislation is interpreted later and people find areas of difficulty such as this, people can refer to that statement of intent. Unfortunately, we do not do that. I hope that we will do it at some time in the future.

name: Senator BJELKE-PETERSEN
content: —I have received a long telex from the Chairman of the Mackay Holiday Regional Council, who is concerned about the harmful effects of the tax on the accommodation industry where people have to live in to look after accommodation such as motels, caravan parks or cruise vessels. The gentleman who sent me the telex, Mr Trevor Atherton, said that the fringe benefits tax, calculated at 46c in the dollar, could amount to as much as $1,656 weekly, so employees in holiday flats and caravan parks will have problems. The people in the accommodation industry maintain that the effect of this extra tax will have to be passed on to their guests or they will have to reduce the standard of service. They feel, and I agree with them, that the accommodation industry seems to be a special case. Everybody knows about the hospitality industry, but they have asked me to raise with the Government the concerns of the accommodation industry.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —This matter has been raised before. The situation is that if employees are being provided with a permanent home in a caravan park or motel as part of their salary, they will be liable for the fringe benefits tax. The difference with cruise vessels, I think, is that the people will be living away from home. That is a living away from home situation and I suspect that they would not be liable for the tax. Of course, that non-cash income will now become taxable and that will mean that there will be small extra costs in the running of a business. When one thinks of the size of a motel and the number of rooms in it, I do not believe that the cost of the one place that is usually provided would lead to the 10 per cent increase in costs which Senator Newman has mentioned it would be likely to be.

name: Senator NEWMAN
content: —I cannot comment on that. But it had nothing to do with Tasmania. I want to raise now the question of organisations such as the Youth Hostels Association and the National Trust, which are not profit-making organisations. By the very nature of their work they require people to live on the premises as either wardens or caretakers. I am sure that the Government will have had representations from such bodies. I know that the Commissioner of Taxation was dead against their getting any assistance in this matter. Has the Government given it further consideration? Is the Government prepared either to exempt them from the fringe benefits tax on the basis that they are usually already tax free organisations in some form or another or, alternatively, to reimburse them by way of grants?
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —The situation is that people in those circumstances are still getting a benefit, no matter who is giving it. To exclude them, one would need more compelling reasons than Senator Newman has given. It is my experience-I am not saying it is universal-that, in the case of the National Trust, although the buildings may be valuable, considerable and even at times extensive, the accommodation provided for the warden, the caretaker or whoever is fortunate enough to get that accommodation is considerably smaller. The calculation in these circumstances, as is the case in regard to motels, would not concern the rental value of the whole place-a place such as Entally House. It would concern the rental value of the few rooms in which the people live.In the case of youth hostels, they frequently have very sparse accommodation. In fact, in the couple of youth hostels that I know of, the people who look after them are not provided with accommodation; they live nearby in their own homes. The alternative for the organisations is to charge rent or to pay people an allowance for the accommodation that is provided. I am not sure what is the tax status of the National Trust, but it is probably getting some benefit in that regard. I think it is a tax exempt body, so it is probably getting a benefit in that way. I think it is unreasonable to single out the National Trust, of all organisations, as being an organisation which should be excluded. I think Senator Walsh answered that question last night. The Commissioner of Taxation and the Government do not intend, on the evidence given to us, to make the exemption that Senator Newman seeks.

That is the basis on which I read the legislation. I am sorry if I am wrong.

name: Senator MESSNER
content: —The question that arises in relation to this part of the Bill is two-fold: First there is the question of airline transport fringe benefits. I noticed recently that the group representing former airline employees on this matter had put forward an alternative suggestion to the Government about the way in which the tax might be calculated in order to save the airlines a considerable amount of administrative and clerical detailed work which, of course, is quite costly. I believe that the suggestion was that there should be a flat amount of $300 per person affected by this tax, payable to the Government directly without any further substantiation of the detail behind it. I wonder whether the Government has considered that because it appears to me to be a step in the right direction in terms of a sensible compromise in that the airlines would be saved from very considerable expense which would only add to community costs associated with this matter. Can the Minister give us some idea about the Governments attitude to that?While I am on my feet I mention the second point that concerns me in this general area. It falls under the heading of `board and it concerns the effects upon contractors who are operating in remote areas and working according to firm tender prices. They provide accommodation benefits for their employees which would be subject to the fringe benefit tax. In many cases there are no nearby towns in which those employees can live and in those circumstances the tax would be payable by the contractor who, of course, is unable to renegotiate the price of that contract with the principal. The point is that this is an extra cost which is not recoverable by the contractor, and in that sense it represents a retrospective impost upon him. As such it puts him in a weaker position in terms of his employment capacity. Has the Government considered providing a means by which people in those circumstances can be relieved of the very severe burden that will obviously fall upon them because it must be recognised that the costs of providing services of the kind of which we are speaking in the most remote areas of the country are very high indeed.

content: —I also wish to speak about airline transport fringe benefits. It might be quite interesting for the Senate if I quoted from part of a speech that was made in the House of Representatives on 8 May. The speaker was Mr Mountford, the honourable member for Banks, and he was referring to the airline industrys fringe benefits. He said:The previous speaker said that airline employees would be affected. That, of course, is not the case. When first announced, airline employees justifiably feared the effects on their very generous travel concessions. I received many representations from airline employees within my electorate. Following talks with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the airline industry unions, the airlines have agreed to pay the full cost of the tax without threatening the existing travel concessions. This is yet another example of consensus in action.I draw the attention of the Senate to that last line: `This is yet another example of consensus in action. If ever there was a case of holding the gun at the employers head, those negotiations must have been it. Of course many employers will look at this legislation with a view to seeing which fringe benefits they can withdraw, but the airlines have been compelled to continue to provide these fringe benefits and therefore pay the cost of the tax. That does not mean that the cost to the airlines will go away. It means that although the employees will still get their concessions, the airlines will still pay and guess who will pay the bill? Ansett Airlines of Australia estimates that these agreed rates of fringe benefits tax on the travel concessions of its employees alone-just the travel concessions-will be in the region of $2m to $4m. How will the Government prevent this flowing on to the airline costs of the average Australian traveller?

name: Senator PETER BAUME
content: —Clause 47 defines certain exemptions. We are seeking some advice regarding the exemptions in relation to work-based child care. I remind the Committee that page 35 of the Governments statement entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System states:However, the provision of in-house child care facilities for the dependants of employees will not be taxed.I have raised this matter with the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) before. The Opposition seeks to know whether or not adequate provision is made for exempt benefits in relation to work-based child care. I will take the Minister through our concern. If one turns to clause 47 (2) (b), at the top of page 39 of the Bill, there are some words relating to the provision of child care in a child care facility if that facility is located on the premises of the employer. On page 41, there is an amendment which the Government put in in the House of Representatives, which I acknowledge has helped because I think it provides in a very appropriate way an exemption for certain other kinds of provision of child care.There is only one remaining problem. I will explain it to the Minister in this way: A company in central Sydney owns a large building. It cannot establish a child care facility on those premises and have it registered but it can do so 200 yards away. I know of a company that was faced with that possibility. Reading clause 47 (2) (b) on page 39, as it has been drafted, child care provided in that facility which may not be a subsidised facility but is otherwise a work-based child care centre may not be an exempt benefit. I ask the Minister to explain to us what happens to people who are attempting to provide work-based child care in accordance with the spirit of what the Government is seeking to exempt. If they have to provide that facility in premises adjacent to or slightly away from their premises in order to meet the State licensing requirements, where will they be left in relation to the benefit exemption and how does that fit in with the provision of the Bill?

name: Senator GRIMES

I think that is clear from the legislation. I cannot read anything in the legislation that that is not clear. It is certainly the intent of the legislation.

name: Senator CRICHTON-BROWNE
content: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Community Services, by way of observation rather than asking a question, to the distinction between the treatment of a mining company which chooses to fly its employees in and out of a site and a mining company which provides housing. I am obviously referring to mines which come under the remote area definition. It seems to me that the mining company that provides housing whether it is on-sold or not, notwithstanding the discount which some might describe as generous and others as modest, would be considerably disadvantaged compared with the company that flies its employees in and out. That company would receive the full tax deduction applying to the cost, whereas the company providing accommodation would ultimately be left with a residual amount of fringe benefits taxation.What I find most disturbing about the proposal is that more and more mining projects such as the Argyle diamond prospect in the Kimberleys of Western Australia-where there is no decentralisation, no mining town, no infrastructure and where there are no suitable roads and no desirable attractions for the area to be opened up generally-will fly their employees in, provide them with very sparse accommodation and fly them back out again. As I said, there will not be the infrastructure which can attract people, as is the case with Mount Newman, Dampier, Karratha, Paraburdoo and Pannawonica. One can name a whole range of mining towns which have been built around mineral deposits. It seems to me that as a result of the provisions of this legislation mining companies will be encouraged, because of the benefits so accruing, to provide simple accommodation on site and to fly employees in and out. In my view, such a situation would begin to debase the very character of society and very much destroys the incentive to have a decentralised community.

It was particularly put into the legislation to cover those cases where we have joint projects between the Commonwealth and private companies-a development that we are trying to encourage. They are specifically exempted. On page 41 of the legislation sub-clause (8) of clause 47 states:Where-. . . .the employer of the employee, or an associate of the employer, made a contribution, under the scheme administered by the Commonwealth and known as the Childrens Services Program, to obtain that priority of access;That sub-clause was put into the legislation by the House of Representatives.

content: —I apologise to the Minister for not being completely au fait but it is due to circumstances beyond my control. If an employer provides an employee with an amount of money or, alternatively, pays somebody else to do the child caring in the employees home, would that be regarded as a fringe benefit? Let us take the latter example. If the employer paid somebody to look after the employees kids in the home of the employee, would that be regarded as a fringe benefit and would that be exempt under this legislation?

name: Senator Harradine

That has not only philosophical problems for some of us but also very big budgetary problems-$500m to $600m worth of budgetary problems for whoever is in government.Clause agreed to.Clauses 48 to 57-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.Proposed new clause 57a (Provision of benefits to employees of public benevolent institutions to be exempt).

name: Senator PETER BAUME
content: —I move:(2) Page 46, after clause 57, insert the following new clause:`Provision of benefits to employees of public benevolent institutions to be exempt`57a. Where a public benevolent institution provides a benefit to an employee of the institution, the benefit is an exempt benefit..From the moment that the fringe benefits tax was announced it became clear that its effect would fall upon charities. I am using the word `charities in the sense that most of us understand that word-the great institutions that care for other Australians. It is quite clear that they would be caught by this Bill, that the application of the fringe benefits tax would mean that they would be paying tax where they pay no tax now and that that tax would have to be paid from moneys that would otherwise go to doing the charitable work for which they are responsible.Honourable senators have raised this matter a number of times over the last few months. We raised this matter with Senator Walsh in his ministerial capacity and we received answers which indicated that he had no sympathy for and little understanding of the effect which this application of the fringe benefits tax would have upon the great charities of Australia.

name: Senator PETER BAUME
content: —I did expect Senator Walsh to be sympathetic to charities and I was very disappointed with the answers we got when he sought to belittle charities and the work that they did and he gave no indication at all that he would move to ease this impost or to ease their load. The Opposition parties announced early, following party and shadow Cabinet consideration, that we would move to try to exempt charities from the effect of this impost. We issued Press releases at the time and we have issued some subsequently. I must say that the Australian Democrats have also had a concern about the effect of this tax on charities and I understand that they have negotiated with the Government on their own. We determined that we would move an appropriate amendment. We hoped that, when the Bill was finally drafted and introduced, the Government, notwithstanding Senator Walshs macho rhetoric, would have actually inserted some exemption for charities, but there was none. As far as the Australian Labor Party and the Government were concerned, the charities were to be taxed for any fringe benefits that they offered. Clearly, some of those fringe benefits were absolutely unavoidable. Others may not have been but many of them were unavoidable. It seems to us that all that would happen was that the work of the great charities of Australia-the Sydney City Mission, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Salvation Army-would be adversely affected, so the Opposition prepared an amendment.I wish to indicate that Senator Haines has pointed out to me, with accuracy, that my understanding of the word `charity and the legal meaning of the word are quite different. Let me acknowledge that it has been possible, working with the Australian Democrats, to develop a form of words which talk about the provision of benefits to employees of public benevolent institutions. The words `public benevolent institutions have their own meaning in law but they cover the great charities of Australia. If this amendment is picked up it will ensure that, where these public benevolent institutions provide a benefit to an employee, that benefit is exempt.

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator HAINES
content: —I would like to go into this particular amendment in a little more detail. As Senator Peter Baume mentioned, this has been a cause for concern for most of us ever since the fringe benefits tax legislation was brought down. Certainly at the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled conference in Brisbane last year I made comments then about the unworkability of the Governments proposal to tax fringe benefits provided by charities and then to try to make up for this by some sort of compensatory grant. It seemed to me that that was the most complex and cumbersome way that the Government could have gone about it. It seemed to us to be a much simpler method simply to exempt charitable organisations.We had a number of discussions with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on this matter last year and again earlier this year. In discussions with Senator Peter Baume we settled on a definition of charitable organisations that appears with respect to section 23 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. To the lay person reading section 23 (e) and seeing the mention of charities and charitable organisations it would appear as if that was a perfectly appropriate lynchpin on which to hang an amendment to exempt those particular charitable organisations from this fringe benefits tax. Unfortunately, as Senator Peter Baume said, we entirely overlooked the tortuous minds of some members of the legal profession and some of the issues that from time to time over the years they have picked up and classified as being related to charitable organisations. In fact, the word `charitable has a technical legal meaning which is completely different from the meaning that most people in the general public and I suggest most honourable senators have. Various Privy Council decisions and other legal decisions have led to some fairly extraordinary cases being picked up as charitable organisations which we in this place would not wish to be classified as such. Indeed, the Statute of Elizabeth is taken in by the legal profession and hence by the courts as defining what the charitable institutions are. These include some fairly extraordinary ones.

name: Senator HAINES
content: —I do not need any help, Senator Puplick. It continues:supportation, aid, and help of young tradesmen, handicraftsmen, and persons decayed--this may or may not apply to some people in this chamber or in another place--the relief or redemption of prisoners or captives; the aid or ease of any poor inhabitants concerning payment of fifteens;--whatever that may be--setting out of soldiers, and other taxes.Indeed, what has occurred as a result of this is that everything from vegetarian societies to homes for lost dogs has been classified by the courts as a charitable organisation along with, of course, the things that we would more normally classify as charitable organisations such as the Royal Blind Society and so on. Included, I might add, in this list of extraordinary things which are qualified as charitable organisations by the courts has been the reduction of the national debt. I do not know exactly how the Government could use that to its own deficit benefit, but maybe it could well do so. Having been met with that extraordinary list of things that were likely to be suddenly exempt from fringe benefits tax if the original proposal classifying charitable organisations under section 23 (e) were taken up, we then went looking amongst the murky depths of legal history for something that defines public benevolent institutions. In fact, an organisation is legally defined as a public benevolent institution if it satisfies the following tests:its object is the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness;it is carried on without purpose of private gain for particular persons;it is established for the benefit of a section or class of the public; andrelief is available without discrimination to every member of that section of the public which the organisation aims to benefit.Quite clearly that definition of what is legally known as a public benevolent institution is the word that we, in this place, and most people in the community would regard as applying to what we would normally call a charitable organisation. So people who have been concerned, for example, that the Church of England has been exempt through the religious exemption, but the Brotherhood of St Laurence has not, will now be satisfied that picking up public benevolent institutions and exempting them will mean the Brotherhood of St Laurence, St Vincent de Paul, ACROD and the Blind Society of New South Wales and the Sydney City Mission provide a service.
