Speaker: N/A

name: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT
content: —Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate on the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986? There being no objection, it is so ordered.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986 [COGNATE BILL: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986]
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —The Senate is debating cognately the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986. It is my pleasure to lead on behalf of the Opposition on these two pieces of legislation, and to indicate that the Opposition will be supporting both of these pieces of legislation, although we have a number of matters to raise by way of query with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I indicate that we have had some discussion with the Australian Democrats and when we come to the Committee stage we are likely to be supporting some of the Democrat amendments which I understand have also been discussed with the Government.These two Bills are part of an overall package which may be considered to have been developed over the last few years in terms of providing a structure for financial support for research and development to take place within Australia. Apart from these two pieces of legislation which are before us, one needs to bear in mind that they are supported by a number of other initiatives including the successful development over the last couple of years of the management and investment companies system and the development of the second boards, whereby a number of companies, particularly those in the high tech and venture capital area, have been able to get themselves listed on Australian stock exchanges and to raise funds for research and development under that particular method.As I said, the two Bills before us, which are measures to support industrial research and development by the provision of direct government financial assistance, are assisted by the MICs and the second boards. It is very encouraging to note in the 1984-85 annual report of the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board that the number of eligible business entities, as far as that operation is concerned, rose in recent years from one to 36. It should also be said that the scheme, which underlies the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill, for the provision of a 150 per cent tax concession for eligible research and development work undertaken, was one which has bipartisan support. It was, in fact, provided as part of the policy of the Liberal and National parties going into the last election that we would give a 50 per cent tax incentive over and above eligible expenditure which is exactly the same as the Governments provision for the 150 per cent subsidy being provided here.It is also important, when we are looking at research and development in its overall sense, to understand that it cannot simply be provided by measures of financial assistance. There is a whole raft of areas, particularly those which come within the portfolio of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce which also need to be borne in mind. I mention just a couple of these. The first is the development of an effective offsets policy. The Minister has been very diligent in attempting to develop a more comprehensive and intelligent approach to offsets policy, but there is still a degree of reluctance within the Australian Government to support Australian industry by a more positive buying Australian campaign. There is, for instance, a letter in the 30 May edition of Business Review Weekly from David Reid, headed `R and D misses out which makes the point that Telecom Australia is purchasing about $1m worth of local area network equipment, but that it is purchasing it from overseas. There was an article in the journal Australian Society in October 1985 under the heading `Government wont buy Australian in which it said that the Government, which is responsible for purchases of approximately 40 per cent of the material purchased within the information technology market nevertheless continues to pursue a policy of not positively buying Australian and making a contribution in that regard.For instance, we have a Bill on the Notice Paper, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. One of the things that that Bill attempts to do is to increase the tariff on the importation of optical fibres from the minimum 2 per cent which it stands at at the moment, up to a 20 per cent figure. We cannot see how, in terms of the development of an integrated approach to support Australian research and development, all of these policies are properly co-ordinated.One of the things which this legislation will do will be to go some way to redressing the imbalance of expenditure undertaken by the Labor Government-both this Government and the previous Labor Government-which has not been good news for science. I look, for instance, in the Budget papers. Going back to the 1981 Budget, if one looks at the Department of Science, at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, or at the Antarctic Division-the three areas which I have extracted-one can see that in the period of Liberal administrations there were substantial increases in the budgetary allocations, and that in the period of Labor administrations there have been substantial real decreases. My colleague the shadow Minister for Science, Senator Archer, in terms of an analysis of the three years of funding provided to research and development in Australia by the Labor Party, has produced a balance sheet which shows the extent to which science and technology have not fared as well under this administration as might have otherwise been the case. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the figures and statements to which I have just referred.Leave granted.The documents read as follows-SENATOR BRIAN R. ARCHERSENATOR FOR TASMANIAA MAJOR STATEMENT FROM THE SHADOW MINISTER FOR SCIENCELABORS THREE YEAR SCIENCE REPORT CARD-A FAILUREShadow Minister for ScienceShadow Special Minister of StateOpposition Spokesman on Tasmanian AffairsThe Federal Labor Government has been a disaster for the scientific development of Australia. Over the last three years, science has consistently been accorded an extremely low priority resulting in a crisis of confidence within the scientific community and an ever increasing drain of our best scientists and innovators to overseas commercial and research institutions.Clearly the Labor Government has failed to understand the link between scientific and technological advance and long-term economic development.The Labor Governments catalogue of anti-science decisions includes:Allowed Government funding of medical research to become the second lowest in the western world (after Italy) while hundreds of millions of dollars are wasted on the ALPs ideological binge-Medicare. As a result, Australias immense technical talent in the area of bio-technology and the vast commercial potential offered in this area will be wasted.Broken its promise to increase expenditure on scientific research in Antarctica by 300 per cent in its first three years.Drastically reduced the funding of Australias premier scientific and industrial organisation CSIRO despite promises to the contrary.Has pursued an incoherent policy towards the CSIRO often penalising those divisions of most benefit to the economy, e.g. the cuts to the Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures may cost Australia millions in lost export earnings.Has failed to provide any response to the ASTEC Inquiry into the future direction of the CSIRO, including the recommendations for greater flexibility in employment practices.Ditched the National Technology Strategy casting aside two and a half years of preparation and almost 250 submissions from industry, government and community groups. The strategy, which was to provide a detailed blueprint for government technology policy, now represents only a vague framework for policy.Refused a request from N.A.S.A. to provide night-time landing facilities for N.A.S.A.s Kuiper Airborne Observatory which was to study Halleys Comet utilising Australias technical and geographic advantage. As a result, Australias credibility as the leading technologically developed nation in the southern hemisphere has been severely damaged and NASA has been forced to relocate its experiment to New Zealand.May prohibit Australian scientists, companies, and research institutions from participating in a range of commercial and technological opportunities offered by co-operation with the USA on research relating to the Strategic Defence Initiative.Presided over the disastrous failure of the `Sunrise Industries Scheme ignoring the potential of applying new technologies to existing enterprises. On November 25 1985, the Secretary of the Department of Science admitted-`While sunrise industries had a gee-whizz appeal to a large number of people in the populace, the hard-headed businessmen saw they werent the way to go. I think he (Minister Barry Jones) has come to realise that but unfortunately its too late.Has placed in serious doubt, the future of the Australian Research Grants Scheme. The A.R.G.S has been targeted by the Expenditure Review Committee which recommends a halving of its funding. This is in direct contrast to Labors promise in March 1983, that it would increase ARGS funds by 10 per cent more than inflation in its first three years. That promise has been utterly broken.Eliminated commencement grants to new and small businesses initiating technology-based research as well as abolishing public interest grants which produced such international breakthroughs as the bionic ear and the new malaria vaccine.Excluded individuals, new and small businesses investing in industrial research and development from benefiting from the 150 per cent tax incentive scheme.Bungled the attraction of sponsorship for the proposed Bicentennial National Science Centre necessitating an injection of an extra $10m of government funds to underwrite the project.Failed to respond to the Industrial Property Advisory Committee inquiry into the Australian Patents, Trademarks and Designs Office completed in mid 1984.Failed to respond to the Madigan Committee report `A Space Policy for Australia published almost ten months ago.Presided over the continued deterioration of basic weather services, a situation which led forecasters to issue disclaimers with their forecasts. Labor has failed to fund the Bureau of Meteorologys re-equipment programme at a level recommended at ASTEC.Has failed to promote private sector investment in research and development by failing to contract out its strategic research and development to industry. The Australian Government contracts out only 2% of its R&D expenditure whilst the U.S.A. and Japan contract out almost 50% of their expenditure to industry.Split the portfolios of Science and Technology setting adrift two inextricably related functions of government innovation policy.Signalled the introduction of a capital gains tax at marginal and company income tax rates, thus destabilising the high risk/high return delicate balance for new and entrepreneurial high-technology companies and discouraging the flow of investment funds to high risk activities.The Hawke Labor Government must be judged by its record-as it has been demonstrated-and it stands condemned.Australias relative position in the scientific world has been falling rapidly, and as the entire future economic progress of the nation is so inextricably tied to our innovativeness, initiative and scientific development, the actions of the Government have already prejudiced our future.As the Liberal and National Parties continue to develop their Science and Technology policies this serious state of affairs will be taken into account.For further information and interviews: Senator Brian Archer (004) 315111 (004) 451164 A.H.Further information: Brendan Pearson (062) 726185.April 4, 1986. Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —This is not something new for the Labor Party. If one looks at an article by K. C. Westfold in the August-September 1985 journal Search, which is the journal of Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science, under the heading `Research funding-the Whitlam Debacle it states:In the last days of the Whitlam Government it brought down a budget in which the 1976 allocation for the ARGC was reduced by 66 per cent and that for the NH&MRC by 42 per cent, notwithstanding an election commitment ` . . . to expand research work in the Universities. The impact of those cuts on the research community and its limited success in recovering the situation are recalled, in the context of the most recent ARGS allocation.One can look for instance at the very glossy publication-goodness knows how much it would have cost-entitled `Living by Our Wits, a selection of speeches by the Honourable Barry O. Jones Minister for Science in which we are treated to the collective thoughts of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) on this matter. If one looks for instance at the sort of ideological underpinning of science policy as it has been developed by this Government in his essay `New Paradigms for Old it states:The major influences on my thinking in writing Sleepers--that is an abbreviated form of Mr Joness magnum opus on the question-were Karl Marx, especially in his Grundrisse, the three dedicatees, Lewis Mumford, author of The Myth of the Machine and The pentagon of Power, Simon Nora, the French civil servant who prepared the major report Linformatisation de la societe . . . Hugh Stretton of Adelaide University, author of Capitalism, Socialism and the Environment, the Japanese economist Yoneji Masuda, and Professor Joseph Weizenbaum of MIT, author of Computer Power and Human Reason.That might all be very interesting as far as the intellectual development of the Minister for Science is concerned, but the record of the Minister in providing funding for research and development is better understood if one looks at the annual report of the Australian research grants scheme. The 1984 report stated:The funds available to the Committee were appreciably less than the amount required to maintain an adequate level of support under the Scheme and limited its capacity to provide proper support for its projects . . .The 1985 report stated:This increase was grossly insufficient to support the number of worthy projects that the Committee considered should be funded.Fortunately, a large part of Australias research and development policy has now passed into the control of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. There has been an appreciable increase in the significance given to the funding of research and development since Senator Button took this into his portfolio.We have two Bills before us this evening: The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986, the purpose of which is to provide a 150 per cent tax concession for eligible expenditure in research and development, and the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986. The first Bill is primarily a Bill which will benefit companies whose expenditure on research and development is $50,000 or more. It is true that companies which spend $20,000 will get a phased-in tax concession between $20,000 and $50,000 which will be of benefit to them. If they spend less than $20,000 by contracting out the expenditure to an approved research institution, they will benefit fully from the 150 per cent taxation concession. This scheme was criticised for not providing sufficient incentive and assistance for small and start up research and development companies. The Industry Research and Development Bill, however, picks up the area of small companies and innovative new companies and provides them with financial assistance along reasonably similar but not identical lines.As I have said, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill provides for financial assistance to companies which undertake approved expenditure. That expenditure is to be judged in a number of ways. The legislation defines research and development activities as those which include the systematic investigative or experimental activities that are carried on in Australia or in an external Territory; those which involve innovation or technical risk and are carried on for the purpose of acquiring new knowledge, whether or not that knowledge will have a specific practical application; or those which create new or improved materials, products, devices, processes or services; and those which are for certain other related activities. I think it is important to understand that this Bill provides some assistance for developmental activities. It allows the company concerned to contract its work to approved institutions. Those institutions are as approved under section 73a of the Income Tax Assessment Act. They include the CSIRO, a large number of government departments, educational institutions, overseas institutions, museums and certain other general research activities. debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I thank the Senate. Proposed new section 73B (2) provides certain exclusions for expenditure. It provides that things such as market research, quality control, petroleum or natural gas prospecting, the making of cosmetic modifications to products, management studies, social science, arts or humanities research and the development of computer software other than for the purposes of sale, rent, licence, hire or lease or the making of donations are not to be taken as being eligible expenditure under the Act.I would be grateful if the Minister would address himself to a number of questions I wish to raise. I refer firstly to the question of patenting. As I understand it, this Bill will provide that a patent which is taken out in the course of a research and development activity in order to lead on to the next step of actual research and development is to be an allowable expenditure under the Act. However, the patent which is taken out at the end of the research and development phase, and prior to the moving into the commercial exploitation phase, is not to be taken as an allowable expenditure under the terms of the principal Act. I would be grateful, firstly, if the Minister would confirm whether my understanding is correct in terms of expenditure being allowable in respect of a mid-way patent which leads to further development but being excluded in respect of the final patent which leads on to development. If that is a correct understanding, will the Minister tell me why the Government has decided that the first patent should be an allowable expenditure and the final patent should not be?The other point which I make is that the board which will be established under the Industry Research and Development Bill is going to have certain powers. Those powers include advising the Commissioner of Taxation as to whether in fact an expenditure should be regarded as an expenditure which falls within the definitions provided in the principal Act. It is interesting to note that clause 35 of the legislation provides that once the board has given that advice to the Commissioner, the Commissioner is in fact bound to accept that advice and therefore does not have a separate and independent discretion as far as that is concerned. I think it is interesting that there are very few other examples where the Commissioners personal or independent power of discretion is taken away. Only two instances have been drawn to my attention-one in relation to assistance to the film industry in Division 10ba of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and the other in relation to the certification of manning levels of coastal ships which is determined by the Department of Transport under what I think is section 57am of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Nevertheless the board has the power to make certain determinations.This potentially leads to a slightly confusing situation in that if the claimant for assistance is unhappy with a decision of the Commissioner, he must pursue his appeals through the normal process of the Income Tax Assessment Act. If, however, he is unhappy with the determination made by the board established under the industry research and development legislation, he must pursue his appeals, as I understand it, through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. I think there could be some confusion arising in the minds of claimants as to the course of action which they would have to follow if they were seeking an appeal against a determination that certain expenditure was not to be allowed as a deductible item.The other point I want to raise in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill is that it is interesting that the section 73b (2) exclusion of cosmetic modifications or stylistic changes to products is somewhat at variance with the way in which the Government was prepared to provide funding for the automotive industry. If one looks at the Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Bill, which we passed last year, one will see that under that legislation certain cosmetic and stylistic changes to the motor car industry are allowable deductions. So there again is a slight difference, depending on the particular field in which one is operating.The Industry Research and Development Bill allows the Government to provide financial assistance. Essentially, this will be done through a board which is to be established. Classes of grant will be made available so that industry research and development can be undertaken. The first of these are discretionary grants in which the Minister may essentially declare an activity to be an eligible activity for the purpose of receiving financial support and assistance. Secondly, there are generic technology grants. The Minister may declare an area of technology to be one of generic technology and assistance may be provided under that heading. Thirdly, national interest agreements are to be established. The board, which may in fact be required to act on the direction of the Minister, will be allowed to enter into agreements with individual researchers, or presumably with research institutions, to undertake research into an area which is regarded as being of significant national interest. As part of this whole process the old Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board scheme is being wound up. There are transitional provisions to allow grants made under the old AIRDIB scheme to continue in place and many of the areas of AIRDIB funding are being transferred, in effect, into the discretionary generic technology and national interest agreements as provided in the Industry Research and Development Bill.The Minister may care to advise me as to why it is that under the guidelines which were published by the Minister in relation to this legislation, once again the cost of patenting appears to be excluded as a matter which may be taken into account in working out the expenditure to be provided for companies receiving some sort of assistance under the provisions of this legislation. I am slightly concerned about the extremely wide discretion given in the legislation to the Minister to give directions to the Board. He may give directions to the Board about what is or is not a generic technology. We know that from time to time Ministers will take markedly different approaches as to what constitutes a generic technology. I think there would be wide agreement in the chamber that things such as biotechnology, electronics and information technology are clearly part and parcel of the emerging frontiers of science and technology which ought to be assisted, but from time to time undoubtedly favourites will be played by Ministers, depending on what they happen to be particularly excited about at that time. I would not like to see a situation in which some degree of uncertainty was introduced, depending on whether a particular generic technology was fashionable or not. We know that scientific disciplines and scientific areas come and go as areas of high fashion, depending on a number of circumstances, very few of which have anything to do with the intrinsic merits or otherwise of the technology concerned.The Minister has power under clause 26 of the legislation to declare `eligible activities. He has power under clause 30 to declare what are generic technologies. He has power under clause 33 (2) to request the Board to consider entering into national interest agreements in respect of projects of research and development which the Minister specifies. So the Minister is put in a very powerful position to direct the nature of funding towards particular areas of research and development. We are not proposing by way of amendment any attempt to curtail the Ministers power in this regard. However, we indicate that it is a matter we will be looking at and observing with some degree of caution over the years.As this is the first opportunity on which this particular situation has arisen, I cannot let pass clause 4 (7) of the Industry Research and Development Bill. It is the first occasion on which I have has an opportunity to talk about the construction of boards under this Government. The Board is to consist of a chairperson and certain other persons. The Bill then goes on to provide:For the purposes of this Act-(a) the Chairperson may be referred to as the Chairman or the Chairwoman, as the case requires;Frankly, the cluttering up of legislation with such absolutely pathetic nonsense as `chairman or chairwoman as the case requires really is indicative of the extent to which we are bedevilled with this distorting of the English language which is going on at the moment. As to whether the case requires some objective test of whether the person should be referred to as chairman or chairwoman really boggles the mind. Undoubtedly the Minister will be able to give appropriate directions in appropriate cases.

content: —You ought to be grateful that it does not tell you how to conduct the test.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —If the Minister is minded to provoke me on this matter, there will be even further trouble about it. The other point I make is a general point about funding of research and development. I put it clearly on the record that I believe we have swung too far away from the funding of basic and fundamental research in this country. I understand the enormous drive which is being made for relevant research to be funded-research which will yield an immediate technological fix, economic fix or scientific fix. I understand the very lengthy debates which have taken place over a number of years about the relevance of scientific research, but I think we have now taken that to extremes. We have moved away from the funding of absolutely basic and fundamental research to altogether too great an extent.I look at an article by Leon Lederman in the Scientific American in November 1984 which indicates that, while the American taxpayers spend only about 5 per cent of the cost of applied research and development on fundamental technology, that is where most of the real innovations and developments originate. I look at an article in the Australian Financial Review in November 1984, headed `Japan downgrades development, beefs up basic research. I look to the seminal research paper in the Journal of Political Economy in 1959 by Nelson, entitled `The Simple Economics of Basic Scientific Research; an article in the November 1984 issue of the New Scientist by Martin, Irvine and Turner, entitled `The Writing on the Wall for British Science; and an article in the Economic Review of March 1986 by Stoneman, entitled `Research and Development Policy in the United Kingdom. All of those articles make the point very basically that unless we are prepared to spend sufficient funds on fundamental and basic research, all the applied technology, important as it may be, nevertheless will eventually wither and die. The failure to invest in basic research, in particular the failure to invest in technology transfer as an underpinning of development and research in Australia-we will have the opportunity to discuss this by way of an amendment to the legislation in due course-seems to me to be a matter of very great significance.Finally, I would like to put on the record a number of paragraphs in an article by Donald E. Lewis from the Department of Economics of the University of Wollongong in the autumn 1986 issue of the Australian Quarterly, entitled `Swedens manufacturing sector-a modern success story. Certain paragraphs on pages 26 and 27 make the point about the Swedish Government funding of basic research and a table indicates the expenditure on research and development in Sweden compared with a number of other Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries. I seek leave to incorporate that material in Hansard.Leave granted.The document read as follows-The Swedish engineering sector has always been prepared to make substantial investment in research and development. Both the historical and contemporary Swedish economy, especially the engineering industries, can be characterised by high levels of investment in research and development. `Almost half of Swedens exports now consist of products from the engineering industry which, moreover has largely focused on high technology and a high level of research.10 In this sector `about 4-5 per cent of sales value goes towards research and development each year.11As shown in Table 8 Sweden has one of the highest per capita expenditures of R & D in the OECD, exceeded only by the USA, Switzerland and West Germany. Swedish expenditure per capita is more than double that of Australia (194 verses 92 US$).Furthermore, Sweden was the only OECD `country where R & D spending grew more rapidly in the 1970s than in the preceding decade.1. Total expenditure on R & D in Sweden is small by world standards. It ranks ninth amongst OECD countries and accounts for only about 1 per cent of world expenditure on R & D. Nevertheless, it invests 36 per cent more in R & D than Australia.Table 8N/AEXPENDITURE ON RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT, 1979Gross Expenditures in...Per capita Expenditures inmillions of U.S. dollars...U.S. dollarsN/ACountryRank inOECDAmountCountryGovt.CivilianTotalRank inOECDN/AUSA...156,560USA641882521Japan...218,285Switzerland82152232Sweden...91,608Sweden171771944Australia...111,183Australia8849212N/ASource: Young, A. 1983 `Science and Technology Indicators, OECD Observer, 121, 34-38.Substantial expenditures on R & D is an important reason why Sweden has been able to specialise in medium to high level technological based products.Entrepreneurs, scientists and engineers are very knowledgeable of industrial and engineering developments (widespread knowledge of foreign languages is a big help) and like the Japanese, they are quick to imitate and utilise overseas innovations.The newly emerging robot industry illustrates the rewards of substantial investment in R & D. In 1982 Sweden was the fourth largest user of robots (behind Japan, USA and West Germany), the third largest producers of robots (accounting for 24 per cent of the European market and 7 per cent of the American market) and was the most intensive user on a per capita employment basis in the world.13 ASEA is the major, Swedish producers and has already established assembly plants in Spain, France and production facilities in Japan. Investment in R & D is continuing and $40 million (Australia) has been allocated to research on robotics, computer aided design and computer aided manufacturing during 1980/81 to 1984/85.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I thank the Senate. I conclude by saying that within the overall raft of measures being brought forward for the support of research and development in Australia, the Opposition welcomes these two pieces of legislation. We note the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, 27 May 1986, indicating that there had been a significant increase in the private sector activity in research and development. We know that the best part of 1,000 firms so far have registered-as a firm must register under this scheme-to be participants in this financial venture. We are encouraged by that. I believe that Australian industry as a whole has been encouraged by the lead it has been given by the Minister.It would be churlish to refer at too great a length to the criticisms made by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills about the delays in the presentation of this taxation legislation, which was first announced a year and three days ago, I think, and which has only just seen the light of day. A number of people have been confused as to exactly what the provisions of this legislation would be and there is really very little excuse for a piece of taxation legislation to take more than a year to move from the ministerial announcement to the final form in which the Parliament is able to debate and consider it. Nevertheless, we welcome these two pieces of legislation. We believe that they will make a significant contribution to Australian research and development in the years ahead. The Opposition will be pleased to vote for them and to accord them a speedy passage in the Senate.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator McKIERNAN
content: —I will not delay the Senate over long in my contribution to the discussion on these two very important Bills-the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986. My involvement in this area is a continuing one. In fact, apart from my swearing-in as a senator, my first official words in the Senate were contained in a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in regard to research and development in Australian industry. Because of the time restriction that I am placing on my speech, I will refrain from picking up many of the arguments which Senator Puplick, who preceded me in this debate, put forward. It was a very well thought out contribution. It contained a little nitpicking, but many positive parts as well. I do not know whether we can attribute all of that to what he has read, but he did quote from one excellent piece of material which is doing the rounds at the moment-a book by Barry Jones called Living By Our Wits. Hopefully, he will recommend it to his colleagues and put some more pressure on those who sit on the Opposition front bench.The two pieces of legislation on industry research and development that are before us tonight should provide a much needed shot in the arm for Australian industry. Although it has had a very great shot in the arm in recent years, particularly in regard to the 30 per cent devaluation, many of the captains of industry-some of whom are very vocal at the moment in regard to the other major debate on the fringe benefits tax legislation-have apparently been sitting on their rears and doing very little in looking at the future. They have been whingeing, whining and complaining bitterly because their lurks and perks will be taxed, but they have not been getting off their bums to undertake a little more investment, which is needed in the long term interests of this country.The legislation, as Senator Puplick mentioned, has been discussed for quite a period. A number of industry sectors have welcomed it. I dare say that other representatives of industry in the very near future will castigate it. Another point Senator Puplick mentioned very early in his contribution was the question of buying Australian products. I also take up that point very briefly and relate it to some of the discussions that took place in the Senate last night. I refer honourable senators to the arguments that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, used in defence of the tax on perks. Nobody was able to explain to him why some captains of industry use Rolls-Royces and Mercedes-Benz and not Australian built motor vehicles. I hope Senator Puplick will join the buy Australian campaign. We should show that we have confidence in Australian industry and that our products are good enough for our captains of industry.The two pieces of legislation are aimed ostensibly at private enterprise, because private enterprise investment in research and development is at a very low level when compared with the levels in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We are from time to time reminded of other statistics in regard to OECD countries. In regard to interest rates, we are continually reminded of the comparison between other OECD countries and Australia. In the area of private investment in research and development, the comparisons between Australia and other countries are also noteworthy. Private spending on research and development in Australia amounts to 0.3 per cent of the gross domestic product, compared with an average figure of over three times that amount-0.98 per cent to be precise-in other OECD countries. Between the years 1973-74 and 1981-82 that represents a decline in real terms of 40 per cent. Recent statistics show that the figures have picked up in recent months and years, but they have not yet picked up enough. The two pieces of legislation that are before us this evening-I hope that, with the agreement of both sides of the chamber, they will be passed-will provide that much needed and necessary shot in the arm.Of course, other areas of research and development must be addressed. I refer to the direct area in which governments become involved. The Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 addresses the areas of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the tertiary side. Much needed drive and assistance has been provided in that area which hopefully will be in the long term interests of Australia. If this country is not to decline-and I do not like to use the term, but it has been used-into a banana republic, we will have to take some long term investment decisions. The Government is showing that it is willing to make those long term decisions, decisions that show confidence in the future of the nation. It is now up to private enterprise to join us and show what can be done in a consensus atmosphere. The events of last weekend in one of the rural towns show that consensus is not yet dead. I commend both pieces of legislation to the Senate.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —We are debating a very important issue for Australias future. The two Bills that we are debating tonight-the Industry Research and Development Bill and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill-will offer an incentive to private industry to get into the act in terms of doing research in Australia. I will cite some figures which show that we are not very good in this area of doing research in industry. Currently there is world-wide recognition of the need for research and development, particularly in the high technology areas.Japan has a number of high priority programs, handled by its Ministry for Technology, which give priority to specific types of technology. This legislation is the first in Australia actually to recognise specialised technologies. Japan has a program to deal with highly parallel computers. We have no programs for developing computers in Australia. We do not offer any real help to people who are trying to develop systems. These Bills may give a boost to some of our local industries which currently have been dependent on programs which have been quite good, such as the management and investment companies and venture capital programs, and programs which have been developed within specialised organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the universities. But Japan has gone a lot further than us. It is actually looking at developing 14 science cities or technopolies. These areas will bring together people who are interested in general research and who will be able to work together to develop new products.I join Senator Puplick in making a call to the Government not to be blinded by the practicalities of technology and to take heed of the need for fundamental research if we are to produce practical and practicable technologies and practical products which are innovative enough to be able to attract world markets. Australia currently has a considerable problem due to the neglect of this area over the years. I will not dwell on the trade balance which is currently in a desperate situation. The rural commodity markets need to be developed with a lot more value added products, both in farming and in mining where we could process some of our minerals and energy to develop products which could be directly marketed in both developing and developed countries. We are just not doing enough in this area and I am not certain that these two Bills go far enough in terms of recognising the stages which must be gone through from taking a product from a glint in the eye of the inventor through to something which can be sold on world markets.Australia has a declining share of world trade, particularly in the manufacturing and high tech areas, and I hope that if sufficient money is pushed into these areas these Bills will have the effect of building up our credibility. In 1981-82 Australian firms imported more than 98 per cent of their technical know-how, 75 per cent of this being payments to overseas parent companies or subsidiary companies for patent rights. These were transfers of technology, the research being done overseas, not in Australia, and then being applied as a production process here. This does not produce a good employment climate and currently we have around 10 per cent unemployment on average with very high spots in certain areas. In the manufacturing industry we are losing around 15,000 jobs a year which, I hope, this type of program will allow us to regain.In the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development examiners report of 1983 on Australias research and development problems, the examiners pointed out that there was a relatively poor investment in privately funded research and development. In fact, our investment was less than a quarter of that of similar OECD countries. Indeed, in those countries with similar populations an average of 0.93 per cent of gross domestic product was invested in private research and development. In 1968-69 Australian private investment was 0.48 per cent and this fell to 0.21 per cent in 1981-82-in fact that was just a quarter of the 0.93 per cent of comparable countries. It was also noted that Australias publicly funded research had declined from 1.3 per cent of GDP in 1968-69 to 0.8 per cent in 1981-82. However, the interesting aspect was that this compared favourably with the average of similar OECD countries, which had an average of 0.76 per cent. So it was mainly in the area of private investment-which these two Bills address-that we had a considerable shortfall.From this report, which made quite far reaching recommendations on directions of Australian research and development, the Government has instituted a review of publicly funded research, looking at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which is one of our most effective research organisations and also at industry-based R and D. Through the reorganisation of those bodies, we are actually turning the corner, I hope.However, I must reiterate what Senator Puplick said and beg the Government not to throw out the baby with the bathwater. I urge the Government not to try to get CSIRO to produce small individual products. It is extremely important that we continue with fundamental research because that research gives us a language with which we can absorb ideas from overseas. It also allows us to bring technology into Australia effectively and gives us a group of people who can effectively answer questions for people in industry.I also believe that we must look very closely at co-ordinating our research in Australia in these areas, particularly research being carried out through rural bodies and funded by industry levies, and shift some of the funds in those areas towards market research because we are failing to produce products that are attractive to the world. We must develop from our primary produce high value derivative products which are of a very high quality and hence much in demand in the developed world. We need a manufacturing industry which understands the market it is addressing and we need to go out aggressively to export to that market. This program must be matched with a sensible program of export incentives. The export marketing development grants system is not adequate to complement this program. In this area there is a need for specialised technology export programs.I wish to look at the different stages of research because they will be relevant to amendments I shall move to both these Bills. The OECD examiners report recognises seven stages of research. Firstly, they look at educational experiments which are basically repeating results from overseas, part learning and part technology transfer. We need to have that funded and the Government seems to have totally ignored it in terms of the funding available in these Bills. We will move an amendment to make technology transfer a part of the processes which can be funded and which are regarded as allowable activities. The second item is the pure or basic research which is driven by curiosity and the goal of which is to increase knowledge and understanding. Generally that is carried out in universities or places of that type in a society such as ours. Thirdly, there is policy driven research directed by specific needs or areas which the Government specifies and also by industrial development which specifies the areas in which we concentrate. This legislation is relevant to grants and deductions for generic technology, national interest projects and specialised projects. This area is handled very effectively by CSIRO and other applied research organisations.We then move to applied research which is the discovery of ideas and which starts the search for practical applications as well as for problems which need solutions. This is an area which is well covered by the Governments legislation. Then we move to engineering and design of a product. The Government wants to cut out much of this area because it is also cutting out market studies to find out what type of product we want to handle. We will move an amendment to include the interrelation between the market study and the development of the product. Another item is production and process engineering, which the Government has recognised, and that is well handled. There is also need for the marketing and service follow-up, which this legislation does not address. I will move amendments to both of the Bills during the Committee stage, and will comment further on the reasons for these amendments at that time.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WATSON
content: —The two Bills before the Senate-the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986-have the support of the Opposition. May I describe them as typical Liberal Party initiatives to industry. I believe the incentives offered to research and development will go some way in encouraging both investment and innovation. The key word is really innovation, because research is not really enough. Dr Whitton, Director of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Institute of Industrial Technology, in a paper to the Australian Academy of Science, pointed out with regard to innovation:. . . the whole sequence of steps from research through development, design, construction and production, to marketing. Especially, it involved the commercial exploitation of technology. It is only by the completion of the innovation sequence, that research can lead to generation of wealth; if we only do research, we will not produce wealth.Dr Whitton went on to say:Britain had concentrated on research, and not on innovation; its record of converting research results into commercial use is poor.He said that was why the position of Britain in world trade was falling. In the past the situation in Australia has not been much different. Australia has achieved world-wide recognition in many areas of science. Our universities are held in high regard and we have a wealth of internationally regarded researchers and scientists in universities and government laboratories. Unfortunately, many have left this country because there is not enough scope or money for future development and achievement. There is surprisingly little transfer of technology from laboratory to full scale production in this country. Australia and Sweden make about the same level of contribution to world scientific publications; yet Sweden produces four times the number of patents and it is regarded as a leader amongst those who have a share in the worlds technological property. Too often research of great significance is made known to the world instead of being protected by patents. As a result, Australian industry loses its competitive edge. Sir Frank Espie has also pointed out that the lack of venture capital and the widespread lack of management skills and commercial experience amongst entrepreneurs in existing enterprises are the two major constraints in the creation of viable new high technology enterprises in Australia.Thus, while I commend the Governments proposal to introduce the 150 per cent tax concession as a means of encouraging research and development and its attempt through the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill to make research funds available to suitable projects that would not be eligible for a tax concession, I am concerned that more must be done to ensure that research is carried through to production and the marketing stage. It is only by completion of the whole sequence that research can lead to generation of wealth. In other words, the Government must take action to ensure that more results from local research are worth exploiting and that industry has the skills, the finance and the motivation to take such research through to full commercial utilisation.Because my time is limited, I wish to raise another issue. I find it rather difficult to reconcile the Governments position, especially in relation to these two Bills which I commend. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, appears rather determined to run the Australian textile manufacturers out of the country insofar as he is foreshadowing a move away from quotas. Since mid-1980 over $570m has been invested in the textile, clothing and footwear industries in upgrading buildings and introducing `state of the art technology in machinery. The clothing, textile and footwear manufacturers have done everything that was expected of them under the plan due to expire in 1988; yet their future is now in jeopardy. Not only is their share of the market declining under the plan but also imports are expected to increase to 28 per cent over the two-year period from 1985 to 1987 on the basis of maximum utilisation of quota.My concern is that we must ensure that any change is a controlled change. The emphasis must be on change. A tariff only regime is difficult to police because, for example, there are valuation problems. Everyone knows that business people in Singapore and elsewhere are prepared to give a receipt for any value that the importer likes to nominate. Another problem is that Australias spending on the clothing, textile and footwear industry has declined quite markedly to only 6.5c in the dollar. Furthermore, locally-produced textiles as a category command only 30 per cent of the total Australian market. On a 50 per cent tariff rate theory it is estimated that 50,000 jobs will be lost. The Industries Assistance Commission suggests that it will be only 20,000. I believe, and the industry believes, that this is a gross under-estimation. In fact, there will be massive social and economic dislocation, particularly in non-metropolitan towns. Change is acknowledged, but a predictable rate is also needed. Australian manufacturing must be given the opportunity to be internationally competitive, while consumers also must be given the opportunity of purchasing a wide range of goods at competitive prices. I am making these comments in the context of these Bills because I believe that by the 1990s technological innovations will be in place in Australia which will enable Australian industry to compete with the present low labour cost industries of Asia. But we must at least have an industry left in Australia to implement this new technology that is expected to be around by the 1990s.I remind the Senate that while the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) views the Australian textile, clothing and footwear manufacturing market as one area for increased Chinese participation, Chinese products already dominate most of the clothing categories, and their share is increasing quite markedly. Are we prepared to sacrifice Australian jobs? I will cite one simple statistic which I would like every member of the Senate to think of. A single worker in an Australian manufacturing operation receives more when he goes on holidays each year than his counterpart in China receives over a full five-year period. That is the difference. Australian industry is vulnerable to disruptive trade practices. The United States of America and the European Economic Community both maintain quantitative restraints. If we move away from the present regimes, as has been foreshadowed by the Minister, Australia will run into the problem of a loss of industry. I believe the Government will encounter the current dilemma that President Reagan faces. He has open conflict within the Congress and the Senate because on one hand the international community is demanding greater access to the American market, causing conflict with Americas international trading aspirations, and on the other hand the domestic economy is unable to adapt to those sorts of changes. I made a commitment that I would speak for no longer than ten minutes. I will stick to that commitment. The Bills have our support, and I wish them a speedy passage.

name: Senator SHEIL
content: —The Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986 are designed to give incentives to investment, and to encourage innovation in research and development. It is an old axiom that anything a government wants more of it subsidises and anything it wants less of it taxes. These Bills are designed to provide less tax and cause a distortion, taking investment into research and development away from economic realities and commercial considerations. Even though we are not opposing these Bills they are inconsistent with the policies that have been followed for some time by the Government in a couple of areas. One area I cite is the pharmaceutical industry, which has been the subject of such stringent policies by successive governments over the years that virtually all research and development in the pharmaceutical field has been driven out of Australia. I will not belabour the point because of the ecumenicalism that exists in the Senate at the moment.The other area of inconsistency that I point to is the film industry. Any investment in the film industry has attracted an enormous taxation advantage over many years, yet here we have Bills which restrict a taxation deduction merely to companies. In other words, anyone else who wants to invest in research and development, such as single people, partnerships or sole traders, will not attract this taxation deduction. That is a point that I would like the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to answer in the interests of shortening the debate, as we have a restricted time in which to speak.The sole trader, the partnership and the single person would not be the only ones who would be disadvantaged. A small company may have a chance of doing research and development in an area for which it does not have the finance and it may wish to attract that finance from a rich uncle or somebody else, but only the company would attract the taxation advantage. The individual who gave the money to that company would not attract the deduction. I think we should be able to do as much for commercial research and development in Australia in the areas of industry and medicine and in all the other areas as we do for our films. I think this could generate a whole area of industrial and medical research that would be of as much advantage to Australia as Crocodile Dundee and all the other marvellous films that have been mentioned here tonight.

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I thank honourable senators for their warm support for this legislation. I do not think I have to digress down every path which was followed in the course of the debate. Three specific things were put to me. Senator Puplick asked whether patent fees paid in the course of a research and development project were covered by the scheme. The answer is yes. If there is a patenting process at the end of a program of research and development, he is right in saying that those patenting costs would not be allowable. The reason for that is that in legislation of this kind one has to confine the parameters of research and development. I think Senator Puplick is concerned about a general problem relating to patenting and patenting costs. I understand that; I agree with that. It is a distinct problem as far as we are concerned.Senator Vigor-I think we will come to it in the Committee stage of this debate-has a number of proposals which, however desirable from the point of view of a personal feeling of warmth, would cause this scheme to be immensely costly by extensions of that kind. I think it is important that we confine the research and development process to what it is and not extend it beyond the process, the patenting at the end of the process being a step in the commercialisation of a research and development process.I think the only other point that Senator Puplick was concerned about was a warning about the apparent wide discretion given to the Minister in respect of designating generic technologies in particular and a warning about fashionableness and all those things. I accept all that. Some discretion is given to the Minister. I suppose one only substitutes the degree of fashion of the populous as represented in the Senate for the degree of fashion prescribed by the Minister. I do not know whether that produces very effective results but I concede that it is a wide discretion.Senator Sheil, the authentic voice of the National Party of Australia in the chamber tonight, had a couple of comments to make about this legislation. As I understand it, he was concerned particularly as to why the tax incentive applies only to companies.

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I thank the honourable senator. That is the warmest endorsement that I have ever had from the honourable senator in the whole of my political career and I appreciate it. If one looks at the area of research and development one sees that governments spent a lot of money on it right throughout the 1970s and all that happened to private sector research and development was that it went down and down, and that is because the incentives were wrong. The incentives in this legislation are applied, as the honourable senator has said, only to companies and that is because we do not want this scheme to be discredited by the other side of the coin which we had in the 1970s. As research and development went down tax avoidance and creative accounting went up. Maybe those two industries-tax avoidance and creative accounting-have an endearing charm for the honourable senator; I do not know. But that is what we have to be very careful about in respect of this legislation. That is why we have provided for a system of registration of companies which seek the benefit of the tax concession and that is why we have excluded sole traders and partnerships. I do not think it is much to the detriment of the genuine research and development community in Australia. I know that 100 flowers might bloom out there but so might 100 tax avoidance schemes and we want to be very careful about that. I do not have much more to say about the honourable senators view of the matter. I suppose that our priorities are different. I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation.Question resolved in the affirmative.Bill read a second time.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I move:(1) Page 2, sub-clause 4 (1), definition of `eligible activity, after paragraph (e), add the following new paragraph:`(f) the development of systems and processes in relation to an activity referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e);.The Industry Research and Development Bill has a definition of `eligible activity which is fairly limited. Our particular concern in this area of definition is that of systems and processes which are a potential area for export of high technology and have, in fact, been ignored by the Government. We believe that it is extremely important that help should be given to people who wish to develop systems and processes within the ambit of this Bill. The first Bill we are dealing with, the Industry Research and Development Bill or the Governments industry research and development scheme, is complementary to the 150 per cent tax legislation, and a lot of the definitions are complementary one with the other.However, in the GIRD scheme the Government has said that the only companies which will be eligible to receive the benefits of these grants are in fact companies which are involved in the manufacture of goods, mining operations or operations for recovery of naturally occurring petroleum and natural gas, construction operations relating to building or works, the production of software for computers or for similar equipment, or activities in respect of which a declaration under section 26, which is a ministerial declaration, are eligible activities. Only companies which carry on these eligible activities will be able to claim a grant under this scheme. We believe that there is a need for us to recognise that a number of Australian companies, such as Kimberley Seeds in Western Australia, export systems for reclaiming land and for growing trees. A number of people install factories and have very innovative ways of doing so. We would like to see those people covered. People who are developing systems, say for manufacturing or systems for robotics or processes for chemical production of goods will be covered by this Act if the amendment which I have moved is accepted.Amendment agreed to.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I move:(2) Page 3, sub-clause 4 (1), definition of `research and development activities, paragraph (a), line 13, after `innovation, insert: `, technology transfer into Australia.This amendment deals with the definition of research and development activities and involves a slightly different problem. It relates to systematic investigation or experimentation activities that involve innovation or technical risk. I have some problems with the meaning of `technical risk. I would be very grateful if the Minister would elucidate this so that I and anybody else can understand what he is talking about. I have an idea of what `technical risk means, but I would like him to cover that so that it is on the public record. My amendment adds the words `technology transfer into Australia onto the end of those research activities. The `technology transfer into Australia, is relevant to people who are actually trying to set up the initial stages of a research program or who are investigating a technology which is available overseas. They can claim the cost involved in getting that set up. The rest of the clause is acceptable.

Let me explain what it does not mean. If a person decides to rechrome a saucepan, that is not considered a technical risk.

content: —It is not a research and development process. Insofar as Senator Vigor puts his argument about technology transfer into Australia, if there is a technology transfer of information, methodology, or something of that kind which is intrinsic to a research and development process carried out under this legislation, then that is covered. When a person applies to the Industrial Research and Development Board and explains his research and development project to members of the Board they would say: `Look, this element of the proposed piece of research and development arises from a technology transfer from the United States and is part of our cost of doing the complete piece of research and development. That is covered by the scheme and this amendment is not necessary. We oppose it for that reason.

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I am not satisfied with the explanation given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce as to whether technology transfer costs are properly comprehended within the definition of research and development activities. I believe that the case for investment of public funds in technology transfer is absolutely overwhelming. When one looks at a number of the fields of very high technology and high technology development it will always be the case that 95 per cent, 96 per cent or 97 per cent of critical research is carried out overseas and that the transfer back into Australia and into the Australian manufacturing sector of research and development results which are achieved overseas will be absolutely fundamental to the growth and development of Australian science and technology and research and development in particular.Those who were privileged to hear Sir Gustav Nosal address the forum that was arranged here last week will have heard Sir Gustav at length on the question of technology transfer. I believe that the case that has been made out for the inclusion of technology transfer as a research and development activity is a powerful one. I am certainly inclined to accept the amendment put forward by Senator Vigor, as far as that is concerned. I am a little unclear as to the way in which the clause would read, simply as a result of the way in which the amendment is drawn. If I am correct, it would mean that it would read:`research and development activities means systematic investigation or experimentation activities-(a) that involve innovation, technology transfer into Australia, or technical risk.If my understanding of the way in which that clause would read is correct, perhaps I may say, on behalf of the Opposition, that we would be inclined to accept that amendment.

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I would caution Senator Puplick against that course. Looking at the definition as a whole-`research and development activities means systematic investigation or experimentation activities that involve certain things; `innovation or technical risk . . . the object of which is new knowledge et cetera-if one includes there after `innovation the words, `technology transfer into Australia, it must be understood that the process of research and development activity inevitably, as I would read the current definition, contains an element of technology transfer. If one puts a scientist on the staff of the company, that involves an element of technology transfer. If one brings in a piece of knowledge from outside, it involves an element of technology transfer. But if one were to rejig this definition so that technology transfer into Australia were seen as an integral part, and an important, spelt out part, of the process of research and development, I think that one would run grave risks of abuse of the legislation, because one would run the risk that people would have an enormously significant piece of research and development done overseas, which is precisely where one does not want it done, and technologically transferred into Australia under the provisions of the expanded definition. We are very cautious about that, and I think, with respect, the Committee ought to be, as well.

content: —I am convinced by some aspects of what the Minister has said. We should not accept that research carried out overseas can be brought in holus-bolus at the full price of that research. It is a matter of definition. name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I am not in the process of taking on the run whether Senator Vigor is or is not withdrawing his amendment. In terms of amendments being put forward, there comes a stage at which, acting in the best of goodwill and good faith, my inclination is to continue to support the inclusion of the words proposed in Senator Vigors amendment. However, I am not prepared to stand around for the rest of the night on shifting sands as far as Australian Democrats amendments are concerned. Nevertheless, to address the points that Senator Button has raised, if there is, indeed, an inevitability of technology transfer in any research and development program-I accept that there is-I am not persuaded that simply saying that in the legislation makes the position qualitatively different, one way or the other.If Senator Buttons problem is that a large scale cost will be involved in terms of the transfer of major pieces of technology or major costs of technology transfer into Australia, I am not persuaded that that is, in fact, a major problem, because of the Ministers discretionary powers under the legislation, particularly under clause 20 (1). That sub-section states:The Minister may, from time to time, by notice in writing delivered to the Chairperson and expressed to be given under this section, give directions to the Board with respect to the policies and practices to be followed by the Board in the performance of its functions, and the exercise of its powers, under this Act (including, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the policies and practices to be followed by the Board with respect to the entering into by the Board of discretionary grant agreements, generic technology agreements or national interest agreements and the provisions to be included in such agreements), and the Board shall comply with any such directions that are in force.I believe, therefore, that under the whole of clause 20, which is headed `Guidelines for policies and practices of Board, the Minister has sufficient power to prevent abuses of the legislation, and I am inclined to persist with support of Senator Vigors amendment-if, indeed, it remains Senator Vigors amendment in the circumstances.

He has a very large amount of discretion in terms of being able to set up guidelines and to specify exactly what are acceptable eligible activities, and what are new research and development activities. All the speeches in the world are made in this place about giving Ministers discretion to do certain things. name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I know that, but Senator Macklin must understand that something might happen to me. I might die of boredom after a few more of his interjections, and then he would have another Minister, and that Minister might not be as diligent as I am in exercising such discretion. With respect, it is not a good argument from a legislative point of view. Senator Vigor wants to include the same amendment in the 150 per cent tax incentive Bill, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill 1986. He is so concerned about what multinationals might do to this country. Imagine the operation of that provision under the tax incentive Bill. That Bill is market led. Matters are very much within the control of the company concerned. The honourable senator has given us a serve tonight about the evils of the multinationals. They could bring in massive amounts of transferred technology under that legislation, sell it within Australia, and make a squillion out of it, largely at the Australian taxpayers expense. Is that what Senator Vigor wants? That would be the effect of his amendment to the other legislation and he says that he would make this amendment here in the interests of consistency.I had discussions with Senator Vigor about his amendments, as he well knows, and I agreed to two of them. I agreed to two of them because I thought that they were thoughtful and intelligent amendments. But I appeal to the honourable senator to realise that these other amendments will make this legislation look like a dogs breakfast. That does not reverberate to the credit of anybody in this chamber including the mover of the amendments. One does not want that said about the legislation after it is ultimately passed.There is an inconsistency in what the honourable senator is seeking to do and the arguments he is advancing in support of it. The industrial research and development legislation, I concede, is very tight. It is designed to be pretty specific about the directions of research and development under grants from that Board. We are not in the business of social welfare here, and none of us ought to be, in terms of research and development done in Australia. We are in the business of providing an efficient, well directed scheme. If we make it sloppy around the edges we might get some comfort over a drink with some accountant on a pleasant Friday night, but we would not get any comfort from the research and development community in Australia. I sincerely put it to the honourable senator that this amendment is misdirected in that sense. I ask the honourable senator what he will say about this amendment when the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill reaches the Committee stage. I think that the best way of achieving consistency between the two pieces of legislation is for neither amendment to be moved.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I accept the Ministers statement about the problems with the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill. In this case it is a granting process which is under the control of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and under very close supervision. In the tax case we do not have this close supervision and I am willing to look at not moving this provision in the case of the tax Bill. I believe that, even though we have this argument for consistency between the two Bills, consistency is not mandatory. Here the final response is under the Ministers control, whereas in the case of the tax Bill we do not have technical people in the Australian Taxation Office who will be able to assess relevance. Under the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill. The person has only to be registered with the granting body as a proper recipient. There is much more control in the Industry Research and Development Bill through the eligible activities than there is in the tax Bill. I will not move this amendment to the tax Bill, but I will to the Industrial Research and Development Bill.
debateinfo: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I am interested to have it indicated to me that Senator Vigor is not pursuing the matter in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Research and Development) Bill. I suppose that taking these things on the run is part of the fun of the game. Nevertheless, the point which has to be made about the Industry Research and Development Bill is that it seems to have largely grown out of the criticisms which were made of the original 150 per cent tax concession legislation that there was insufficient provision being made for the position of small business and for small innovative companies. Therefore, it seems to me that, since they are the principal beneficiaries of the grants for industry research and development scheme, one of the areas in which they should be encouraged is in the significant area of technology transfer. I am totally unimpressed with the Ministers dire warning-apres moi le deluge-that there will never be another significant, consistent, intelligent and alert Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and that it is all downhill from here on in. If that were the case when we came to matters such as telephone tapping, it would be interesting to see whether Senator Button pursued that argument with the same degree of vigour and the same degree of enthusiasm as he will doubtless bring to the trust me syndrome which will occur. I am minded to continue the support for Senator Vigors amendment as far as this Bill is concerned, but I can put the Ministers mind at ease on the other Bill since it was not my intention to support Senator Vigors amendment on that other Bill at any stage.Question put:That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Vigors amendment) be inserted.Clause, as amended, agreed to.Clause 5 (Extension of Act to external Territories).

content: —I move:Page 4, clause 5, lines 14 and 15, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:`5. This Act extends to every external Territory..This is not a particularly important amendment. However, there does not seem to be any reason why the legislation should be worded in such a way as to enable the Minister to declare the external territories to which the legislation will apply. I ask the Minister to explain why the legislation should be worded in that way. The amendment is aimed at simplifying the wording by extending the legislation to every external territory rather than leaving that decision open for some type of ministerial declaration.

The reason for that is quite simple. The Government of the Territory of Norfolk Island does not like this Commonwealth Parliament imposing bits of legislation on it. It does not want this legislation to apply to the island. As I said, I will be circulating an amendment in a minute. Perhaps Senator Vigor will withdraw his amendment.
