name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —The Opposition will be happy to support the amendment that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is going to move. However, I am not prepared to allow the opportunity to pass without indicating just how inconsistent the Minister is in coming to us and, on the one hand, saying that the Government of Norfolk Island does not like this legislation and, on the other hand, being prepared to cast aside the clear opposition of the Norfolk Island Assembly in regard to the amendment to apply the Bill of Rights to Norfolk Island as being inconsequential. I think the Minister has some difficulty in explaining the consistency in his sensitivity to the Government of Norfolk Island. He is perfectly prepared to be sensitive on the question of industry research and development grants and he is perfectly prepared to be insensitive in regard to the Bill of Rights. However, on the basis that he is now on the right track as far as Norfolk Island is concerned, we are perfectly prepared to support the amendment which the Minister intends to move.

content: —I have a question to ask of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in regard to clause 7 (8). I understand that there has been a communication between the Cattle Council of Australia and the Minister with regard to the ability to establish joint ventures with the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Research and Development Corporation. I am informed that the initial approach to the Government was negative-that is, it was not possible to enter into those joint ventures inasmuch as the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Research and Development Corporation is 50 per cent funded by government funds and hence was outlawed because of the proviso that research and development activities funded by government grants are excluded from the concession contained in this Bill. Following further discussions between the Cattle Council and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and Senator Button, as the Minister responsible for this area, the Cattle Council was given to understand that it was not the case that the Corporation was excluded from those joint ventures. In fact, the Department of Primary Industry specifically wants these types of ventures to take place.There seems to be some confusion on this matter. I think it would be useful in the Committee stage if the Minister could give an answer as to whether or not in this specific case the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Research and Development Corporation might be included in the scope of the Bill. Can the Minister advise me whether or not similar corporations might find themselves in a similar situation? Is this a specific problem which affects this Corporation?

content: —I move:Page 12, clause 26, line 4, leave out `The Minister may, by notice in writing published in the Gazette, insert: `The regulations may.The Australian Democrats are following the general principle of examining the process of parliamentary review of administrative action or delegated legislation in all Bills that we consider. Basically this amendment is aimed at decreasing in this one case only the Ministers discretion to change the legislation without reference to the Parliament. The Minister can determine what is an eligible company. However, we believe that the Parliament should have the right to disallow that determination. The amendment is to make that activity of declaring an eligible activity into a prescribed process and to set it up by regulation. I understand from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), that he is not happy about this, but I seek from him reasons why he would not want such a very central activity in the Bill to come back to the Parliament for possible disallowance. All the rest of the clauses under which the Minister can declare something in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette have been agreed to; there is absolutely no objection from the Australian Democrats to those.

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —The Opposition will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Vigor. There is a major inconsistency in attempting to do this in clause 26 but not attempting to do it so in clause 30 and relating it only to discretionary grants and not to generic technology grants. There is a major problem in attempting to have the Parliament make a series of decisions on the question of what is or what is not an eligible activity to be declared for the purposes of this legislation.I do not believe that the Parliament is giving away oversight of a significant power. The Minister has to have the discretion to decide from time to time what is or is not an eligible activity within the discretionary grants part of the legislation. We will have plenty of opportunity, if the matter is gazetted, to debate it. It ought to be debated. Under those circumstances, I do not think that this matter should have to come backwards and forwards every time by method of legislation. The fact that this amendment will put the Ministers power in discretionary grants and the Ministers power in generic technology grants on an entirely different footing is sufficient to persuade the Opposition not to support this amendment.

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I move:(1) Page 4, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (1), definition of `contracted expenditure, line 25, after institute (first occurring), insert `or the Coal Research Trust Account.(2) Page 4, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (1), definition of `contracted expenditure, line 25, after `performing, insert `or that trust account.(3) Page 11, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (21), line 31, after `deduction, insert `for depreciation.(4) Page 11, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (21), line 32, leave out `under a provision of this Act other than this section.(5) Page 12, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (21) (b) (ii), line 6, leave out `other, insert `first-mentioned.(6) Page 12, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (22), line 11, after `deduction, insert `for depreciation.(7) Page 12, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (22), line 12, leave out `under a provision of this Act other than this section.I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short speech which explains the purpose of these amendments.Leave granted.The speech read as follows-Clause 7 of the Bill as introduced will insert provisions into the income tax law to provide special deductions of up to 150 per cent for certain expenditure incurred by Australian companies in respect of research and development activities carried on in Australia.The first 2 amendments being moved will provide for contributions by eligible companies to the coal research trust account for the funding of R&D activities on the companies behalf to attract deductions at the rate of 150 per cent, regardless of the level of a companys R&D expenditure in a year of income.Under the provisions of the Bill as it stands, such contributions would attract that rate of deductions only where a companys R&D expenditure for the year of income was $50,000 or more.The other amendments being moved relate to those provisions of the Bill that allow 2 exceptions to the general position that expenditure in respect of which the special deductions have been allowed, or may become allowable, cannot also be allowed as deductions under any other provisions of the income tax law.The first exception is where plant ceases to be used exclusively for R&D activities before its cost is written-off under the concession provided by the Bill.In such a case, the balance may be eligible for deduction under other provisions of the law.The second exception relates to the excess, if any, over the first $10 million of the cost of pilot plant. Where that first $10 million has been written-off under the concession, the balance may attract any other relevant deductions.The amendments will provide for depreciation deductions only to be allowed in the foregoing circumstances in respect of plant expenditure not written-off under the concession.This will ensure certainty in the application of the law in the particular circumstances and will generally be to the advantage of eligible companies.But for the amendments, it would be open to question as to which other provisions may apply. Also, if, for example, the general mining provisions of the income tax law were applied, write-off of the plant would be over the lesser of 10 years of the life of the mine, instead of over a maximum of 5 years under the accelerated depreciation provisions of the law.The amendments will also ensure that, where plant is used for other than research and development activities and is eligible for depreciation deductions, those deductions will become available from the time the R&D concession would otherwise have applied in respect of the plant. I commend the amendments to the committee.Amendments agreed to.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —I move:(1) Page 4, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73b (1), definition of `deduction acceleration factor,(a) leave out `$20,000, insert: `$2,000; and(b) leave out paragraphs (a) and (b), insert: `1.5.This amendment is to clause 7 of the Bill. Basically, my concern is that the Government has a requirement that before people shall get the 150 per cent tax rebate, they shall invest more than $50,000, if the research is done on their own premises, on research activities or research related activities. There is a formula which phases in that amount from $20,000 to $50,000. We feel that small organisations should be given the benefit of doing research on their own premises without subcontracting that research to an external body, which is allowed under another clause of the Bill. We propose that the starting point for being able to claim the 1.5 per cent be from $2,000 upwards, as we believe that this will cover a number of quite small projects and would not place too much of a burden on the Commissioner of Taxation or on the registering body.
debateinfo: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —The Opposition will not accept the amendment moved by Senator Vigor. I do not believe that research and development to the amount of $2,000 is likely to be carried out on the premises of some company. The deduction which is available to any small company which undertakes research under the value of $20,000 is, in our opinion, adequately provided for by reading proposed new section 73b (13), regarding contracted expenditure, with section 73a (6), of the principal Act. Expenditure under $20,000, in terms of expenditure by small and start-up companies, is deductible-if it is done in an approved research institution and contracted out-at the rate of 150 per cent. We therefore do not regard this as an appropriate amendment.I am conscious of the time constraints and of the Ministers problem in getting this legislation to the House of Representatives. Apart from a couple of matters which I am sure Senator Vigor will want to raise regarding amendment No. 5 which he has circulated, I indicate at this stage that, of the 11 amendments circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats, it is not the intention of the Opposition to support any of them.
debateinfo: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —The amendment is not acceptable to the Government for reasons of prevention of wastefulness, abuse and all sorts of things like that. The Australian Science and Technology Council, for example, took the view that the figure should be higher than the figure of $20,000 prescribed in the legislation. In respect of registered companies, 25 per cent of research and development expenditure will be by companies with less than 100 employees-that is, small companies. We think the figure proposed in the amendment is ridiculously low.Amendment negatived.

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —by leave-I move:(2) Page 5, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73B (1), definition of `pilot plant, (b), lines 10 to 14, leave out the definition, insert the following definition:` ``pilot plant means an experimental model of plant for use primarily in research and development activities;.(3) Page 5, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73B (1), definition of `plant expenditure, line 23, leave out `exclusively.(4) Page 5, clause 7, proposed new sub-paragraph 73B (1) (a) (ii), definition of `research and development activities, line 29, after `innovation, insert `, technology transfer into Australia; and(5) Page 5 clause 7, proposed new sub-sub-paragraph 73b (1) (a) (iii) (b), definition of `research and development activities, line 35, after `processes insert `, systems.(6) Page 10, clause 7, proposed new sub-section 73B (14) (b), lines 21 and 22, leave out the paragraph.(7) Page 10, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (15), (a) and (b), lines 32 to 38, leave out the paragraphs insert `one-third of the amount of that qualifying plant expenditure.(8) Page 12, clause 7, proposed new sub-paragraph 73B (23) (e) (i) and (ii), lines 35 to 45, leave out the sub-paragraph insert `the amount ascertained by multiplying the amount by which that written-down value exceeds that consideration receivable by the deduction acceleration factor in relation to the company in relation to the year of income.(9) Page 17, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (31) (a) line 38, after `exclusively, insert `or in part.(10) Page 18, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (31) (d), insert the following new paragraph:`(da) the extent to which the plant, building or extension is used for research and development activities; and.(11) Page 18, clause 7, proposed new paragraphs 73B (33) (a) and (b), lines 41 and 42, leave out the paragraphs, insert `in a manner that is for the benefit of the Australian economy..Basically, all of these amendments are aimed, in our view, at improving the nature of the definitions within the Bill and also allowing for plant expenditure to be partially assigned to research rather than exclusively assigned to research. I have decided that I will not pursue amendment No. 4. Most of the proposals contained in amendment Nos 6 and 8 are consequential upon amendment No. 1, which has been defeated. So I will not be pursuing those amendments. I am, however, concerned about amendment No. 11. I want to make a point about that amendment and I seek an undertaking from the Government. My major concern is that the Australian people should benefit from this legislation and the grants which come under it. At page 18 of the Bill, clause 7 in relation to products being sold states:(a) On normal commercial terms; or(b) in a manner that is for the benefit of the Australian economy.I see no reason why one should have in the clause `in the course of normal commercial activity. I believe that any of the activities that should be carried out should be for the benefit of the Australian economy, if grants or tax allowances are to be given to these people. I seek an undertaking from the Minister on this matter. There are three matters involved. One has to do with partial use of the plant and people getting a partial benefit as a result of partial use of a plant; there is the Australian benefit; and there is the problem of a better definition of what a pilot plant can be used for.
debateinfo: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —We do not agree that it is a better definition of what a pilot plant can be used for. The Government does not accept any of the amendments. In regard to amendment No. 11 I make the point that Senator Vigor supported this amendment on the basis that the Government, as he put it, would be handing out grants to people and they ought to be for the benefit of the Australian community. He is referring to the wrong piece of legislation. This is the tax incentives legislation. There is no handing out of anything by the Government. It is a market led scheme. I think the honourable senator is referring to the wrong piece of legislation. So the commercial criterion is of the utmost importance. None of the amendments are acceptable.Amendments negatived.
debateinfo: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator VIGOR
content: —by leave-I move:Page 8, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (2) (a), line 3, leave out `market research, market testing or market development, or.Page 8, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (2) (b), line 5, leave out the paragraph.Page 8, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (2) (d), lines 9 and 10, leave out `or stylistic changes and `processes or production methods.Page 8, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (2) (e), line 11, leave out the paragraph.Page 8, clause 7, proposed new paragraph 73B (2) (g), lines 13 and 14, leave out the paragraph.The Government has tried to exclude a large number of activities which I believe to be associated with research and which are an integral part of research activities. In particular, it is very important, if we are to produce proper products for overseas markets which are relevant to those markets, and if we are to carry out research to develop those products, that we should carry out proper market research, market testing and market development. I do not wish market research, testing and development to be specifically excluded from the ambit of this Bill. It is also very important that we produce quality products and, if we are doing research into quality control, I believe that that quality control should be able to be claimed as a deductible expense for tax purposes. I am not talking about quality control at the production stage, but quality control during the research stage and the setting up of quality control procedures.We also have here a statement that cosmetic and stylistic changes to process or production methods should not be allowed. As Senator Puplick has pointed out, this seems to be in contradiction to some of the attitudes that the Government has taken in the car industry in terms of grants in that area. It seems to me that a considerable amount of research can be done in terms of better ergonomic suitability of the products we have and that is probably one of the major things that will determine whether our products will be successful in foreign markets. One of the final two paragraphs relates to computer software. I believe that if people develop computer programs or software in the course of research programs for either monitoring or recording information associated with the research, that should be a claimable expense under this scheme. I seek the Ministers views on this subject.
debateinfo: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator BUTTON
role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
content: —I will state my views very briefly. If honourable senators want a wall to wall system of industry assistance at the taxpayers expense they will vote for Senator Vigors amendment because there would be nothing that most thoughtful companies in Australia do that would not be covered by the research and development tax incentive scheme. Marketing, market research, testing, market development, stylistic changes-all those are things which any company worth its salt would do in the normal course of its business. Research and development is not necessarily something which any company would do in the normal course of business; it is something to be encouraged by this legislation. The distinction between research and development and marketing and so on is very important in that regard. The costs of this scheme would be prohibitive if Senator Vigors words were included. The amendment would be of benefit to some companies but of great detriment to the amount of research and development done in Australia. The same applies to paragraph (d). The Government could not accept this amendment.

name: Senator PUPLICK
content: —I indicate that the Opposition agrees with the analysis that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has just made of the amendment. We do not support it. In particular, paragraph (d) would be primarily of benefit in areas such as the automotive industry but I believe that section 5 of the Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Act 1985 adequately provides for that particular matter. Therefore I indicate that we would not support the Democrats amendment. However, we hope that the Minister will continue to keep the question of patents under notice. I hope he will be particularly conscious of the comments made about the operation of the Australian Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office in the report of Estimates Committee A to the Senate this year. I hope that the Minister will be good enough at some stage to take the control of the Australian Patent Office away from the Department of Science and put it into the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce where it properly belongs. Perhaps then someone can make sure that it operates efficiently.

debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —No, we are not good hearted at all. Had I known that the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled was a registered benevolent organisation, I may have had harsher, more terrible things to say. I think that that organisation is a very good example of what I am talking about. Under this amendment ACROD could-and I dare say it would-provide its executive secretary with a car which he or she could use 24 hours a day for his or her own personal use and be exempt from the fringe benefits tax. Arrangements could be made, and I predict would be made, whereby through a so-called benevolent institution a person could provide individuals in the community with cars-I use this example of cars over and over again-24 hours a day, seven days a week for his own personal use and that would be okay. I think the people who donate to so-called benevolent institutions should know that from now on as a result of this amendment their donations can be used and will be used for that purpose. I am not concerned about the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society and those reputable organisations which have always done the right thing in this area. This amendment will open a loophole.I can understand the concern of the Opposition and the Democrats and that they were not happy about what they regarded as protections for what they saw as charitable organisations. I think it is very significant that the place where this was a big issue and a populist issue was at the ACROD conference on the Gold Coast last year. As I said earlier, we will probably come back in a year or two years and have a look at this amendment. We do not oppose it. Honorable senators opposite have all done the right thing. They have all made themselves big people in the eyes of what they see as charitable or benevolent organisations, but they have left a hole big enough for a Mack truck to drive through. We will close it later.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALTERS
content: —Senator Grimes is now venting his spleen, I suppose, against losing the vote on the amendment put by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. He picked on one organisation and said that it would abuse the system. I am quite sure that it is not beyond the wit of the Government to be able to close any loopholes that could be used by the organisation that Senator Grimes accused it of being able to use. He has to realise that the groups of people we are particularly concerned about are those who work for small salaries and for long hours. Senator Grimes is aware of so many organisations whose members do this. Those were the sorts of organisations that the Government was also getting into its fringe benefits net.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

content: —No.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator WALTERS
content: —Yes, it was. It is those organisations that we were particularly concerned about. I do not believe that it is beyond the wit of the Australian Taxation Office to be able to close any loopholes and pick up any organisations that are abusing the system. We have heard Senator Walsh in the Senate accuse charities of ripping off the tax system. He did not name just one organisation; he lumped all charities together. I believe that it is that sort of rhetoric that causes the various charities to get their backs up. Senator Grimes should send the Minister for Finance out of the chamber. That would probably be a very good idea. To say that we will be accused by the people making donations of allowing an abuse of the system is a ridiculous statement, because that can be covered by the Taxation Office.
debateinfo: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986 FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —I just want to reply very briefly to what Senator Walters was saying. I think she is being quite unfair and I am not venting my spleen on anyone. Under the arrangements that we had before, benevolent institutions which provided cars or accommodation for anyone in the course of their duty in providing a service to the community were exempt from this tax. The people we were worried about were people such as executives who were provided 24 hours a day, seven days a week, with cars to drive around in. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said previously that we would look at compensating organisations for the services provided in the course of their duties, but we did not believe that charities in the community should be able to provide these sorts of things tax free any more than anyone else.We are accepting the amendment. This amendment gives people carte blanche in that area. If honourable senators opposite are right, if no one abuses the system and if everything is okay, fair enough; it will not affect anybody. I think every honourable senator sitting opposite knows quite well that people will grasp at any opportunity to get over this. I find it very difficult to understand how the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled qualifies under the amendment and how the Australian Council of Social Service or the Australian Council on the Aging do not.

name: Senator GRIMES
content: —The honourable senator brought it up and took it up at the ACROD conference. She waved her flag and away she went on her white horse, and this is where she has ended up. It was a great populist cause. All sorts of umbrella organisations will be claiming the same sorts of privileges in the future. If we were to decide that ACROD was not a charitable or benevolent organisation and if we were to knock it off, the honourable senator would be the first one to say that that was a terrible thing. I understand that, and we will not do that, because we are political realists, amongst other things.I am not opposed to small charitable organisations. I believe that voluntary organisations and organisations of the type that we are talking about are absolutely crucial to the sensible delivery of services and of social welfare in this community. I just do not like to see them abused and used as tax lurks in the way they have been used in the past. I think this amendment leaves a hole in the legislation where they can do it again. But, if I am wrong, I am wrong.

name: Senator SIDDONS
content: —The comments of the Minister upset me a little also in the sense that I am bound to say that in the discussions and negotiations we had with the Government late last year, a firm undertaking was given that existing genuine charitable organisations would not be seriously disadvantaged. There was very little of that in the legislation that the Government brought down. I believe that it did not honour its original undertaking. If this amendment is a little looser than the Government would have liked, it has only itself to blame. It should have paid attention to this question at the time of preparing the legislation.Question resolved in the affirmative.Proposed new clause agreed to.Proposed new clause 57B (Provision of benefits to employees of scientific, charitable or public educational institutions to be exempt).

Speaker: N/A

name: Senator PETER BAUME
content: —I move:Page 46, after new clause 57A, insert the following new clause:``Provision of benefits to employees of scientific, charitable or public educational institutions to be exempt``57B. (1) Where a scientific, charitable or public educational institution provides a benefit to an employee of the institution, the benefit is an exempt benefit.``(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), `scientific, charitable or public educational institution has the same meaning as it has in paragraph 23 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, but does not include a body the income of which is exempt from income tax by reason of any other paragraph of that section..Earlier Senator Haines drew attention to the problems associated with section 23 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and to the variety of organisations which are covered under the definition of charities. We are very concerned about the situation which may face certain schools. I wish to mention the problem. In any one town in a remote area we may have two schools-a government school and a non-government school. For example, subsidised housing may be available at both schools. We are concerned with regard not only to the question of housing but also the other things that may be regarded as fringe benefits for which there may be a penalty which may fall upon the providers of non-government education. They operate as non-profit organisations.

name: Senator PETER BAUME
content: —The honourable senator interjects, but I remind her that in the case of non-government education in Australia, seven students out of eight are in the Catholic education system. If we are talking about non-government education, to be fair, in the case of 87 per cent of those involved we are talking about Catholic education. The problems I am talking about will fall upon the Catholic education systems. Two weeks ago in Western Australia I talked to members of the staff at the Catholic Education Office. They are concerned about the effect of the fringe benefits tax upon the operation of their system. We have therefore moved this second amendment to pick up a number of organisations, not least of which are the Catholic schools of Australia and, indeed, the other non-government schools.I also believe that there are other charitable organisations, and I listened to the list that Senator Haines read out. While it ranged widely I thought most of them were organisations with merit and most of them were organisations which we would not want to see penalised. The amendment which we have proposed seeks to cover scientific organisations, charitable organisations and public educational institutions.Consideration interrupted.

name: Senator VANSTONE
content: —Tonight I wish to raise the matter of appointments to public office. Many people wish to make points with respect to appointments to public office. The last time I recall such comments being made in this chamber they referred to the Constitutional Commission and the failure of the Government to take the opportunity to appoint a significant number of women to that Commission. I do not believe that all appointments to public office in statutory authorities and commissions should be political neuters. I quite accept that there are occasions when people who have acquired political skills from either side should have the skills that they have acquired used in some other area to serve the community. In the United Kingdom such appointments are very common but in the halls surrounding this chamber-referred to by some as the corridors of power but which might otherwise be referred to as the whirlpools of rumour-rumours have started to fly. The question has been raised of impending government appointments and who will go where. In particular, rumours relate to the person whom some describe as the arch priest of spontaneous moral indignation. This person is also sometimes referred to as the expert of predetermined moral outrage. This person, who took 20 years to decide he was in the wrong Party, is none other than Senator Chipp.Senator Chipp coined the phrase: `We should keep the bastards honest. Speculation is now mounting that Senator Chipp is about to sell, or has already sold, his birthright in that respect. Rumour has it that his time has come and that, within six or 12 months-honourable senators can place various bets depending on the period that they put on it-Senator Chipp will retire. I raise the matter of rumours in the Senate because I think Senator Chipp should know that these rumours are circulating about him, and, accordingly, he will then have an opportunity publicly to clear the air with respect to these rumours and to put the situation straight. I think he should be telling us whether he wants to retire, and he should be telling us when. Will he retire before the next election or will he wait until after the next election in the hope that he gets back; retire a month, two months or six months after that and have a casual vacancy that ensures that we have an Australian Democrat in the Senate for just a little longer than most of us would like to see?I am sure that Senator Chipp will take the opportunity to respond to these comments at a later stage. But having heard the rumours I turned my mind to exactly what sort of position he may be interested in. Of course, he would not be interested in political patronage because back in 1983 he made a very nice speech about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and indicated that he did not want to return to the bad old days of jobs for the boys. Some other people have been so unkind as to suggest that he will do endorsements for private companies. The one that has been suggested to me is the Wrigleys chewing gum company because, as his behaviour in this place indicates, he must be a very good customer. Other suggestions have been that Sir Nicholas Shehadies appointment is coming to a close and that Senator Chipp might like to move off to the Special Broadcasting Service. Perhaps he would like a position on the Board of Qantas Airways Ltd or Trans Australia Airlines or the National Library of Australia. Perhaps when the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is formed-if it is-Senator Chipp would like a position there.There are numerous positions that Senator Chipp could have: I am sure that he would be interested in a position on the Film Censorship Board or on the Australian Science and Technology Council. All these areas that I mention relate to areas of Senator Chipps interest. Perhaps he would like a position on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or its advisory council. Perhaps the Commission for the Future would provide an interesting sideline. It is pointless to go on and speculate through the whole list of government appointments that could come up in the relatively near future and which Senator Chipp could accept were the offer to be made. If a deal has been done between Senator Chipp and the Government for a particular appointment some would say that it makes what is referred to as the Gair affair and the night of the long prawns spring back into the minds of all Australians. We all know that some, if not all, of the other Democrats are hovering around the Democrats throne; so presumably they are keen to see him go. I take this opportunity to air these rumours-namely, that Senator Chipp is about to be bought off by the Government with a plush job--

name: Senator NEWMAN
content: —I rise to speak tonight on a matter of concern to my electorate-namely, the threat to the airline services to the Bass Strait islands. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) announced recently the adoption by government of an aviation cost recovery policy plan to apply from 1 July 1986 for the use of aviation facilities and services provided by the Federal Government. Airlines of Tasmania Pty Ltd, which flies regularly to the Bass Strait islands and the west coast and north west of Tasmania, is facing a huge increase as a result of Federal Government action which it can ill afford. This airline is a small commuter airline which carried approximately 38,000 passengers in 1984-85 and a modest profit has been expected for the first time this year. The airline already pays $60,000 per annum for the use of airports, registration of planes, et cetera.As a consequence of the Ministers decision the charges for this little airline will go from $60,000 to over $150,000 in the first year. This amount of $150,000 is the amount which will be due after allowance of a $2m subsidy package to help country commuter airlines during the transition to the new charging arrangements. Airlines of Tasmania will expect to receive its share of the $2m which is to be distributed between 29 commuter airlines in Australia; that is an average of only $68,000 each. In 1987, therefore, it will be expected to pay approximately $150,000. In 1988, with the temporary assistance removed, the charges will go to $340,000. Let us survey that situation again. Airlines of Tasmania is being expected to move from $60,000 to $340,000 in just two years. That is a jump of 466.6 per cent in charges over two years. Only a government without any understanding of small business would impose such sudden increases in governmental charges on small businesses. I am talking about a business with an annual turnover of less than $3m. The company has claimed that it is becoming a tax collection agency for the Government.I remind the Government that it is not just the little airline that will suffer from this sudden huge imposition of extra charges. The people of Flinders and King Islands have no other alternative means of transport off the islands but air. The people of Flinders Island are totally dependent on Airlines of Tasmania Pty Ltd for regular transport to hospital, the doctor, the dentist, schools, stock and station agents, shops et cetera. The telephone calls to the Tasmanian mainland are subscriber trunk dialling calls and it is interesting to note that even Launceston Airport in the meteorological report which was released today is described as an isolated provincial airport. How much more isolated are the people of the Bass Strait islands? They will obviously have to face increased fares in the region of 5 per cent to 7 per cent. The Independent Air Fares Committee which sets fares is duty bound to include these costs in its calculations. There is no possibility that they can be absorbed by the airline. If numbers of passengers drop as a result of the increase in air fares, so too will the frequency of services have to be reduced, thus increasing the isolation of the islanders. As if the increase in costs is not bad enough, the islanders need their only airstrip upgraded.It is ironic that in my first visit to Flinders Island since becoming a senator a few weeks ago, one of the primary concerns of the islanders was the need for the upgrading and night lighting of the airstrip at Whitemark. These people are entirely dependent upon air travel, but have been trying in vain to have their runway resheeted. They need night lighting which now is possible since the introduction of hydro-electric power to the island which would enable the local hills to be lit at night. Night lighting would be invaluable in enabling existing services to be more flexible and to enable better utilisation of the flying hours and the available aircraft. It goes without saying that it would assist greatly in the constant air-sea rescues which take place in Bass Strait and also in the service of the Flying Doctor. The local hospital on the island covers cases of small emergencies and medical cases. All maternity cases and serious casualties are evacuated to the Tasmanian mainland.Considerable amounts of freight are taken by small commuter airlines to and from the islands. The freight will also be required to carry the increased charges generated by the Government. Speedy carriage of perishables for consumption on the island and freight of seafoods away from the islands is imperative. I remind the Government that these increases come on the heels of the withdrawal last year of the 10 per cent subsidy on air fares from Tasmania to the mainland. The islanders can thus justifiably claim to have been doubly disadvantaged. While I can applaud attempts to reduce the costs of government expenditure and trust that the Government will make serious attempts to reduce the size of its deficit, I call on the Government to reconsider the means by which these charges will be implemented. Bearing in mind the isolation of the islanders and their dependence on air transport, I ask the Government to look once again at the speed at which these new impositions will be placed on the very small commuter airlines in isolated areas.

name: Senator REID
content: —I wish to refer tonight to the plight of many in the Australian Public Service who are in the category of being redeployed and the difficulties they face in obtaining other employment. I am not for one minute suggesting that it is an easy problem for management in the Public Service, but I want to stress the problems of those who find themselves in this situation. It has happened to a large number of people in recent times. It covers a number of departments that I know of. As I said, I am not suggesting that the departments are not trying to solve the problem. I ask that the Minister responsible for the Public Service take up the matter with the Public Service Board and perhaps work out some guidelines and some principles which would operate to assist those who find themselves in the category of being redeployed and without a meaningful job.There are two men in the Department of Territories in particular whom I thought I would use by way of example. I think both of them were invalided out of the remand centre. That is a particularly stressful place for them to have been employed. One man was then offered and accepted a Third Division status position as a clerk class 2/3 in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. He held this position for some time until he was told he was incorrectly placed and was reverted to a base grade clerk. He said:This position was quite unsuitable and I was informed that I would not be able to work in that type of environment.He did some courses at the Reid technical and further education college to occupy himself and to give him additional interest. As a result he lost about $7,000 in salary. The Department also stopped his first aid allowance as he was no longer in a permanent position. He said:All I have ever asked for is a suitable permanent position and to retain pay similar to my income whilst working at the Remand Centre.I have had nothing but good references from each section of the Department that has used my services.It is a fact that as a Redeployed Officer I am disadvantaged and cannot be given higher duties although I have seen others within the system rise rapidly through the ranks.It seems that while a person is in a status of being redeployed it is almost impossible to apply for another position and get any form of advancement. The problem is that after a period people feel that nobody cares about them. That may not, in fact, be the case, it may be that the Department is unable to do anything. These men feel that they are just on the scrapheap of humanity and there is nothing left for them. It is frustrating, it causes additional stress and I think it has an impact on their families as well. It is often suggested that they go back to the Commonwealth Medical Officer, get a sick note to cover being away, or all sorts of devices to, in a sense, almost fill in time. Again, this man refers to the frustration of applying for positions. He has served with the Scout organisation for a very long time in a number of countries before coming to the Australian Capital Territory and he has a record of service in sporting fields. He has not bludged along on the system. He says that all he wants is a meaningful job.The other case history I have is similar. It concerns a man of 55 years of age. In many respects it is perhaps worse for a man at that age to find himself without a permanent position, unattached and to be redeployed. He said to me that under the system redeployees have no chance. That is the pity of it. They really feel that there is very little left to live for. He also said that to be redeployed makes working life totally meaningless. I am not blaming the departments because perhaps they do not have a meaningful job to offer. I think it is a matter of looking at the policy that governs the situation of redeployment and trying to find a system which can make life meaningful for those in the Public Service who find themselves in that category. It may only be that they cannot work in a particular type of employment. Many have repetitive strain injuries. A number of bus drivers have been stressed and have been told not to drive buses any more. I think greater effort needs to be made to make life meaningful for these people so that they avoid the frustration and stress of being redeployed and feeling that they have been left behind.

name: Senator RYAN
content: —Senator Reid has raised matters concerning the Australian Public Service and redeployment. I will refer that to the relevant Minister. Senator Newman has raised matters concerning airline charges. I will also refer that to the relevant Minister. Senator Vanstone raised matters concerning the alleged motives of Senator Chipp in a number of matters. I am a little distressed that Senator Vanstone has raised those matters. In the absence of Senator Chipp or any representatives of his Party, obviously I can make no comment on them, but I hope that Senator Chipp will have the opportunity to respond to what seemed to me to be fairly serious allegations and perhaps allegations that should not have been raised in the absence of Australian Democrat senators.Question resolved in the affirmative.Senate adjourned at 10.49 p.m.
